This game is huge. It throws items at you to learn them might take years. Levels are not optained easily though you have to really fight for them. The bosses give no quarter. I come with a Skyrim background and in comparison this "old one" seems to be ridiculously easy, but the questlines are a bit more, hm, "illustrated", in ER you have to really search for the next hint/encounter. The gamer scene around ER is also very engaged and I find myself more than once trying this or that build/weapon for a first after watching a video about it. This game is just great.

New 2024 honest review: 
Game isn't fun for me at all. Movements in the game feel sluggish and slow. The way you get rewarded with new weapons etc is very bland and boring. The developers don't really seem like big fans of multiplayer because they don't allow you to do everything in the game with a friend. The only way you can get around this is with the use of some cool mods. Other users opinions will differ of course but I'll have to say the idea of mastering each fight in the game is cool but the movements just feel too realistic for me and by that I mean slow.

Old review was positive:
Please at some point allow workshop mods. I really want to play as Kratos or even Jetstream Sam from MGRR. I want to fight Tomas the tank engine! Or even our Elden lord Shrek

Combat is extremely jank in all the soulsborne series. Inputs are constantly ignored/inconsistent, enemies are constantly assaulting you nonstop giving you no window of opportunity to attack even with the fastest builds. Enemies have very weird timing on their attacks like pausing to subvert your expectations. I find overall the experience poor. Iframes don't appear to matter as much, timings are also odd, like the Iframes window seems to shift which makes it very inconsistent. Having some enemies do attack flurries make it impossible to roll out of because it doesn't stop. This is coming from some one who's beaten all of the Dark Souls and DLCs. It's not hard because of skill, it's hard because of bad game design that subvert every expectations and makes it feel jank to play rather than fluid.

I really enjoyed this game. However, there are some stuff I don't like about it.
First of all, writing. I don't mean "lore" in general - it's pretty dope. But how the characters (especially bosses) talk... gosh, it's weak. In Dark Souls 1, for example, bosses were silent and menacing. Here, when you approach a boss, they consider it their duty to say something to you, and their sayings sound so dull, lackluster and pretentious! It's like in anime, when a villain says something like: "You beat me... But it wasn't even my final form!" I'd like it, if it was once, maximum twice, but it happens almost every goddamn time!
Also, about bosses. Why are they so obsessed with using parts of their bodies as a weapon? I don't mean their fists, for example, but a lot of bosses like to cut off/tear off their own body parts and turn them into weapons. Again, it was cool for the first time, but it happens really often.
Catacombs are boring (and you have to visit a lot of catacombs). They're gray, full of dull skeletons and imps. There is serious lack of variety in enemy design - multi-colored zombies, some knights... 
I hate Lake of Rot. Yeah, when I played DS1 and 2, I didn't like the Blighttown and Black Gulch, but they're much better than this stupid lake. In the Blighttown you can completely evade contacting poison, so everything depends on your skills. Here you HAVE TO contact this freaking disease! It's like Farron Keep in DS3. And Farron Keep was awful.
But all the other stuff I really liked :)

I love this game a lot, but what I love so much more is how unplayable it is on PC

Edit: Go to your Nvidia control panel by right clicking anywhere on the desktop then change the shader cache size to unlimited, thus negating most if not all stuttering issues.  Also making sure any and all overlays are off helps tremendously for performance.  I can now truly recommend this game

My first Soulslike game. I was looking for an RPG with open world but I am not into Soulslike games. I gave it a try.
I dont like to study moves/attacks/dodges of every boss in the game. This game is so annoying. Not for all people.

On the other hand the game is a masterpiece. The music, graphic, art style of the world and monsters is incredible. A lot of work was put into development of this game.

The annoying part is to learn the moves/attacks of bosses. I may die over 30 times and still dont know how to avoid some of the attacks. It is also a luck in my case that a boss use type of attack I can dodge/avoid.
The game dont tell you which of the summoning spells is better. You dont see the stats. I used Banished Knight Oleg +10 and he is not that good. Then I used Mimic tear ashes +10 and it is way much better. More DMG more HP, range attack, etc. Much easier to fight bosses. I didnt have any stats/information so I stick to Oleg throught entire game except of final Boss.
It is not pleasant that you have to search in the internet what is good or bad.

I became an Elder Lord but I will not play any other Soulslike game ever again. This game is a masterpiece but not for everyone.

A Masterpiece Reborn with Every Playthrough! 

The feeling of revisiting the Lands Between never gets old with the variety of weapons.

If you're on the fence about diving into the vast, breathtaking world of Elden Ring, let me be the nudge that sends you plummeting into one of the most rewarding gaming experiences of our generation. 
What truly sets Elden Ring apart is its unparalleled weapon variety. Whether you fancy yourself a nimble swordsman, a brute force hammer wielder, or a sorcerer with arcane might, there's something here indeed!

But let's talk about the crown jewel of Elden Ring: Leyndell, Royal Capital. There's no feeling quite like the first time you set foot in this majestic, fallen city. The architecture, the enemies, the lore, and oh, the music. The haunting melodies that accompany your exploration through Leyndell are nothing short of a masterpiece, echoing the glory and tragedy of the Erdtree's guardians. It's a favorite area for it's music next to Limgrave for me!

and with Shadow of the Erdtree in the coming months, there's never been a better time to dive in! See you in the Lands Between, fellow Tarnished. May your journey be grand, and may you find your own grace.

Everything about this game is the absolute culmination of every other FromSoftware soulsborne games. It is absolute perfection. The open world is absolutely dripping with atmosphere and lore coming out of every crack and crevice you can find. There are secrets littered all over the place and really does an amazing job with giving enough lore to make a cohesive story line to follow while also leaving enough unknowns to allow people to theorise why and how things happened.

The music is an absolute delight and the boss fights are varied, fun and best of all, difficult. If you were a fan of Dark Souls I - III, Bloodborne and Sekiro, then this will sate your taste AND THEN SOME. If there is any game you want to buy and have a challenge as well as an amazing story and world aesthetic, then buy Elden Ring.

100% Completion Review.

What an experience. A satisfying and expansive open world, with beautiful sights and decrepit mysteries to uncover, all combined together with the Souls formula to make a one of a kind, masterpiece. There's almost nothing that I can't praise about this game, it's all extremely excellent. Especially look out for the challenging boss fights, this one does not hold back. While it has very few flaws, like re-use of assets or a tiny few performance issues, it still holds up as a nearly flawless video game.

Elden Ring is a lovely experience that I believe everyone should try out. It's challenging, but satisfying and rewarding, mechanically intricate and lets the player guide their own experience. Don't be afraid to ask for help though, you might need it. Even I had some help from my friends, as a newbie, they were extremely knowledgeable and helpful even now, so thank you to them. Elden Ring is also playable with friends, which while quite limited, is still great to hop on and just traverse The Lands Between together.

10/10, thank you for reading.

P.S. My favorite boss is Malenia. And also try the Seamless Co-Op mod!

I started playing this game 2 weeks ago (5th Feb 24) and had 30 hours after one week bc I just couldn't get enough of it! it is my first real Soulsbourne game and it is just as fun and exciting and rewarding and challenging as I expected. In my 45+ hours of gameplay I have rage-quitted only once trying to fight the Crucible Knight: I was a bit under leveled for him and just couldn't defeat him, especially in the second half of the boss fight where he used magic wings and a magic dragon tail. After rage-quitting I leveled a little the next day and eventually managed to defeat him. And exactly two days later the trailer for SHADOW OF THE ERDTREE drops. Man was I even more hooked into this game afterwards. And despite all the other amazing new gameplay mechanics (like foot-weapons and throwing bowls filled with burning oil) I am most excited about getting the exact same magical wings the Crucible Knight used!

Needless to say, the game is not for people, who want to relax and have a relaxing evening, but for those  who love a challenge. And I'm one of those.

I can't wait for the DLC! (I NEED ME THOSE WINGS)

For AMD this is respectively [u]SMT[/u], and [u]SVM.[/u]

I've played every Souls game minus Demon's Souls. BloodBorne being my favorite FromSoft game and DS2 being my favorite Dark Souls game. After the hundreds of hours put into those games its easy to point out the good and the bad. FromSoft have come a long way and have been able to encompass all of the positive aspects of their previous souls games and put them all into Elden Ring. 
If you are new to the Souls-Like style of games I feel that Elden Ring would be an excellent place to start your journey. It's world is beautiful, full of secrets, and endless areas to explore. The game has a unique and familiar charm only Souls games can offer. It's challenging but not impossible. It gives such a sense of accomplishment and growth as a player. I cannot recommend it enough! 

Pros: 
Beautiful open world environment 
Combat feels smooth and rewarding 
Endless battle styles and character customization 
Large amount of unique weapons, armor, and spells 
Bosses are intriguing and at times mesmerizing 
Jolly cooperation! 

Cons: 
Dungeons offer uniqueness but are recycled 
Field Bosses/Dungeon Bosses are recycled 
Many re-skinned enemies 

Be Good To Each Other and Stay Safe Out There!

This is from the mindset of a person whose played the previous titles from FromSoft.

I played this game on release, and it's probably the best open-world I've ever experienced. The sound design, art design, atmosphere, lore are all AMAZING, but.. I think this is probably my least favourite SoulsBorne game.. (i haven't played DS2 or Sekiro yet). I'm also gonna add that I had an extremely buggy first experience at launch which has soured my opinion on the game overall, even after most of the bugs have been fixed(some are still in there though).

While the bosses look awesome and are well crafted, visually, I don't find enjoyment in fighting most of them. I can count on one hand how many I actually felt satisfied after killing. They're really tedious, repetitive and the reward never really made it worth it, at least for me. The game really didn't need so many bosses, cause you can tell they had to re-use bosses to compensate. I'd rather have fewer, but fulfilling bosses.

A lot of the enemies, bosses items and NPCs feel a bit "copy and paste" from older FromSoft games, visually and animation wise. It's not THAT big of a problem considering the Dark Souls franchise has done that in all their games, it just bothers me a bit considering it's not another Dark Souls game, it's a new standalone game. If it was just like a small handful I wouldn't mind but I recognise so many re-skins and animations that are just ported from their older games.

Looting is extremely unsatisfying. The amount of times I've worked my way through a boss or an area or just a specific section with a chest reward at the end, only to open it and get a flower, or something that was useless. It's just playing with your expectations, under-delivering BIG TIME and a waste of a chest. When i see a chest I expect something more "special" like and armour set/piece, weapon, talisman, tool or quest item, and yes chests are used for that too but majority of the time it's just trash. The good loot is often just on random copses in the game that you might just run past if you're not a loot goblin like my ass.

In my first playthrough at launch, I got really far into the game, near the end of Crumbling Farum Azula, but i got so tired of forcing myself to "give it another try" that I stopped playing and forgot about it. It had gotten so bad that I saved areas for second playthroughs, so that I'd have another reason to play the game more.
I started a couple of other playthroughs after but never got far with them either and gave up earlier. It wasn't until I tried playing it with a mod (seamless-coop) which made it a lot more fun and I found myself wanting to play more. Still had my moments where I just did not enjoy myself at all, it also kind of removed the "rewarding" feeling of defeating a boss since it makes it easier, but it's not like the game had that to begin with either way imo. 

The game is not bad, FAR from it. I just have some issues with it that really ruins my experience with the game, most of them being issues with the boss design, everything else i could try to excuse.
Generally i do recommend it cause its not a bad game, i'd just rather play Dark Souls 3 for the 672nd time(over-exaggeration, I have just played through the game more than I can count).

I hope the upcoming DLC is better than the base game, especially the bosses, and I actually have high hopes, and expectations for it. I believe it'll be good and maybe it'll change my overall opinion of the game.

[b]Elden Ring[/b] descends upon the entire PC gaming landscape like a Tarnished plummeting from the grace of the Erdtree, tasked with piecing together the shards of an open-world experience so vast and unforgiving, it could only be the brainchild of FromSoftware, Hidetaka Miyazaki, in collaboration with George R. R. Martin. This collaboration has birthed a world so dense and intricate, it makes the lore of "Dark Souls" seem like bedtime stories for wayward knights.

[b]Graphics & Performance:[/b]
This masterpiece of a game is a mixed bag of splendid vistas and occasional graphical hiccups that remind you of the game's mortal origins. The Lands Between are breathtaking, offering landscapes that range from hauntingly beautiful to "I need to pause and take a breather" levels of oppressive. On PC, performance can vary like the effectiveness of your dodges; with the right hardware, (capped at 60fps) the game runs smoother than a butter-slathered Slip 'N Slide, but on older rigs, it can feel like trudging through the swamps of Aeonia.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
[b]Elden Ring[/b] is an evolution of the Souls formula, refined to a radiant sheen. Combat is as punishing and rewarding as explaining the game's plot coherently. The introduction of horseback combat and a sprawling open world filled with secrets, dungeons, and bosses so tough they'll make you question your life choices, elevates the experience. The freedom to explore and tackle challenges in a non-linear fashion ensures that masochism has never been more inviting.

[b]Story & Lore:[/b]
The narrative, co-crafted by George R. R. Martin, is as deep and convoluted as one might expect. Players are left to piece together the lore from cryptic conversations, environmental storytelling, and item descriptions that require a PhD in FromSoftware-ese to fully comprehend. The story is there, somewhere, hidden beneath layers of mystery and the occasional Elden Lord ready to pound you into the ground for looking at them funny.

[b]Sound & Music:[/b]
The sound design and music are, simply put, a triumph. Combat sounds pack the punch of a Great Rune in your face, while the score ranges from hauntingly serene to "this is the end of me" boss battle symphonies. The auditory experience in [b]Elden Ring[/b] does more than just complement the visuals and gameplay; it elevates the entire experience into something ethereal.

[b]The Verdict:[/b]
[b]Elden Ring[/b] is an epic in every sense of the word. It's a game that respects your intelligence enough to get utterly lost in its world without a guiding hand, ensuring that victories are as sweet as discovering a shortcut after hours of peril. It's a testament to the art of game design, even if it occasionally feels like it was created by a sadistic architect who enjoys watching players fall to their doom. For those willing to embrace its challenge, [b]Elden Ring[/b] offers an adventure as rewarding as it is punishing, proving once again that FromSoftware is the master of making us love the pain.

     A truly beautiful masterwork of FromSoftware, their magnum opus. Despite this being a game brimming with love for design and finely-tuned mechanics, this game made me hate FromSoftware with a vindictive ire that I have yet to feel for any other company. The loathing that I feel when loading this game is akin to going to work, or school, or even just basic yet tedious house chores. Never before or since has a video game made me feel such irksome and fervent irritation. I quite literally, actually feel it under my skin at times. This game makes me feel my blood pressure raise; a sensation not familiar to me since my first time playing Dark Souls 1. I do not consider that a net positive, however I felt it prudent to note. Never before have the impacts of my own minuscule and minute mistakes caused such violent and visceral knee-jerk reactions as when fighting the most basic of enemies or the earliest of roaming-bosses. 

     Despite all of the aforementioned and highly discouraging information I have listed above, I still play due to some suspected masochistic impulses, self-hateful tendencies, or otherwise straightforward bullheadedness and unshakable stubbornness combined with a need to prove some ability to meet unnecessary and meaningless achievements to myself. As if by completing this quite difficult and punishing video game I will stumble upon some self-actualization through pattern recognition or simple brute-forcing of the situation.

    When looking back on my past experience with the rest of this series over the years, I have come to the conclusion that this game is Dark Souls with Bloodborne bosses. I'm sure that this is a common feeling among the community who have come into contact with this purulent heap of enticing suffering. This game feels smooth yet, clunky. It feels open or even free-form, yet air-tight. It feels impactful and all the more so when you mistime a dodge by fractions of a second and die to the most mundane things. I can never get a word in when fighting against bosses, so here are all the words I could think of saying. The exploration is perfected, the weapon system is expansive with options to fit any niche you might want to try. the options for magic are varied and satisfying to those who enjoy such a play-style. And yet... with all these options available to me, being able to travel far and wide to distant lands to power-level and omega-buff my weapon to fuck-all... I still insist on fighting the Tree Sentinel and Ulcerated Tree Spirit at base level because I hate myself.
Only complaint is that post-Leyndell is a bit grindy but other then that its a perfect game. Also I dislike the quest system.

I completed Elden Ring on console and decided to revisit it on PC. However, getting back into the game has proven more challenging than anticipated. While the game boasts stunning visuals and occasional moments of enjoyment, it also resurfaces all the frustrations that made me question why I am playing it again. Yet, here I am, giving it another shot, perhaps motivated by the promise of DLC content.

Elden Ring demands both skill and luck, particularly evident in encounters where boss attack patterns defy logic. It can feel frustrating to dodge only to get hit and suffer significant damage. While some games handle leveling and progression more effectively, Elden Ring seems to lack meaningful differentiation in this regard. Ultimately, success often hinges on memorizing enemy move sets, a repetitive task that quickly becomes fing tiresome.

I must admit that my gastrointestinal tract has been quite active during my gaming sessions of Elden Ring. The volume of flatulence I have emitted is nothing short of remarkable, and I cannot help but marvel at the sheer magnitude of gas that has been expelled from my body.

The reverberations caused by the expulsion of gas have been felt throughout the room, and I have no doubt that the decibel level of these emissions would rival that of a jet engine. The noxious fumes that have been unleashed have left me questioning my dietary choices, as the pungent aroma could easily be mistaken for a chemical weapon. Despite the overwhelming stench, I soldier on and continue to fight the demigods with a stoic determination, all while the air around me is thick with my flatulence.

## Technical issues ##

60fps lock and ultrawide support in 2024 is still baffling, especially when modders have been unlocking the FPS counter in their games succesfully for years. They haven't even bothered to improve on this one bit.
Their frame limiter is still HORRIBLE and provides terrible frametimes, ALWAYS. This is a known issue and affects their titles on console as well. Removing their FPS lock and using a better frame limiter (like rivatuner) fixes the frame pacing issues.

This game is an outlier in the market since it has Raytracing without any upscaling solution, on an already graphically intensive game at 4k. It doesn't need saying that raytracing in this game is basically not playable at a stable 4K 60fps without a 4090, and for no reason at all. So it was included and it looks great but it cannot be used unless you like playing in photo mode. There are mods which easily enable DLSS for this game. Implementing DLSS or any other upscaling solution is the minimum that the market is at. Japanese devs still have issues with basic PC needs, even though they're slowly improving.

Other than that, performance issues from launch have actually been fixed. Make SURE to have DOCP enabled (or XMP if you're on Intel) in your mobo. 

But I cannot recommend 

My specs:

R7 5800X3D
RTX 3080 FE
Dual channel 8GB + 8GB 3600Mhz RAM
NVME SSD


## Game ##

The most overrated Souls ever. These are my rankings for context:
S. Bloodborne, Demon's Souls
A. Dark Souls (would be S without the cut content), Sekiro
B. Elden Ring
C. Dark Souls II, Dark Souls III (S for the DLC), 

Not much of a new IP, but an expanded Dark Souls with a new coat of paint. It's still very good, but grandiosity has taken space away from quality. Bosses are recycled, dungeons are recycled, animations are recycled from older titles, the open world is innovative and with great surprises, but at the same time can be boring for most of the time. Balance can be lacking.

Copy and paste dungeons plagued with artificial difficulty are overabundant and really drag the game into the mud. You will find the worst level designs ever in "Hero's Tomb's", with fast and unkillable chariots one-shotting you when you don't run perfectly through the labyrints. In one of the dungeons you can actually destroy one of them, in the most unintuitive way possible. They don't offer any satisfaction even after clearing them, only a sour aftertaste of frustration.

Elden Ring is at its best when you reach a closed level interconnected with the open world. The Academy of Raya Lucaria, Leyndell, the Sewers, Siofra, the Halightree...They all make the open world 
pale in comparison.

The game's strongest strongest points are the art design, the addictive gameplay loop, the expansive and immersive world and the variety of builds.

It's been praised endlessly for being an open-world without quest markers, but it's not the first to do it and it's not the best at it either. NPC quests are A W F U L. At the worst they've ever been in the Souls Series.

## Quest design ##

NPC markers don't help because they don't tell you *where* NPCs will show up, they tell you the positions of NPCs you've already visited. After they move, you have to find them again.

Want to complete a character's questline? Sure! Here's this M A S S I V E map. You have to:
1. Get into one of the world's areas at random early enough so that you don't miss the quest
2. Come back to random locations at random times. Good luck finding them.
3. Find "Layla" or "Nepheli", or x new character without knowing how they look and where you should look for them. Good luck checking the whole world to no avail.
4. Beat a boss at the other end to the world to proceed with the quest's next step. Rinse and repeat.

The ACTUAL way to complete quests is to check the wiki for it. There is no other solution other than accept that you will miss on huge integral parts of the game without reading the wiki.


## Bossess and fighting mechanics ## 

Bosses are very hit and miss. Margit and Godfrey provide some of the best bosses the Souls series have ever offered, while the worst offenders are horribly balanced and show poor design that wasn't present in earlier titles. 

The gameplay highlights compared to other entry in the Souls series are:

1. Horseback fighting 
2. Enemies have delayed attacks that punish panic rolling
3. The jumping allows to dodge shockwaves far more effectively and with more reward 

Horseback fighting isn't very impressive, and looks like it wasn't given too much thought into. While it can be very fun, there is no balance to it. You *will* get hit by random attacks since you don't have a way to dodge or block. The added mobility can make up for it in some slow fights or for ranged combat, but it can be a real pain for melee. You *will* get stunlocked and get knocked off your horse, without being able to improve on that. Honestly, they really should have given some way to get i-frames on horse.

They deserve less credit for the third point since there is *no* in-game tutorial explaining that jumping actually shrinks your hurtbox and is an important form of dodging. It's also not clear which attacks you can use it for (shockwaves make sense, but not really Gurranq's fangs).

Great Runes are mostly inconsequential and should just be permanent upgrades.


## Too many fast attacks, can feel like playing Sekiro without the parry. ##

Malenia with her waterflow dance. Radhan before being patched. THE FUCKING REVENANTS.

The final boss is basically a bullet hell that should be fought on Torrent while the game doesn't allow for that to happen. 

On the bright side. They have done a nice job of rebalancing the game, and they have separated PVE and PVP scaling. And you can actually dodge Malenia's waterflow dance with the new fast roll.


## Lore ##

The lore can go from great to very confusing and uninteresting, especially when you compare it to other entries in the series. While some concepts like the rune of death are inherently cool, others can bore you to death and make you wonder why you should care, being seemingly irrelevant. ESSENTIAL cutscenes are not present in the game. You can't understand Marika's grief without watching official game story teasers on YouTube. You don't know who tf Godwin is for half of the game, and you probably still don't understand it afterward. You haven't seen Radagon fight Malenia and lots of other important lore info is straight up missing from the game and only available with other forms of media.

What this game really needs is a bestiary/archive/index with lore, where voices that link into each other as you slowly unlock objects, so that you can connect them with characters. It's hard to remember what you read in the object you picked up 20 hours ago. While this sort of narrative could work for passionate players in older titles, the size of this one really kills the experience unless you go full in and start taking notes.

The intro, while cool, is just the naming of characters and doesn't provide anything for the game's lore. It's definetely not enough to start such an ambitious narrative.

Important names always start with G, R and M, and aside from the tribute to Martin this just makes everything more confusing, and characters like to use double names.
Characters like Smithing master Hewg, Sir Gideon Ofnir, Radhan, Malenia, Margit, Rogier, Ranni are great and super interesting but media mix, cut content, quest mechanics and translation issues get in the way of the enjoyement.

Good lore is not confusing lore. They really could have done a better job with it, like they did with Demon's Souls and in part Bloodborne (yikes for translation errors).

The game leaves lots of unanswered questions, hopefully which will be answered in the DLC.

## Conclusion ##

Still better than most games you can pick up. It has lots of great moments, but there are far better Souls games. Can't recommend a game with a 60fps lock in 2024.

I was always so scared to play FromSoftware games.  I tried Dark Souls when it first came out and couldn't quite figure out what I was doing.  Elden Ring is great for beginners and really helps bridge the gap for people who want to play Souls games but are too scared to try.  At the same token this game does scale its difficulty and becomes very difficult in late game.  By then though you are confident in your combat and defense abilities that you can easily figure it out!  I also enjoy the open world aspect...if you can't figure out how to defeat a certain boss you can just leave, level up, and come back whenever you feel like it!  Sometimes skip them altogether!  It's such a good game and I can't push it enough to anyone who wants to try a Souls game.

A Masterpiece of Adventure and Awe

Elden Ring isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s an odyssey. FromSoftware has woven a tapestry of wonder, challenge, and discovery that transcends mere entertainment. Hereâ€™s why it stands tall among gaming legends:


-World Unveiled: In my 100+ hours within the Lands Between, I was spellbound. The vistasâ€”majestic, haunting, and awe-inspiringâ€”left me breathless. The sheer scope of this enormous open world invites exploration at every turn.

-FromSoftwareâ€™s Evolution: Elden Ring takes the baton from The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and sprints with it. Freedom and curiosity drive the experience. Yet, seamlessly woven into this vast expanse lies a full-fledged Dark Souls adventure. Itâ€™s a harmonious blend that defies expectations.

-Organic Storytelling: The grand narrative unfolds subtly. As a â€œTarnished,â€ blessed by grace, you journey toward becoming an Elden Lord. The golden tree, the enigmatic charactersâ€”I pieced together their tales, hungry for more. George R.R. Martinâ€™s influence adds layers to this epic saga.

-Side Stories: Forget waypoints and exclamation marks. Elden Ringâ€™s characters are real, with their own agendas. They donâ€™t beckon; they exist. Their fates intertwine with yours, shaped by your choices. Itâ€™s storytelling at its most organic.

-Combat Mastery: The combat systemâ€”challenging, rewarding, and thrillingâ€”demands skill. Each swing, dodge, and parry feels consequential. Boss encounters are symphonies of desperation and triumph.
Visual Splendor: Improved model quality, intricate scenes, dynamic lightingâ€”Elden Ring is a feast for the eyes. The world breathes, pulsates, and whispers secrets.

-Community and Lore: As we unravel the lore, we become part of a global fellowship. Lore videos, discussions, and theories enrich the experience. Elden Ring isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s a shared journey.

Character Depth: Side stories that matter.
Combat Brilliance: Skill-based and satisfying.

Masterpiece. Plain and simple.

It is not a game you can just enter, grab some easy dopamine and leave. It is a massive, slow burn, immersive experience. It goes on and on and on and quality never drops. Start playing it blindly, with a lot of spare time, and you will find a very rewarding and deep experience.

Compared to other FromSoft games, the art direction here is unparalleled - the final boss is one of the best sound and visual experiences I have ever had in videogames. The more colorful environments compared to the very bland Dark Souls III are a very good change. The writing is very hidden sometimes, but it made me speculate and try to investigate some very compelling mysteries while playing, and that is the best part of FromSoft writing for me. All the plot twists will be rewarding and make sense if you do your research.

PVP is, at the very least, much more varied than previous entries in the series. I tried at least 20 builds, all of them very different and viable. The colosseums are great and really let you have a more fluid PVP experience. Some people may find that the increased "power scale" of the skills detract from the original, more basic-attacks-focused duels, but I find the more powerful skills add an additional tactical layer I really enjoyed.

Really worth every penny. I was afraid it would be more of the same, a "dark souls with horses", but the changes were really enough to make this a very special game. Thank you, Michael Zaki!

I'm probably about the only person that beat the game, and even Malenia, and going to give it a No.  I just don't enjoy Fromsoftware games it seems.  Everything about feeling a sense of accomplishment and all that, I don't feel with their games.  Every boss after mid game or so just felt like "well, the misery is finally over."

I've periodically and slowly been working through Nioh, and I actually do enjoy that game, I feel like I'm developing actual strategies on a boss by boss basis.  In this game, my build ended up in the dreaded "Jump+L1" trend.  It helps I like in Nioh that item selection layout much better.  This game, and other Fromsoftware games have all your consumables on a single D-pad button (if using controller), and all the spells on a separate single one.  The other two being taken up by weapon and shield.  Nioh used a different way to select weapons and, gave more item options available at any one instance without so much swapping.  One item per D-pad direction, with a second set of 4 a single swap button away.  You get less overall options, but it's much snappier to use and I actually give a damn about item use in Nioh.

I'm also not fond of how missable everything is in this game, because I ended up having to read up on nearly every quest line to make any progress in them.  Blaidd for example, I had to look up how to initiate talking to him, I never noticed the one boss is who he was looking for, never noticed the summon spot, never saw him standing nearby outside after defeating the boss, and eventually when I got to Ranni, I was left wondering just where the hell he was.  They later hide him from you again because of spoiler reasons, and by this point I was too frustrated with every other quest line to care to hunt him down myself.

Boss reuse, to the point of them becoming common enemies for some of the earliest side bosses, just got excessive, too.  It features over 100 bosses or such, but what isn't mentioned is probably 33% or more are just rehashed as harder versions in some way.  Sometimes the same boss but bigger stats.  And if you're like me, and hate the Crucible Knight as your worst nemisis, well get ready to fight him like 6 or so if you want to beat all instances of him.

I'm only writing this review because Shadow of the Erdtree was finally announced and I want to go on the record for anyone who never got around to playing it yet for whatever reason. If you heard about the DLC and are thinking "yeah, maybe now is the time I'll finally dive in", then this is directed at you.

Elden Ring is not for everyone. If you don't respect the grind, then it will kick the shit out of you without remorse. There is no easy mode, no save-scumming, no cheat codes, and absolutely no hand holding. Yeah sure.. you can rely on Youtubers and Wiki pages to tell you what some of the ULTIMATE BUILDS might be... but even if you're relying on a crutch like that, you STILL have to put the work in and "git gud" when it's all said and done. It also takes a while to even get access to all the weapons/gear that those guides expect you to be using, not to mention earning the experience needed for the build to be viable. So my suggestion to you is to worry less about building an exact carbon copy of a character that some other person already played as, and just try to take it all in and experience it for yourself first.

I got every achievement, defeated every boss, and it was the most rewarding grind I've ever embarked upon in a game. I made a lot of mistakes along the way, but I learned from every single one of them. I got my ass kicked every time I booted up the game, but every triumph I celebrated was unlike any other thanks to all of those ass-kickings. From the hardest boss fights to the most annoying mobs, you truly feel every single victory... and that's where I got hooked because the sense of accomplishment you get from progressing in Elden Ring... I'm telling you, it is the ultimate dopamine shot.

Now, I personally loved the story, but it's definitely a subjective experience. Elden Ring is a mythological story about gods and demi-gods, and if you take the time to read through the item descriptions, look closer at the game world, and try to fill in the gaps kind of like a detective would, then you will probably enjoy it too. If you are expecting the cutscenes to be the only thing you have to pay attention to in order to know what's going on, you might be disappointed. 

Without a quest menu or anything like that to keep track of things, the game forces you to do your own due diligence and keep track of the NPCs you've spoken to, and to really listen to what they say because completing side quests isn't like most open world games that just plop a waypoint down for you to walk to after you've skipped all the dialogue. You need to listen and think about it, and if you've already progressed through certain points of the main-story, then you might not even get to experience some of the side quests. This aspect of Elden Ring can be a bit frustrating because you really aren't given any indication if you've missed a part of a quest or if you missed a quest entirely until it's too late. I will just say that if you're bee-lining it straight to the main bosses, you are definitely missing a LOT of what makes the game so good (and you're also missing out on side quests that lead to valuable ITEMS and EXPERIENCE!!!). So if you don't want to miss anything, my advice is to take it all very slow, and just try to clear regions and talk to everyone you see before moving on to new areas. If you think you missed stuff, keep in mind that you can always try again in NG+. 

Multiplayer is completely optional, but opting in to allow invasions can be rewarding because testing your build against actual players is pretty fun, plus you get to also see what other people are doing with their characters. Sometimes seeing someone else in action can inspire you to try new stuff, or it can make you aware of a flaw in your own character. I will say that I personally played with the player messages turned off though because I didn't want to read possible spoilers, and I felt reading messages left by other players all over the place broke my immersion.. but to each their own.

If you've never played Elden Ring before and are finally considering a run through the game for the first time... I truly envy you because I would do anything to wipe my memory and play it again for the first time. It is a game like no other, and it will test you in more ways than one. Just don't get discouraged when you hit a wall.. because we've ALL been there... all you have to do is learn to overcome it. Once you do, I promise there is no greater feeling in all of gaming.

Compared to dark souls 3, I still think ds3 has better level design and progression. due to elden ring being an open world, the progression can be a little funky depending on the player's exploration. i also think ds3 has higher quality bosses and music(biased becus ds3 dlc fights and music were rlly good). That being said the amount of content that elden ring delivers is insane with so much diverse builds and bosses. It is the bundle of the past and adds a little innovation to keep things fresh. The lore is also just as interesting as fromsoft's other games, its still not given to us directly but its much easily digested than the souls lore. This game is also easier overall imo, only being quite challenging if the boss's resistances directly counters the build you play. 

If you are new, it definitely took a while for me to get adjusted to the genre, but it was worth it. No reason to refund over margit, go explore a bit, raise some stats and practice dodging. I dont even pass most boss's vigor checks and its very doable, even easier on solo imo.

Just to be clear I love the game! It is fantastic! This is the first time I ever played Elden Ring (at the time of writing this review). The reason why Iâ€™m giving negative is because of a boss called "Malenia, Blade of Miquella". I have died about 60-70 times to this single boss. (I know a lot of people died even more times but for me, this is the threshold)

I tried parry, dodge, shield, spears, fast weapons, strong weapons, freeze, blood loss.... basically, anything reasonable. I can still only reach Phase 2 after every 10-12 deaths, just to die from her special attack. (I have spent about 10 hours fighting THIS single boss) At first, I said to myself: "Well, well, well... this is a challenging boss!" Then it became really annoying for a long-long time....

And now this is the point where I become bored by this single boss fight.

Don't get me wrong, I still find the rest of the game amazing but when they created Malenia, they really didn't think it through. It feels like they just wanted to do something CRAZY OP boss but they ended up creating a boring one for first time players, which kind of ruins the whole experience.

Iâ€™m hoping they might change her just a tiny-tiny bit. (No major change is needed, just tiny tweaks to make it more First Timer Friendly IMO)

so after a year of playing this game I don't think this game is that bad. the bosses are re-used a lot but after taking a lot of time learning the boss movesets in this game it just comes down to "they changed the attack patterns." the enemies in this game read your inputs, other souls game did this to a smaller degree but its why this game was so hard for everyone in the beginning, because the enemies are programmed differently from the get-go which is not necessarily a good thing.
I am leaving the original unedited review from the month the game was released for historical purposes only and because I think its funny. this review was initially not recommended and I still think the majority of the enemies in this game are hot garbage and not programmed to be challenging but instead just to screw with you in as many ways as possible. this game is better than DS3 but that's not really saying much. it feels like a more complete version of ds3 if anything, but atleast it tried to be a little bit different whilst not making the entire game look like old semen residue. 
there are some things I still agree with in my original review but a lot of it is completely false and just me going through the 5 stages of grief in regards to the enemies input reading and me still trying to learn how to abuse and counter it.

if you still wanna read the original review just keep reading, otherwise I recommend it. it was made during a different era in the game before they nerfed certain enemies/bosses, changed boss attack patterns and before they nerfed casting/summoning ashes. pvp also was just terrible but atleast it gave invaders options to legitimately annihilate the host which I support entirely (there was essentially zero downscaling for weapons and spells for pvp so everyone was dying in 3 seconds).





--- written march 7th or 8th or whatever something in 2022 ---

game looks great, has a lot of content, lot of armor and weapons. players have a lot more opportunities for builds and character customization. voice acting is great, art design is great and the combat is more fun than ds3
but of course, you must be asking why is this a negative review. and if you have already played this game, you might have a clue why.

because every boss, most if not all especially in the late game, is broken. not broken as in glitchy, or buggy, just flat out untested and unfair to fight which I must say very carefully, (and sometimes actually bugged). most other titles in the series you learned the movesets in tandem with your frame rate, stuck it out and delivered damage during the recovery phase. 
2/3rds of the bosses/enemies in this game have no recovery phase, what does this mean you ask? it means you will be constantly running away from an enemy that never stops attacking. this, in combination with the mathematically perfect and infallible constant tracking every enemy does means that unless you timed your very small i-frame roll correctly to the dot, at the right location and distance depending on your luck regarding enemy AI, you will lose atleast 1/3rd if not all of your health in one swing/stunlock combo regardless of your armor. this wouldn't be so bad if 2/3rds of the enemies and bosses in this game did not lunge and leap at you like a demented and deranged wasp with heat seeking capabilities.
there are some bosses in this game that are quite definitively impossible for pure melee builds, especially on the strength side. this is not to say all are impossible, some you just have to get used to the ridiculous attack patterns, but you will know almost immediately which ones I am talking about. you cannot beat these specific bosses without either
A. overleveling your character to oblivion
B. summoning, or getting a friend
C. using overscaled sorceries and buffs to one shot the entire game while the boss is distracted

having all these insanely unfair scenarios wouldn't be so bad if it didn't force you into playing a single, mind-numbingly boring playstyle, being the wimpy summoner sidekick if you're not a caster. games like this are meant to be played solo I am pretty sure? I don't recall having to summon fifteen wolves or a copy of myself with 6x the health to beat a goblin man with a serrated pogostick in demon souls. but of course they knew what they were doing for when the game's population inevitably dies some 5 or so years from now when they added in the ash summons and nobody is available for coop.


I can say without the shadow of a doubt that a no hit run can never be achieved in this game
a theory is that miyazaki saw all those funny little streams of people beating the game with a broken straight sword, never getting hit or using throwables, and took a deep and personal offense.
this is not dark souls, this is "summoning your friends to gank the boss" souls and you wont get a more clear answer than that seeing as I have played and beaten demon souls to ds3 multiple times without ever having summoned someone to help since I first started ds1. 
I have never thought so negatively of a souls title since I first played a game like this in 2012 with prepare to die edition. this game gets incredibly boring and tedious to play in the later game, once you have fought one boss you have fought them all. the results of this is a rather unappealing and unrewarding back and forth of bosses that are essentially minutes away from eachother, all of which have near identical behaviors. even learning the bosses, and soloing most of them with zero backup feels meaningless when you realize you're just going to have to keep fighting the same boss over and over again with differently timed delayed attacks mixed with 2-4 frame hitscan animations and constant area-of-effect bombardments to artificially introduce a sense of difficulty. did I mention second phases/healthbars? dont you worry about that, there are few bosses without.

PVP, on another note, is also very lackluster. it's in marching formation with bloodborne, being that only people who have summoned atleast one other are susceptible to invasion. this results in boring back and forth attrition warfare if one or the others have not min-maxed their builds to being overpowered with one-two shot capabilities; this is also essentially impossible without bleed/frost due to the combination of weapon and level scaling.

I have beaten this game, and created another character up until the last 2 bosses to test just how bad colossal weapons are which I used in my first, and this is so far my least favorite souls game. it's entirely due to the enemies and bosses. the common theory is they spent too much time developing the world than they did fighting their own monsters. if you think where are you are isn't bad, just wait until the later portions of the game; tree sentinel and margit are cake walks by comparison. getting mad at these bosses assumes that one knows they have a chance at winning, most of the time I am just getting more bored and miserable. you don't learn anything from these bosses, you don't get any better at the game, you just memorize a singular attack pattern and get used to the RNG. I got no satisfaction from any of these bosses outside the first few when they were new to me, not realizing what would later come (or wouldn't come). there are a few bosses that are interesting visually such as radahn, but that's as much credit as I will give them. 

unlike most other souls games, I have no desire to continue past beating the main game and occasionally helping others via summon. I don't think I am going to return to this one for awhile as I have no desire to be a caster and do the same thing over and over again, or use another melee build because i've already done that multiple times in much more rewarding titles.

oh also, good luck if your computer isn't up to par with the insane hardware requirements

Fantastic use of open world design with familiar Soulsborne mechanics. I find Elden Ring to be more accessible than previous titles because of the open world design. If you ever hit a difficulty wall in one dungeon, you can easily go somewhere else and spend 12 hours or more concurring different challenges before ever needing to return to where you hit that wall. This is also a masterclass in utilizing minimal HUD and map markers while rewarding thorough exploration. I've likely played nearly 400hrs between PS4 and now PC versions, and I still find new stuff in every play through. If you've ever been interested in FromSoft's Souls games but were nervous about the difficulty curve, this one is a great starting point. That said, the game is still incredibly challenging, demanding patience and perseverance to overcome most/all major bosses. In my opinion, the open design, with little to no bottlenecks, actually allowed FromSoft to make bosses harder than ever before in terms of move set complexity, player animation reading, and overall aggression. So it's no walk in the park, but again, with patience and proper strategy all challenges are manageable. Highly recommend!!

Such a beautiful game. And fun too!

The world and lore they created is great. It literally calls you to explore and find new things and places.
But sadly exploration is just like in any other open world. You will explore land to its fullest for the first time to find interesting places, secrets and to get loot but in NG+ you will have no reason to do it all again and you will get bored of exploration.

Ambient music is much better than in previous DS games. Voice acting is good to.

NPCs that you find in the world are all interesting.
Almost all of them have a quest or is some way connected to some quest.
But this can also be double-edged sword some times. In order to complete quests successfully some NPCs quests demands certain steps that must be made in specific order or it can fail.

Horse is great in battle.
But not all battles are suited for fighting on horse back to. So be careful in what battle you use it.
When it comes to platforming with horse...well here its not so great at least on K+M.

Now for my main reasons why I gave this game negative review:

Boss fights: A lot of them feel unbalanced.
It also feels very cheap when its two bosses on one player. Well there's a lot of gank bosses this time but most of them are optional or allows you to summon spirits.
Bosses have disgustingly large HP pool especially towards the end of the game. This makes even simple boss fights to drag on (especially if you're fighting with large slow hitting weapons).
Seriously most annoying fights in this game are gank bosses especially if they are already hard to deal even if fighting separately. It is just cheap difficulty for the sake of difficulty.

When it comes to general combat with no horse well here it depends on your build and to know when to attack and when to be on defence. Some builds handle some situations better than others. It was always like this in every DS game.
But this time around I don't know. Some times fighting just seems off somehow.
The controls in this game just do not feel very responsive like they did in other DS games and personally I think enemies lack fair openings.
There are a lot more long spamming combos.
A lot enemies and some bosses can cancel their own recovery faster and so making slow weapons or guard counters useless and make some builds really struggle.
You literally get the feeling that they came from Sekiro fast combat style game.
Do not get me wrong I played Sekiro and all other DS games solo and love them.
Still somehow this one seems off with combat.

Co-op PvE is bad:

In DS1, 2 and 3 you could get summon signs or been summoned almost at any bonfire as long as you stick to community character lvl for Co-op.
But this time in ER forget it.
The only summoning signs or being summoned for Co-op that I have seen and experienced was at the boss fog gate or if you play with password (with a friend from your Steam friends list).
Random coop is almost gone in this game thanks to world being so large this time and no one wanna Co-op out of Legacy Dungeons in open world because it just take to damn long to get anywhere on foot with out a horse (you can't use horse when in Co-op or PvP).

PvP is bad:

Almost everyone goes to YouTube and finds same most OP condition build there is and use it. So don't be surprised if you see a lot of katana edge lord PvP.
PvP was always a shit show in DS series but it was at least entertaining. This time it's just boring and annoying since almost everyone uses same OP build.

Catacombs. Boring and forgettable dungeons.
Dungeon that you can find and explore but visually they all look the same just different dungeon layout and only good to visit once to get the loot and never again in NG+.

PC optimisation: it is bad. Stuttering, FPS drops and PC crashing.
This developers can make great games but they know crap about optimisation. You would think they have learned something by now after making so many DS style games but no.
Really a shame.

DLC: Hahaha they want 40 euros for DLC. Fuck no.

Elden Ring is a good game but after more than 100h in the game I must say that I like the size of the world, exploration and combat like in Dark Souls 3 and Sekiro more and those two games will stay my favorite Soul games.

in the realm of digital wonders, there exists a masterpiece crafted with the finesse of a seasoned bard and the ingenuity of a master smith. 'Tis none other than "Elden Ring," a game that doth transcend the bounds of mere entertainment and ascend to the lofty heights of artistic brilliance. Verily, in its beauty lies not only visual splendor but also the power to stir the soul and kindle the fires of inspiration.

Behold, as thou venture forth into the expanse of the Lands Between, a world wrought with myth and  majesty, where the very fabric of reality is woven with threads of wonder. Each vista, each crevice, is imbued with a sublime grandeur that doth enrapture the senses and transport the weary traveler to realms unknown. From verdant forests to desolate ruins, from towering citadels to forsaken tombs, every corner of this realm resonates with a haunting beauty that doth linger in the mind long after the controller is laid to rest.

But 'tis not merely the visual splendor that sets "Elden Ring" apart, for within its labyrinthine depths lies a narrative of profound depth and complexity. Through the tales of heroes and villains, gods and mortals, the game weaves a tapestry of myth and legend that speaks to the very essence of the human experience. 'Tis a story of struggle and triumph, of loss and redemption, that doth resonate with the deepest recesses of the soul.

Yet, perhaps the true beauty of "Elden Ring" lies not in its landscapes or its lore, but in the profound impact it hath upon the spirit of the player. For in the face of adversity, in the midst of countless defeats and setbacks, the game doth teach a valuable lesson: perseverance in the face of adversity. As the player battles through hordes of foes and overcomes seemingly insurmountable obstacles, they come to realize that no challenge is too great, no obstacle too daunting, if one but has the courage to press on.

And so, as the final credits roll and the journey comes to an end, the player is left not only with memories of a remarkable adventure but also with a newfound sense of purpose and determination. For "Elden Ring," in all its beauty and complexity, hath the power to inspire and uplift the spirit, to kindle the flames of ambition and drive one to strive for greatness in all endeavors.

In conclusion, 'tis clear that "Elden Ring" is more than just a game; it is a work of art that doth resonate with the soul and stir the heart. Through its breathtaking beauty, its captivating narrative, and its profound message of perseverance, it hath the power to uplift the spirit and inspire greatness in all who dare to embark upon its journey. Truly, 'tis a testament to the transformative power of art and a reminder of the boundless potential that lies within us all.

[b]Is this game just Open World Dark Souls?[/b]

Not really. While some aspects are still there, like the way your character controls, it all has been enhanced and made better!

+ Open world is not just empty like Ubisoft gameworlds, There is always something to find, like some material or enemy encampment and even small dungeons and more.

+ There are big and small dungeons, the small ones have some interesting items in them and sometimes may become your go to place for farming crafting materials (if you use a lot of certain crafted items like special arrow-types or bombs), you will get a unique item for defeating a boss in most cases. The big dungeons or overworld dungeons have the important bosses that are directly related to the lore and are not "just" sidenotes to the lore. Also openworld bosses are thing, have fun running into them! Also some may appear only at certain times!

+ You have a lot of weapon options which can be enhanced using ashes of war (weapon arts > special attacks) and can be made to scale with certain stats, not all weapon can be used for that > some are set.

- I am going to note here that there is a lack of ashes of war and standard weapons that scale in certain statcombination like: Intelligence & faith (if you have a deathmagic-sorcerer for example), faith or intelligence & arcane.

Arcane is a stat that increases buildup of status effects but you are fairly limited with how it scales, having a blood-infused weapon for example you scale with Dex and Arcane > your bleed-buildup will go up if you level Arcane.

But if you have a character that uses faith + arcane there is no buff to innate bleed-buildup on weapons when you make them scale with faith and you have high arcane. Which is fairly limiting and the same goes for my other examples. There is no way to make a weapon scale with intelligence and faith, except it is innate (infusion usually reduces other scaling by a lot...), but there is only one staff (not weapon) that has both. There are weapons which are infusable and have either faith or int scaling on them... Please add more or:

I hope they will add death ashes of war or if balancing that status effect for PvP is to hard (mild spoiler: [spoiler] it causes insta-death[/spoiler] ) they just can add magic+fire scaling and reduce physical-scaling for that weapon > certainly more interesting than what we have.

Int + Arc should be able to scale for frost-buildup, even on spells! Maybe add a staff that allows that? There is one that has bleed-buildup but it doesnt have that many spells, but at least it scales its bleed-buildup onto the blood-spells!

+ Talismans (basically rings from DS 1-3) can add a lot to your character

Useful if you keep your character at the meta level most people play at > its 150
> for example you can use talismans to add some stats like +5 dexterity and there are talismans like that for every damage stat (and also some others and Great Runes as well, dont sleep on those, they drop from main bosses).

Thing is the dex one has a variant that adds more positive effects on top of it... but there are none for the other types. I hope they will come with the DLC or I will be disappointed, it is quite the advantage to have an attack and a stat boost like that on an item.

+ Very little handholding, you just go and explore and find stuff yourself which is very rewarding gameplay > there also [b]is[/b] stuff to find, take note openworld-devs!

+ Difficulty: This game is not hard if you have a funtioning brain, there are spirit-summons which make the game easier and cartain playstyles allow for an even easier, although more boring, experience (Heavy shield or poison / rot and simply waiting).

Coop is readily available via a craftable consumable of which the components are just around everywhere. PvP is not forced upon you in Singleplayer and in Coop you can rely on Special Player Summons that come and help you get rid of the evil red invaders :P

A tiny negative here is that Coop stops you from using your horse and you can not fully stick together, you need to resummon people in new areas.

+ Oh yeah this game gives you a mount, which is very fun to use! You can even perform combat from horseback and you can build your character to get a bonus to attack while on horseback. Cant use shields thou > except for smacking a fool. The horse has its own healthbar and you might need to spend a flask of your own healing revive it immediatly in combat. Cant be used in coop/invasions.

+ Game runs great [u]without[/u] ray-tracing on. With it on it has framerate issues, at least for me. There are minor framelosses in some more vertical / busy areas and only for a short amount of time, otherwise the game runs superb.

+ Amazing story, find it for yourself. You can find lore anywhere even on the most mundane little items > check their descriptions!

This is my first ever FromSoftware "souls" game, and I am truly impressed with my first experience. 

I bought this game on sale and I feel like I've cheated the developers because of how much content this masterpiece has.
This game is HUGE - The Lands Between is a sprawling, interconnected expanse that beckon exploration at every turn. Thinking back on my play-through, there have been so many memorable, unique experiences that makes the game feel like an actual adventure. I found myself blown away numerous times at just how beautiful the diverse areas and landscapes can be. Because there are no quest markers, I found myself looking up online guides from time to time, but that's not necessarily a bad thing- I prefer it this way honestly.

The combat is nothing short of exhilarating (especially when I'm carrying a plethora of runes) - Elden Ring doesn't hold your hand; it challenges you to adapt and overcome, rewarding perseverance with a sense of accomplishment as you trek through The Lands Between slaying an incredibly creative cast of enemies.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is an essential experience for anyone seeking adventure, challenge, and a touch of extraordinary. It's straight-up a legendary masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of what we thought possible in the realm of action RPGs. Top-tier game.

This game is incredibly fun and I have enjoyed it for the most part even though it is very challenging.

[strike]HOWEVER

The PC port is absolutely terrible. It is obvious they put no consideration into making it user friendly for PC players.

Stuttering and frame time drops when fighting every boss, which apart from the visual annoyance makes fighting the boss harder (than it already is) as it throws off all your timings for dodges and attacks.

The movement controls are janky with mouse and keyboard, causing situations where you just cant face an enemy to hit them a lot of the time.

All the controls are still designed as if you have a controller and its limitations. You cant map items to certain keys, have a quick heal key or assign spells to keys. You have to use it as if you have a D pad which is ridiculous. Also the mapping options are incredibly limited and some things just cant be remapped.

All the menu controls are still in Xbox controller format and there is no list which controller button is mapped to what key and you cant custom map them.... its so bloody stupid. I still have no idea what half of them are and I've been playing for 16 hours! Their fix for this is to right click on the menu screen to bring up a drop down list that lets you choose what controller button you want to press.... Its incredibly annoying and frustrating. I dread having to go into my inventories or equipment screens cause its so badly designed.

Speaking of going into those screens, to access the menu to select aforementioned screens you have to press escape... there are no hotkeys for inventory, equipment, crafting etc etc. having to take your hand off they keyboard to press escape every time is also, you guessed it.... annoying.

Until they fix these obvious issues, I cant in good conscience give it a positive score. Odds are you will like this game, but the UI will drive you insane.[/strike]

They fixed a lot of the problems, I am happy to give it a positive review now.

Elden ring.. a combination of every dark souls game at 5x the scale. Spectacular bosses, amazing soundtrack and engaging combat as per usual.

With these types of games, simply take everything you thought you knew about difficulty and bosses and throw it out the window. Like how bosses in this game have a plethora of attacks and aren't artificially inflated in difficulty (obsurd damage sponge healthbars, and enemy damage multipliers, hoards of enemies). Enemies and Areas are carefully designed, in a way that makes the difficulty of souls games unique. Elden ring isn't gonna hold your hand and tell you where to go, how to dodge some attacks, that's for you to do. It's a big part of the game to simply explore and find new things, be it new structures, mythical creatures or legendary artifacts. The main goal isn't just depleting the bosses health bar to 0 through any means, It's that satisfying feeling of accomplishment of overcoming a challenge that you yourself learned how to overcome. Majority of the difficulty in these games come from the learning curve. A boss with attacks that seemed impossible avoid at first, is trivial the 2nd time around. There's always a trick to every boss, like the delaying dodges, the direction to dodge to avoid certain attacks and weaknesses. Some may say the gameplay is trail and error and tedious. That of which are simply incorrect, as you can learn from your past attempt what to do and what NOT to do in that boss, rather than mindlessly trying again till you survive by luck. But, if you're trying over and over again and are simply stuck (lacking damage, getting one shot because underleveled), just leave and come back. Thats the thing with elden ring being open world, you aren't locked to one area in order to progress. There's always multiple exploration paths to take leading to different items to find, enemies and bosses to defeat, ultimately become stronger. If you really are stuck or just impatient, you could use assists like npc/cooperator/spirit summons or really cheesy strats. (takes the fun out the game, makes it as easy as just watching a video of someone else play) but it may help you in getting hands-on a sense of the game and mechanics as a casual or someone new to the genre. Also consider not spoiling your playthrough like the boss phases (so it doesn't ruin the suprise factor) or bosses names, which its basically like saying this movie character dies in this movie because you kill the bosses eventually. So try to keep youtube/wiki searches to a minimum or at least spoiler free (ruins the first time experience IMO). In addition, you should also have some motivation to progress, like wanting to see the new areas, beat all the bosses or making new builds, which is a huge part of this game. Without motivation, its hard to persevere through difficult sections of the game without wanting to simply quit. Some say replay value is lacking, I disagree. Elden ring is one of the more replayable souls games, most of which coming from Online CO-OP and PVP through invasions or 1v1 colosseum duels. Overall Elden ring is a fun and rewarding experience, and enough content to be worth full price.

However, if you are not into action RPGs or dislike mythical/fantasy themed worlds and enemies then this game might simply not be of interest for you. One thing to note, this isn't a storytelling game. Don't expect a god of war level narrative with cinematic button sequence cutscenes, just stick to the EA/Rockstar/Sony productions story games.

Instant negative review. I refuse to support scummy business practices; as if they had to try one-upping Capcom for trying to silently place in Deck-breaking DRM into their titles.

I enjoyed my time with the base game, but this is an absolute bloody joke, and flatly gouging people's wallets because they're banking on hype and their IP.

With Shadow of the Erd Tree having just been announced, so were the eye-popping prices, on top of one gigantic F-you to all players who already own the game.

Already have Elden Ring and wanna get the DLC? That'll be $60AUD.

Never bought it? That's okay, here's [b]50% off the DLC if you buy both.[/b]

So why even charge $60 if the [i]actual[/i] price is $30, FromSoft? The developers clearly think whatever content's coming is worth far less than what they're asking of people who already own the game.

Only get the base game on sale. Don't ever pre-order fellas, not just this DLC, just as a general hard rule.

Definitely one of the best open-world games to date. They've taken the Dark Souls genre and merged it into an Elder Scrolls type of freedom. I haven't felt such adventure since The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

FromSoftware's latest magnum opus, Elden Ring, stands as a testament to the studio's unparalleled craftsmanship in the realm of action RPGs. Released amid immense anticipation, Elden Ring transcends expectations, offering a boundless world ripe for exploration, formidable challenges that test the limits of players' skills, and a depth of customization that empowers every adventurer.

At the heart of Elden Ring lies its unparalleled sense of exploration. From the moment you step foot into the Lands Between, the game beckons you with a sprawling, seamless open world that teems with secrets, mysteries, and untold dangers. Every corner of this vast expanse holds treasures to uncover, ruins to explore, and adversaries to overcome. The freedom afforded to players is staggering, as they chart their own course through dense forests, towering mountains, and forsaken dungeons. The dynamic day-night cycle and weather system add layers of immersion, transforming the landscape with each passing moment and presenting new challenges and discoveries at every turn. Whether on foot or astride a majestic steed, the journey through Elden Ring's world is nothing short of breathtaking.

Yet, with great exploration comes great peril, and Elden Ring delivers in spades on the front of challenge. From the lowliest grunt to the mightiest demigod, every foe poses a genuine threat, demanding precision, strategy, and adaptability. Combat is a visceral dance of life and death, requiring mastery of timing, positioning, and the intricate interplay of weapons, magic, and abilities. Each encounter is a test of mettle, rewarding those who dare to face adversity with triumph and growth. The sense of accomplishment that comes from vanquishing a daunting boss or conquering a treacherous dungeon is unparalleled, a testament to the game's finely tuned difficulty curve and impeccable design.

Moreover, Elden Ring's depth of customization is nothing short of astonishing. From the creation of your own bespoke character to the myriad weapons, spells, and abilities at your disposal, the game offers near-limitless possibilities for self-expression and playstyle refinement. Whether you prefer to wield a massive greatsword with devastating power or harness the arcane arts to bend reality to your will, the choice is yours to make. The intricate skill tree system allows for unprecedented depth and specialization, empowering players to tailor their character to suit their individual preferences and strengths. The sheer breadth of options ensures that no two adventurers' journeys are ever alike, fostering a sense of personal investment and ownership over the unfolding narrative.

In conclusion, Elden Ring stands as a crowning achievement in the annals of gaming history, a tour de force that exemplifies the very best of what the medium has to offer. With its awe-inspiring exploration, exhilarating challenge, and boundless customization, it sets a new standard for the genre and reaffirms FromSoftware's status as visionary trailblazers. For those brave enough to venture forth into the Lands Between, untold riches, glory, and adventure await. Dare you answer the call?
