[h1]Elden Ring Review[/h1]

[h3]Introduction[/h3]
I'll be completely honest with you - I've never been all that interested in FromSoftware's games or the "Souls-like" genre in general. With how infamously difficult these games supposedly were and with how obnoxious "git gud" attitude from the fanbase, I pretty much wrote it all off as just a niche genre that simply wasn't for me. So, you can imagine how skeptical I was when the first Elden Ring gameplay trailer dropped. Everything about it looked awesome, and with a highly regarded author as George R.R. Martin commisioned to pen this new world, I was intrigued but cautiously optimistic.
I bought the game just a few hours before it launched back in February of 2022 and was thorougly impressed with what I had played in those initial 20+ hours. Truth be told, my time with Elden Ring didn't last too long. At the time, I was focused on Dying Light 2, which had just released earlier that month, and with "gamer ADD" making it difficult to focus on Elden Ring, I didn't get too far in my playthrough. However, with the upcoming [i]Shadow of the Erdtree[/i] expansion finally set to release in June, I decided to finally get back into Elden Ring and continue on from my initial playthrough. I did start a second playthrough a while ago but have since returned to my first playthrough as of writing this review. So far, I have only just defeated Godrick, so most of this review will mainly just be based off of my experience up to that point. Here is my review of [i]Elden Ring[/i].

[h3]A Breathtaking Fantasy World[/h3]
Elden Ring has one of the most visually breathtaking open worlds ever made, full of vast landscapes and mindblowing discoveries to be made. So far, I've only just made it to Liurnia of the Lakes, but I feel like I've already seen so much. By far, the most mindblowing moment in my time playing Elden Ring has to be when I first entered Siofra River for the first time. Discovering this area on my own with no prior knowledge of its existence is what makes Elden Ring one of the most impressive open world games ever. I can only imagine what the rest of the game has hidden in its world, and I can't wait to find out. 
Elden Ring has no shortage of breathtaking landscapes and secrets to discover, but it also has a world filled with history and lore, all of which was penned by [i]Game of Thrones[/i] author George R.R. Martin. The worldbulding of Elden Ring is very enigmatic in nature, with a keen focus on letting the player piece it together themselves through conversations with NPC's, item descriptions, and environmental storytelling. As much as I love and appreciate the cinematic storytelling of games like [i]Red Dead Redemption 2[/i] and [i]The Last of Us[/i], I much prefer FromSoftware's approach to storytelling and worldbuilding by letting the player figure it out for themselves. 

[h3]Larger Than Life Characters[/h3]
Within this vast fantasy world lies a large assortment of creatures and characters that stand out from most works of fantasy. Whether it's a herd of goats that literally roll away from you when you get to close or a giant walking rock with a bell tower on top of it, Elden Ring has no shortage of bizzare and imaginitive creatures to come across. What makes these characters and the bosses you fight throughout the game so grand and spectacular is the sheer scale of these creatures. It's hard to describe, but the way Elden Ring makes your character feel small and insignificant when compared to the bigger, more intimidating-looking creatures is done in a way that I find very impressive. Elden Ring has the coolest character designs I've seen for any fantasy game and it's not even close. 

[h3]An Epic Fantasy Soundtrack[/h3]
Music has always been a core part of any fantasy game - Without it, these worlds, their lore and the overall experience would feel weightless and not as exciting. Elden Ring's score is just perfect and complements the world and it's scope. The score feels very reminiscent to [i]The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind[/i] with how mysterious and alien the world feels, especially when compared to most fantasy games. The different regions in Elden Ring are presented with a dark and dreary tone and atmosphere, complemented heavily by the ambient score that plays as you explore each region. FromSoftware have done a masterful job at creating an immersive fantasy world that feels just as distinct as it is epic. 

[h3]Engaging Combat & Gameplay Loop[/h3]
It's one thing to have an impressive-looking world and boss fights, with epic music to go with it, but if the gameplay isn't complementary, then it won't mean much in the long run. If there is one thing that FromSoftware are great at, it's the gameplay loop that's at the core of every Souls-like game. The gameplay loop of Elden Ring, as with seemingly the rest of FromSoftware's games, is a lot of fun and very satisfying. Unlike in many other games, you can't just simply cheese through each of the game's different boss fights. In order to effectively defeat the many bosses present within the game's world, you must level up your character and carefully choose which attributes you'd like to rank up and specialize in. Not only must you level up your character, but you'll have to account for the various abilities and moves each boss has and learn how to properly defeat them through trial and error. This is what makes boss fights in Elden Ring, as with the "Souls-like" genre as a whole, so special. Instead of heavily-scripted, movie-like boss fights, FromSoftware puts gameplay at the forefront of the experience while still maintaining that cinematic flair, just without the smoke and mirrors. 

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
I still have a long journey ahead of me in Elden Ring and I'm sure there's a lot more to say that I haven't already said in this review, but I'm confident that this game will remain just as phenomenal as it currently is in my playthrough. Like I said, I used to avoid these types of games for their harsh difficulty, but after playing this game, I finally get it. While Elden Ring and the "Souls-like" genre may appeal mostly to a certain type of player, I still strongly recommend Elden Ring to anyone looking for a new game and world to get lost in.

Easily the most polished and well rounded RPG I have ever played. If you think its too difficult, then you haven't explored enough. Simply move onto a different area and come back later. Its beautifully rendered with a variety of different nature, geographic, and environments. Bosses and hostile NPCs are well balanced for the most part... requiring different techniques and ashes to defeat them. The fextralife wiki is definitely a plus, but not required. Some of the optional quest lines are a bit obscure if you want 100%. Go in blind and you'll be fine if you just explore a ton. Expect 100hrs for a playthrough at minimum.
Definitely worth putting way too many hours into

Art : 11/10 I think its art style and graphics make it the best looking game out there.
Difficulty: Not as hard as people say, sure you'll die but you'll never be stuck on a boss forever and beating it just adds to the enjoyment.
Variety: The amount of weapons, armor pieces, talismans, and potions in this game is absurd in a good way. You could play it 50 times over and still have a new build. On top of that, the weapons and armor in this game are so well designed artistically and fun to use as well.
Story: The story isn't quite Red Dead or Last of Us in terms of pulling at heart string or character development but the world that is constructed is so well done especially if you can piece it up all on your own.

Once the initial hype phase passed and I look back on this game, it isn't perfect that's true, it has its flaws but I still think it's one of the best open world games I've ever played.
It struggles with recycled content and feeling dragged out towards the end, like most open world games tend to do, but despite that I still didn't want it to end. The world they've built and the some of the bosses you come across were challenging enough to be memorable, while others felt so out of place and terribly balanced/tedious (the numerous duo fights were shockingly bad considering the same devs made the O&S fight in Ds1).
It would be unfair comparing it directly to DS3 considering the pacing will always be worse with open world games so I'll leave it at that.

Overall I can't say it beat bloodborne for the best FS game in my eyes, it's a tie with DS3 for second as the music and boss design in that game is outstanding; great effort for their first open world game and I hope it has an effect on future open world games just as BOTW did but a part of me hopes fromsoftware goes back to their beautifully paced, tightly knit style of gameplay.

Elden Ring: Where death is your philosophy and Torrent is your emotionally unstable Uber driver.
 
This game is:

â€¢ Dark Souls on steroids with a vast open world where everything wants to murder you.
â€¢ Horse combat that's: 50% epic, 50% accidentally jumping off cliffs because "Torrent, no!".
â€¢ Bosses that: Range from majestic demigods to giant crabs with PTSD. Prepare to die a lot.

But hey, at least:

â€¢ You can dress like a walking pot. Fashion Souls is alive and well, even if your character isn't.
â€¢ You can summon help... who promptly gets mauled by a dog the size of a house.
â€¢ You can learn magic... and accidentally nuke yourself in the face.
â€¢ You can explore a vast, gorgeous world... filled with things that want to end your existence.

Recommended if you:

â€¢ Enjoy pain ðŸ‘
â€¢ Have a masochistic streak higher than the Erdtree.
â€¢ Enjoy scenic views... of your own demise.
â€¢ Want someone to finally hug you (I mean bear, not that blessing girl).

It might not be for you if you:

â€¢ Have a weak heart (or controller).
â€¢ Can't handle women with more than 2 arms.
â€¢ Don't want to develop an emotional connection with your kitchenware and start calling it "Alexander".
â€¢ Value your sanity (or at least your furniture).

Overall:

Holy Miquella, this game is gorgeous! Elden Ring is a masterpiece of pain, beauty, and absurdity with a difficulty curve so steep, you'll need a Sherpa. Elden Ring is like getting punched in the face by a beautiful angel while riding a runaway horse. It hurts, but you can't look away because you love it.

P.S. Please send help. I'm stuck in a swamp surrounded by crabs and I think Torrent is plotting against me.

P.P.S. 11/10 would recommend, also would need therapy after.

nhi

I really hate that Fromsoft makes open worlds now.

Instead of a tightly designed game like Dark Souls 1 and 3, where every squared cm has meticulously designed, where you have a well thought out difficulty curve and you can get in a completely different feeling area in minutes, you're wandering around in a mostly empty sea of grass with a lot of procedural generation going on.

The only time I had fun was when I was in a castle which actually felt like a well thought out experience.

Then I ran into the first boss where I died 5 times without making a dent in his health bar. When that happened in Dark Souls, I would explore a little while leveling up or it would have been obvious it was time to beat it, but not here. Also, where would I explore? The world is so overwhelmingly big and not very dense that I have no idea where I would go. It's not like in firelink shrine where you have a few destict paths to choose from.

Maybe I just had to keep going? Maybe I missed something? (I can't summon spirits yet). Maybe I was underleveled? I don't know.

If only they didn't obsess with making an as big as possible game, combined the sameish dungeons that I know are still coming and instead put all the cool stuff together, it would have been such an amazing game.

Dear Esteemed Council Members,

I hope this message finds you well. As an avid enthusiast of gaming and a passionate member of the gaming community, I am writing to express my utmost anticipation and eagerness for the release of the highly anticipated game. It is with great enthusiasm and anticipation that I humbly implore the esteemed council to consider expediting the release of this monumental creation.

Having closely followed the development updates and glimpses provided by the development team, it is evident that the game is a labor of love, meticulously crafted with attention to detail and a commitment to excellence. The dedication and hard work poured into every aspect of its creation are truly commendable, and it is without a doubt that the gaming community eagerly awaits the opportunity to immerse themselves in the rich, captivating world that has been meticulously designed for our enjoyment.

The trailers and teasers released thus far have only served to whet our appetites and ignite our imaginations, leaving us yearning for more. The breathtaking visuals, compelling narrative, and innovative gameplay mechanics showcased in these previews have already captured the hearts and minds of gamers worldwide, generating a palpable sense of excitement and anticipation that continues to grow with each passing day.

As someone who understands and appreciates the complexities involved in game development, I am cognizant of the challenges and obstacles that may arise during the final stages of production. However, I firmly believe that the time has come to unleash this masterpiece upon the world, allowing gamers everywhere to experience the sheer joy and wonder that awaits them within its virtual realms.

The gaming community is a vibrant and passionate community, eager to embrace new experiences and immerse themselves in the boundless possibilities offered by interactive entertainment. By releasing the game at the earliest opportunity, the council would not only fulfill the desires of countless gamers eagerly awaiting its arrival but also contribute to the enrichment and advancement of the gaming industry as a whole.

In conclusion, I respectfully urge the esteemed council to heed the fervent pleas of the gaming community and grant the release of the game at the earliest feasible date. The anticipation and excitement surrounding its impending release are palpable, and I have no doubt that its arrival will be met with widespread acclaim and celebration.

Thank you for considering my humble request, and may the future of gaming be as bright and promising as the world that awaits us within this extraordinary creation.

Yours sincerely,

The game itself is good, real good, it really changes up how you play an open world game. You actually have to think when exploring and doing quests instead of just having a marker showing you where every single quest objective or npc is. 

The pc port however is absolute shit, stuttering and frame skips constantly which can get you killed especially during boss fights. Summoning in players just flat out doesn't work half the time when it does they'll just get randomly disconnected. Invading is a gamble as half the time hits that register to you don't to them. 

Don't get it yet wait for a patches and driver updates to make it half playable for most people.

Game has been patched and is way more stable and has been for a long time easy recommend and buy now

This game is quite simply a masterpiece.

If, like me, this is the first time you've played this type of game, at first you'll be totally destroyed by everything.

But the more you persevere, the stronger and more confident you'll become, you'll probably easily kill a boss or two and then a random mob in a new area will kill you like you're nothing, and to be fair you are nothing, you're not a hero, you're not a champion, you're just a lost soul in a lost world trying to achieve what no one has achieved and one day if you're strong and patient enough you'll probably change this lost world.

Stay strong, tarnished, this world has a lot to offer, but also a lot to take.

You'll never be the same after playing this game, this masterpiece.

The Absolute Best game in the entire Souls series...
Elden Ring is a open world Souls-like that has everything that was great about Dark Souls but makes it even better... Jumping/Crouching, Horse riding, Spirit Ashes, a new customizable flask, and much more...
There are hundreds of different builds to make for your character and gives the game a LOT of replayability.
Very Co-op friendly and so much fun to play...

The gameâ€™s vastness, like an uncharted continent, beckoned me to explore every nook and cranny. Each sunrise revealed new secrets, and every moonrise whispered ancient tales.

The combat, reminiscent of FromSoftwareâ€™s signature style, demanded precision and resilience. No gentle tutorials hereâ€”just raw, unyielding challenges. Yet, with each fallen foe, I felt a surge of accomplishment. The landscapesâ€”towering cliffs, desolate ruins, and mystical forestsâ€”were not mere backdrops but characters in their own right. Elden Ringâ€™s sunsets painted the sky with hues Iâ€™d never seen before, as if the gods themselves dipped their brushes in cosmic pigments.

And the lore! Oh, the lore. It wove a tapestry of forgotten kingdoms, shattered alliances, and cryptic prophecies. I pored over ancient tablets, deciphering runes, piecing together the tragic saga of the Elden Ring. NPCs, their voices etched with sorrow or madness, shared tales of lost kings, cursed knights, and forbidden magic. I became a scholar, a detective, unraveling the threads that bound this fractured world.

The hours I poured into Elden Ringâ€”like coins tossed into a wishing wellâ€”yielded dividends of wonder, frustration, and awe. The thrill of unearthing a hidden shrine, the terror of facing a colossal boss, the quiet solace of gazing at a star-studded skyâ€”all etched into my gaming soul. I emerged from this epic odyssey with battle scars and triumphs, a bardâ€™s song waiting to be sung.

So, yes, it was worth it. Worth every bleary-eyed night, every adrenaline-fueled duel, every whispered prayer for a bonfire. Elden Ring isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s a pilgrimageâ€”a journey that reshapes you, leaving imprints on your psyche like runes etched in stone. ðŸŒŸðŸ—¡ï¸ðŸŒ„

This game is truly a flawed masterpiece, like many of FromSoft's other titles. It does so much incredibly right. The environments are breathtaking. The combat is fluid. The music hits hard as always. The open world does not hold your hand, but rewards with more game. The only two downsides are major, however. The late game spike in difficulty and damage scaling is immense and can often be overbearing, making the player doubt the idea of 'tough, but fair' as often it is indeed pretty bullshit. The other flaw would be that the world is too big, filled with many inserted copy bosses and lengthy travels with not much happening, as the player rides from one destination to the next, especially after a first playthrough.

Overall, this game is a 10/10 out of pure respect, but a very shaky one. Would not recommend as a first Souls-like.

I have played every single FromSoftware Game to this day, and one thing which remains a constant, is that every single minute detail in this game has a deeper meaning, whether it be small fragments you pick up off of the floor, or walking by a destroyed town on your travels, everything has a reason, a place, and everything is connected.

if you are looking for a game that is linear, holds your hand through every step and doesn't let you stray too far off of the beaten path, this game is not for you.
You can spend Hours going off of the beaten path and exploring the 4 corners of the land between and you will not be short of content. Even the darkest of corners have something to be explored and the sombre atmosphere and lonely expanse adds to effect and engages players to think and connect the dots, it really makes you think 'Why am i here?' 'What is my purpose?' and 'How did this happen?'

After completing the game multiple times, i do have to say, this is by far, my favourite game in recent years, and really makes you wonder.. Whats next?

Overall a great game, but didn't like it quite as much as other Fromsoft titles. Mainly because of the open world. Exploring massive areas was annoying and also threw the game out of balance - I visited places in the wrong order (which I didn't know at the time) and ended up being overleveled for half the time which sucked the difficulty and fun out of the game. 

Also this game shows light/mid/heavy equip load instead of showing the percentage. Good for new players but overall makes it tedious to calculate what equipment you should use. No reason why it can't show both.
This game did a slightly better job at providing info about game mechanics than previous games but somehow still forgot to mention how dual weilding works. It's a very crucial core mechanic in this game that many people who bitch that the game is too hard don't know about.

And then there's the 2 ever-prevalent problems that exist in almost all fromsoft games: 
1. A weapon upgrade system that forces you to use starting weapons the whole game and makes trying out anything new extremely tedious
2. Camera Reset being on the same key as Target Lock and it can't be disabled. Extremely annoying, no one ever needs this feature, all it does is disorient you when you fail to target lock. Can be fixed super easily but somehow still doesn't think this is a problem after ~15 years.

But it also did a bunch of stuff better than previous games: 
- Consistent animations between one- and two-handed attacks. Dark Souls had some weapons that had much worse 2H attack anims than 1H anims which made no sense. Glad they fixed it.
- Guard counters is a very nice addition for melee users.
- No more superlong boss runbacks
- Actually difficult, challenging lategame bosses instead of punching bags

I have a combined total of approximately 800 hours on this game across all of my platforms, maybe more. I'm not normally the kind of guy to say that this or that game is a must-play, but I think anybody out there who appreciates art direction, music composition, or just good general game design needs to give this a shot. Elden Ring was the very first FromSoftware game that I played to completion, mainly due to how free you were to explore from the get-go. If they had forced me to "git gud" in order to beat a boss I was stuck on like Dark Souls, I likely wouldn't have kept playing. But the fact that you can leave a hard boss, explore for 20 hours, then come back far stronger and kick their ass is what I live for, and is ultimately what drove me to complete this game for the first time. I soon became so powerful that I managed to beat every boss from Rennala onward without dying a single time, excluding Malenia of course. A lot of players would deem the playstyle of using every tool at your disposal to obliterate everything in the game boring and scummy, but that exact style was probably the most fun I've ever had in a video game. This game allows people with crafty minds to think outside of the box in order to get past obstacles. Sure, you can brute force that huge group of enemies and maybe die a couple of times by getting stunlocked, or you can use ranged weapons to lure them out one by one, or use a bewitching branch to force a powerful enemy to attack the horde, or clump them all together and disintegrate them with a couple powerful spells/weapon arts. These kinds of strategies apply for some bosses, too! If anything in this game is giving you trouble, there's ALWAYS a way around it. Unlike Dark Souls, you don't have to spend 30 minutes to a couple hours "gitting gud" by memorizing a boss's repertoire of attacks just to get by. It's helpful, sure, but not the required way to progress. I'm not dissing on Dark Souls' progression system or anything, because it certainly has its many merits as well, but the unbridled freedom of Elden Ring is what really keeps me playing.

With all of that said, I can't recommend this game enough, and with the upcoming DLC in June, this 10/10 game is about to get a whole lot better.
Amazing game, highly recommended

Growing up in the 80s I have vivid memories of games with challenges that simply required you to acquire the skill to get around or you could not progress in the game. We learned from that over the years and modern games almost always have a way around each challenge that anyone can complete with a simple google lookup. Elden ring has combined these two styles by both providing overwhelming challenges that keep me coming back because they feel like I can do it with one more try while also allowing me to have fun in the game somewhere else if the challenge is too much on any given day. Its difficult combat, amazing visuals, stellar soundtrack, and endless build variety make for hundreds of hours of enjoyable game play and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys realtime combat and open world games.

Fantastic exploration, great combat fundamentals, and cool enemy designs. Problem is, a lot of enemies (and most bosses) are difficult in unfair ways. Even worse, there are no difficulty options in-game. Needs mods to fix that and make most enemies fun.

Recommended changes:

*Change Crimson Amber Medallions to add the rally effect from Malenia's great rune
*Edit the dodge animations to increase the number of iFrames
*Change Flask of Crimson Tears to restore 40% HP (+ 1% per upgrade) + 100hp (+10hp per upgrade)

Recommended mods:

*Extended FOV
*Pause the Game
*FPS unlock
*Remove the intro

The fallen leaves tell a story.
The great Elden Ring was shattered.
In our home, across the fog, the Lands Between.
Now, Queen Marika the Eternal is nowhere to be found,
and in the Night of the Black Knives, Godwyn the Golden was the first to perish.
Soon, Marika's offspring, demigods all, claimed the shards of the Elden Ring.
The mad taint of their newfound strength triggered the Shattering.
A war from which no lord arose.
A war leading to abandonment by the Greater Will.
Arise now, ye Tarnished.
Ye dead, who yet live.
The call of long-lost grace speaks to us all.
Hoarah Loux, chieftan of the badlands.
The ever-brilliant Goldmask.
Fia, the Deathbed Companion.
The loathsome Dung Eater.
And Sir Gideon Ofnir, the All-knowing.
And one other. Whom grace would again bless.
A Tarnished of no renown.
Cross the fog, to the Lands Between.
To stand before the Elden Ring.
And become the Elden Lord.

2 years later and I had to play through again, but this time on PC. The Lands Between is still as amazing as I remembered. This game is a must play, but surely you know that by now. If you're reading through reviews trying to decide if you want to purchase the game, this is your sign to just do it. Praise the sun !!

Elden Ring is a nightmare from which you cannot wake up â€“ because the beauty and excitement in it is so addictive: realism, immersive experience, mystery of characters and landscapes, realism in physics, the weight weapon and armour, combat strategy, etc. 

Yet it will test your ability to contain the instinctual urge to break free from the invisible walls of the nightmare. Manifesting as real risk for the physical objects around you while playing... lol

If killing a dragon was ever a display of valor, here you will certainly own it.

There are a few design choices that I don't fully understand but accept. Punishment to the player (specially new players) feels too harsh. Also why there are no real friends (besides your goat horse) or friendly cities? Anyways. This game was meant to be dark place. 

Are you brave enough to discover the wonders within the nightmare?

Not a perfect game, but an artistic masterpiece and landmark achievement for open world games. Despite the map being technically smaller than games like BG3, GTA5, Skyrim, etc, this game manages to pack so much density of detail into each area that you have no choice but to feel so, unbelievably *small.* The boss designs are also probably the best of Fromsoftware's entire career.                                                                                                                                                        
                                                                                                                                                                                                  
The only issues I have with Elden Ring are as follows: the bullshit platforming that adds nothing (save for unnecessary frustration with a skill that should be irrelevant to this genre),  some strange balancing decisions both for boss tunings and spell/weapon scalings, lack of reason to fight after previously exploring an area, and the re-use of multiple bosses & enemies occasionally. The frame drops on the PC port don't help either.

Overall, however; the pros absolutely outweigh the cons of this game. I've sank nearly 150 hours into Elden Ring since I purchased it, and have not even beaten the game yet. This game truly feels like an experience that you should not deprive yourself of, despite some lingering gameplay and technical issues. It brings so much passion and creativity back into the fantasy/RPG genre as a whole, and for that I cannot thank it enough.

Game is great. I'm only putting the negative review because it crashes a lot. In the 4 hours I've been playing, it's crashed about 3 times, annoying me enough to write this. Other than that, the game is awesome, just poorly optimized for pc I'd wager (no surprise there given FromSoftware's history with pc ports).

Edit: switched to recommended because they've fixed the crashes apparently. Music is 10/10. Voice acting is one of the best I've ever heard in a FromSoft title. Combat is fluid and, to some extent, intuitive; same thing with Torrent's mechanics (the horse). Many easter eggs and content to look for. I've played over 20 hours and I haven't even beaten the 1st story boss because I've dedicated myself to exploring first. Dungeons are awesome and bring you back to that classic Soulsborne feel aka no horseback fighting or fast travel at any time. Overall, a solid 10/10 for me for many reasons, even new players have found themselves hooked on this whilst older players of the series, like myself, are delighted to get more from FromSoftware's games.

This game is incredible. But it's not perfect. If you want the TLDR, it's an 8.5 outta 10.

Elden Ring feels like a culmination of effort that FromSoft has been working towards for YEARS. Every previous iteration of the souls games introduced ideas, concepts, and mechanics that are nearly all here, in some way shape or form. Note that I say NEARLY all. 

The first time I played through Elden Ring, it made me fall in love with video games all over again. I was suddenly 8 years old, with no concept of the limitations games have and everything seemed possible. I could go ANYWHERE and find something interesting, be it a unique item, a cool boss, a memorable NPC, or just a gorgeous view (ahead). I spent hours poring over every bit of terrain, figuring out little puzzles, keeping track of what key items I had that I hadn't used yet. Hell, I got out Notepad and made a .txt document of "to-do's" for this game just to make sure I didn't miss anything. It was AWESOME.

However, after getting about 3/4ths of the way through some of the cracks started to show. There were repeat bosses. A LOT of repeat bosses. This was something of a disappointment - I was coming hot off of playing through Dark Souls 2 and 3, games with pretty excellent boss variety (especially 3). This partial gripe leads into my biggest gripe: Elden Ring duo bosses are hot garbage. This is because all of the duo bosses are just bosses you would normally fight solo, except they've been placed together in the same arena without much care given to their combat styles or AI patterns. Looking at previous duo bosses like Demon in Pain and Demon from Below in DS3, O&S in DS1, or even Throne Watcher and Throne Defender in DS2, these bosses were all carefully crafted with each half of the duo in mind. This is not the case in Elden Ring, as mentioned above.

So I put aside my issues with the lack of unique bosses and lack of good duo bosses, and finish the game, where I fly off in a magic bathtub with my space princess waifu for a moon vacation. Great! I decide to start NG+, which is where my second issue arises...Elden Ring in NG+ is less of a game and more of a chore.

Due to just how vast Elden Ring is, it's a damn long walk to get from Limgrave (the starting area) to becoming Elden Lord (the final cutscene). This long walk becomes way less fun when you already know whats coming, and when you know what areas aren't necessary to travel to. I believe this severely harms the game's replay value. Let's take a look at one of from's previous entry's and my personal favorite of the trilogy, Dark Souls 3. Dark Souls 3 is very linear which some may criticize, but I believe it serves it well. I love playing through Dark Souls 3 because the level designs are fun, the bosses are really cool and fun to fight, and at any given point I can gauge how far into the game I am based on what area I'm in or what boss I've just defeated. Now, because Elden Ring is an open world game, FromSoft had to take into account players missing out on certain areas (and they trusted themselves enough to make a world worth exploring, without waypoint markers clogging up the map - but I digress). And exploring this open world is amazing!...the first time around. Playing through the game a second time, there's much less incentive to explore because you learned where all the important/good/useful items are, and grabbing anything superfluous would waste time, so you may skip over huge chunks of the map. This sucks because Elden Ring is BEGGING to be explored, and is fun to explore! But only the first time.

Also how many runes (currency) you get from killing enemies is completely borked. I wish it was more like DS2 where you get showered with currency and can level a ton early game but eventually it plateaus later, rather than always only being able to get enough runes to level only once or twice after some bosses.

In summation: Elden Ring is the greatest video game experience you will ever have...but only the first time you play through it. It's flawed, and dropped the ball in some places where previous entries succeeded, but it's a glorious adventure. Go play it.

It's Elden Ring

I have been a fan of FromSoftware games since I first played Bloodborne in 2015. That led me to the original Dark Souls and eventually Sekiro. I was super excited about the release of this game, and I made sure to have it downloaded and ready to play at release. This is probably my favorite FromSoft game followed by Bloodborne/Sekiro simply due to its massive open world, and the ability to tackle different quests/story arcs in varying order; giving it the feel of a real-life world. The cinematics are beautiful and captivating. The music is amazing and fits given locations, bosses, and times of the day. Enemies and characters are all beautifully crafted and added to different parts of the world appropriate for their lore/backstories, and bosses feel well-tuned and are enjoyable to fight. The more I play Elden Ring, the more I learn about the lore and it blows my mind just how interconnected and well-designed the whole game is.

A brutally honest review.

Elden Ring is FromSoft's best game but it's also their worst game, if that makes any sense.  There is HOURS of fun to be had here and you'll without a doubt get your money's worth.  But I did notice a few cracks in it's facade.  A plethora of annoying bosses with ridiculous health bars.  A bizarre and completely disorienting sense of direction. Map exploration that is extremely tedious as the map is so gargantuan it will take up most of your play session.  Critique of this game is so abundant online it's just sad.  I mean, this was supposed to be The Game!  All this I believe has shattered Elden Ring's Great Oracular Bubble and caused it to fall from the heavens, and directly into the clearance bin of your local electronics store.

The game starts off strong with breathtaking visuals, challenge dungeons, open-world exploration, multiplayer co-op and pvp matches- FANTASTIC I love it.  The NPC's have great voice acting and the lore is rich, you know, dry dialogue- the likes of which you've come to expect from these kinds of games.  If you love sleep-inducing dialogue this is your game!  No but seriously, I think Elden RIng's strongest suit is the wide variety of animals and enemy-types in the game.  There's bats, wolves, bears, lions, knights, dragons, skeletons, sorcerers, apparitions, etc.  There's literally something taken from all realms of fantasy here.  FromSoft really went all-out on making sure every enemy encounter was unforgettable.  I commend them on that!  I love fighting the bears they're my personal favorite!  But, lets talk about some of the negative aspects of this game now.

First, Elden Ring is very non-linear.  In order to advance the storyline you'll need to backtrack to areas you already were, scavenge for items that aren't the easiest to find, and exhaust so much NPC dialogue.  Omg, who wants to do that?  Just let me open the damn gate and move to the next area why do I have to go look for shit?  You literally need to have YouTube open on a 2nd monitor so you can look up how to find the next area, because you will NOT figure it out on your own!  The game also gets significantly boring once you reach the "Liurnia Of The Lakes" area.  For reals dude, that's where the game completely lost me as a patron.  I'm not a fan of having to explore vast open swamp land, or vast open snow land, or vast open autumn land.  I would have preferred a linear approach.  Keep it simple next time.

THERE'S CLIFFS EVERYWHERE.  Cliffs, rocks, canyons, pitfalls.  The same uneven terrain over and over again with different colored grass.  Was this game made by AI?

The boss fights can be really exhausting.  Seriously, some of these dudes are straight up damage sponges and it becomes a chore really quick.  Commander O'Neill is a perfect example.  It takes a million hits to bring his fatass down, meanwhile he's also summoning apparitions that shoot arrows at you.  NO, I refuse to apply some stupid sorcery or wear some gay ring just to make it easier- I'm a Parry main.  I PARRY.  That's how I fight.  The same goes for sorcery, I'm not going to fight bosses with sorcery that's for noobs!  But in Elden Ring the parry mechanic has been nerfed into oblivion that it's just pointless to use sometimes.  So you either have to go level up first, or do a co-op mission to complete difficult bosses.  Another point I'd like to bring up is the amount of bosses in the game.  There's so many!  It's like they went with quantity over quality.  I would rather they give us fewer bosses that were designed really well, than a bunch of the same dudes who fight just like the last guy.  And to be fair the parry DOES work on a lot of foes, both big and small.  It's not broken or anything, I just wish the parry did more damage than it does.

So in conclusion: Would I recommend Elden Ring?  No.  The fun level drops significantly once you get to Radahn.  At this point you realize Elden Ring is a bait and switch.  Unless you actually enjoy memorizing 10 different attack patterns per boss.  A vast open world of nothingness that makes you feel lonelier than Starfield.  And never getting summoned to re-do your favorite boss fights.  I guess it's because nobody really plays this shit anymore.  Shame.  At least I got it on clearance.

Elden Ring is a journey of struggles and triumph, with a lowly Tarnished rising against all odds to claim their seat as the Elden Lord. From the gates of Limgrave, the world looks vibrant and welcoming, but soon it comes to reality how weak you are; any enemy can crush you, and it's always an uphill battle with the world against you, and once you grow powerful enough to conquer Limgrave, The next challenge is right around the corner waiting to throw you right back down the hole you clawed your way out of. The few who aren't against you aren't your allies; no one is your ally. Everyone who appears friendly is merely trying to use you for their own gain, yet using them is what you do as well, for a crown cannot rest upon two brows and the seat of Elden lord must be claimed by you alone. Every victory and every boss slain makes you feel like you are on top of the world, and then a new challenge presents itself to remind you of how weak you once were. You grow from a lowly tarnished, who is slain by all to the Elden lord who finally stands on top of the world and stands above all.

Definitely the game of the year for 2022, one of the best games of all time to be honest
i fuond the elder ring

The more I played it, the more I hated it. This game has reverse replay value or something. I would refund my hours wasted on this game, if I could. 
Open world just makes the game an incredibly tedious chore on repeat playthroughs, and I would rather play any other souls game. The more familiar I have become with the bosses, the more irritating and unfair a lot of them feel, even if I can defeat nearly all of them without a single death. 
A lot of level and dungeon design is just stupid "gotcha!" design, which grows more and more into an irritating slog with time. Many areas are just not fun at all, and I question how they made it out of development. 
Playing for so long, and trying so many builds, only highlighted how broken the game balance is. You can either have a complete breeze of a time cheesing everything with OP options, or suffer fighting honestly against extremely cheap enemies and bosses. 
I don't know, maybe games that are based around overcoming hardship for the sake of it, just aren't my bag anymore. The only point in dealing with all the tedious design, is to get that little victory nut, which is a really shallow thing to build an entire game around. 
Ultimately, the first journey and all its discovery was a really fun experience, but that was clearly the only experience the game had in mind.
Elden ring is a game carried by FOMO, journalist favoritism, and a collective covenant of its fans to ignore any faults, or attack anyone who points them out.
It's alright

To get it out of the way, if you played and liked the other fromsoft games, then you'll probably enjoy this one.

Art style is one thing I can say that is positive across the board; it looks great, it's detailed and generally clear enough to see what's going on in a fight. There are points where there was clearly intent to make a vista intentionally pleasing.

What really pushed me to not recommend however is the combat and storytelling.

Fighting can rapidly transition toward frustrating due to the 'stickiness' in how enemies move when attacking and how movement during the wind up and swing is treated. The game seems to permit movement of enemy movement and collision from during the windup and attack animations. It seems that the game does an initial lock-on to player location at the start of the wind-up of the attack, and then a second lock on at some point of the attack animation, causing such interesting cases as watching a dive attack suddenly do a U-turn and jump back into your face because you dodged behind an enemy, or watching a model slide forward an extra few feet to ensure an attack lands. Enemies in a chain of attacks will inexplicably have a model rotation that violates the apparent momentum of their swings. This, from my experience, leads to a condition where evasion is more closely tied with making the dodge during the attack swing to use the I-frames and where evading out of enemy reach during the wind up is punished by how the models move. I feel, at times when the combat feels particularly clunky, like a man on crutches trying to waltz with an ice skater. Does it feel fair? Sure, about 70% of the time, but that last 30% really ruins it for me.

I ended up just being incredibly disappointed by the storytelling, which is made even worse by the fact that the actual story behind it is great. Telling large chunks of story, backstory and location history through the flavor text on items, the very rare NPC interaction and the cryptic mutterings and insinuations is actually godawful. There's no ingame codex to collate the massive amount of information on individual items, noted by NPCs, or plot beats we need to get refreshed on between dungeons, no tattered pages on history or politics that we can collect in the land, just assorted cryptic mutterings from NPCs that either get killed off too soon to give us any impactful dialogue or speak in cryptic circles. The rule is to show not tell, but somebody forgot to tell fromsoft that showing is not the same as making vague implications. Its like being read Lord of the rings by a trio of five year olds stuffing their faces with marshmallows.

Update: 6.5/10, ARPG / Sandbox RPG

TLDR: Lacking in the RPG department and lacks direction. Combat and its difficulty are good (in single-player).

A lack of direction in a sandbox is usually compensated for with immersive RPG elements - the game has to drive you somehow. Whether that means making it story-driven or relying on other design elements.

Hype made the game out to be something it isn't, so I came into Elden Ring expecting a lot more from this "hardcore open world RPG" with "one of the best stories in a game ever," "honestly a masterpiece." 

I remember being so excited to play after making my character, only to be incredibly disappointed there was no way to RP them. No way to interact with the world, no way to show their personality; nothing. I didn't feel integrated into the world at all.

So I aim to set expectations straight, hopefully saving you some frustration. As among other things, it can feel isolating being, apparently, one of the only people who didn't have fun playing this game.

- Don't buy for multiplayer (unless you want to setup mods)
- Be careful if you come from an RPG/CRPG background
- Has a (potentially [i]long[/i]) time till "click" moment. (So I am told anyway, I haven't actually reached that point myself. FromSoft games seem to be designed so the pain of early game makes the end feel more meaningful; you appreciate the struggle. Or maybe that's abuse apologist nonsense. All will be revealed in time, I suppose. Regardless, I feel this transition period is getting into wasting my time territory.)

And a seemingly small gripe I have is the [i]lack of a journal[/i]. How am I supposed to remember the dialog?! This makes the game unplayable for me, but luckily there is a mod for that (ugh). 

FromSoftware clearly wanted to expand their player base (with open world RPG enjoyers), but failed to expand their game accordingly.

On a more positive note, the combat is unique and interesting. Killing and looting is satisfying. Exploring [i]should[/i] be. Min-maxing a build is one of my favorite things to do. I could probably spent 500h on my first playthrough alone, combing through every pixel of the map.

Obviously, this is all based on my experience so far, which is primarily exploring Limgrave: spanking some bears and realizing it's too easy to soft-lock yourself out of basic *disgrunted noises* game mechanics *increasingly disgrunted noises.*

I cannot review the entire game fairly. 

(Review updated to clarify and remove sarcasm, lol)

[h2] Elden Ring Review and Criticisms (It's Still a Great Game) [/h2]
Elden Ring is the first FromSoftware game I've completed, and I wish I could experience it for the first time again. It is a journey through a beautiful, dense, yet hostile world that compels the player to explore the Lands Between and see everything it offers. The first two-thirds of the game is a wonderfully crafted experience and is densely packed with dungeons and caves to explore. Elden Ring is challenging, but the open-world nature of Elden Ring allows the player to fine-tune the difficulty of their playthrough - a player that thoroughly explores the Lands Between will be better equipped, higher level, and generally more comfortable with the game's combat system compared to a player of equivalent skill rushing through the story.

However, the last third is where the magic began wearing off, and as I've engaged with the multiplayer aspect more, Elden Ring's cracks have become more apparent. Below are some of the criticisms I've formed across my two playthroughs of this game:


[h3] Late Game Is Not Perfect [/h3]
Post-Leyndell enemies and bosses do significantly more damage proportionally to your character. Even with 60 Vigor and medium armor, I felt like I was too squishy at some points and relied on boiled seafood and incantations to raise my defenses. However, I could also just be bad at video games.

Actually, I've noticed some similarities between Elden Ring and Monster Hunter Rise Sunbreak. Especially in how their fanbases have responded to some of the changes in the bosses compared to previous titles. In both games, players complained about:
[list]
	[*] Bosses having long combos without many openings for the player
	[*] The amount of tracking some attacks had and how they felt unnatural at times
	[*] Endgame bosses having a lot more AOE attacks to compensate for the player having more movement options
	[*] Endgame boss damage being overtuned, especially with how easily they can roll catch the player due to more attacks having AOEs
	[*] Giant, clunky final boss where it just runs around while you chase it, trying to get hits in
[/list]

While I do have some gripes with the endgame boss design philosophy, the legacy dungeons and bosses really carry the last third of the game even with all their flaws, as the open world is barren by this point, and some of the fights are really fun once they click with you. 

I've gotten better at these fights thanks to playing a bunch of co-op, but I might want to see the damage tweaked a bit to allow for a new player to experiment more with the boss before dying (and so I can help more hosts before they get combo'd to oblivion).


[h3] Great Runes, Rune Arcs, and Invasions [/h3]
Rune Arcs, the item used to activate the effects of the Great Rune you have equipped, are in a weird place. They give you a powerful buff that lasts until death, but Rune Arcs are scarce, 50-60ish in a 100+ hour game where you're expected to die frequently, without farming rats for a 1% drop or engaging in the game's multiplayer. 

You can't even use them unless you are in your own world, so invaders and co-op summons, the players who have the most Rune Arcs and who continue to play the game after completing it, will not get any use out of them, and they can't even drop Rune Arcs for the host to use.

Invasions themselves are in an awkward situation in Elden Ring, as players can only invade worlds that have multiplayer summons or worlds in which the host decided to activate their taunter's tongue. The former situation is much more common and means that invaders will almost always be outnumbered and disadvantaged even if they are higher-skilled players, resulting in frustration, bitterness, and many invaders leaning more towards sweatier setups to secure the win.

Taunter's tongue isn't much better as it removes the timer between invasions, making invasions too frequent instead of just being an occasional, sudden event.

I think Rune Arcs should be more common throughout the Lands Between, and I would like for more multiplayer-centric Great Runes to be added in the DLC. A shop where players can exchange Rune Arcs for rare items would be great, as it would give players more legitimate ways to obtain larval tears (used for re-speccing your character) and other rare crafting materials.

Furthermore, having an active Great Rune should open your world up to invaders, but with a long time between invasions and decreased priority in matchmaking like in previous FromSoftware games (or so I've heard). It would keep the game's multiplayer scene active for longer and would allow for more natural and organic invasions, hopefully reducing toxicity in the community.


[h3] PVP, Netcode, and Suffering [/h3]
I am not going to sugarcoat it: Elden Ring's PVP and multiplayer infrastructure is a hot mess. All connections are P2P, and FromSoftware's netcode was not designed with the international player base in mind. 

One time, I pulled off a combo on my opponent in the Colosseum, but it didn't register until 10 seconds after it happened, and I watched the poor bastard take 1200 damage all at once, get flung into the air, and die. 

The latency isn't always this bad, but it is noticeable enough that combat feels rough and unintuitive for a new player. For example, let's say you hit your opponent on your screen, but due to latency, they saw the attack coming on their screen and dodged. They don't take damage, and you feel robbed. However, status buildup can still be applied in this case even if no damage was exchanged. You can roll through the damaging part of the status proc of bleed and frostbite, albeit you'll still be frostbitten, but madness and sleep procs will stun you out of your I-frames. You can dodge every single attack but then be punished because of how the game applies status buildup.

The same rules apply to you and your opponent, but that doesn't mean it feels great. Especially when PVP balancing is a complete joke and patches only come every few months. There will always be a meta because there will always be a weapon or a build that is stronger and more consistent than the rest, but off-meta options should remain viable, especially if the relative skill between two duelists is roughly equal.

As it stands, certain weapon combinations are oppressively strong, even in the hands of a mediocre player and even worse in the hands of a good player. Additionally, PVP damage is just too high because it uses the same PVE damage formulas, where bosses have HP pools in the thousands and players have 1900 HP at 60 Vigor, and Elden Ring feeds into the player's power fantasy with over-the-top, flashy skills and weapons that are fun to use in PVE but annoying to fight in PVP.

With over 100 weapons to balance and thousands of different build combinations, this game would be a nightmare to balance, and I certainly don't have the solution to perfectly balance this game's PVP.

Regardless, I hope that FromSoftware can alleviate some of these issues in the DLC and future titles. When it's fun, it's addictively fun. When it's not, I regret my life choices. 

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Despite my issues with Elden Ring, this is undoubtedly a great game that I do not regret playing through. I am only so critical because I had so much fun with the game and want FromSoftware to make Elden Ring even better (or at least fix their damn netcode for future titles).

Thus, I highly recommend this game if you are at all interested. I thought that I would be done after my first playthrough, but it wasn't long before I made a new character and journeyed through the Lands Between once more.

I am updating my review. My first review was done at launch and was based on the dominance of item injection exploits and other game destroying hacks carried over from Dark Souls 3. Chiefly among the issues was a remote code execution attack.  

Fromsoftware has fixed the most dangerous exploits, but cheaters are still present. There may also be issues with running the game on Linux and getting falsely banned.

However, Fromsoftware has overwhelmingly corrected issues the community has brought to them. Elden Ring is a fantastic and polished experience. More than a year after release, the combat system has undergone a number of refinements that have made it mostly superior to Dark Souls 3.

Like all Souls games, this game is overrated. 
As a veteran gamer, I find the gameplay basic,  and the combat mechanics slow and clunky, especially compared to the fast-paced, free-flowing combat mechanics of a game like Killer is Dead. It's sad that Killer is Dead was panned by users, but these slow, clunky Souls games are critically acclaimed, even though their gameplay is all the same and never evolves. I admit that Elden Ring's open world looks appealing, but I would always trade that in for fast-paced gameplay with more combat options. As such, I can't get into this game or any other Souls game. If you want fast and varied combat mechanics, the Marvel Spiderman games blows this out of the water.

Very slow to start, guidance is extremely poor, must use a guide and the ER wiki to help understand game objectives, play mechanics and quest lines. Very difficult at times, some QoL is much needed, in particular to the clunky personal stash, quest objectives, and item/character stats. 

Dungeons all fall under 4-5 types of cookie cutter environments, rather uninspiring. The final boss fight with Radagon and Elden Beast are incredibly difficult leading up to that point.  Also new game modes NG+ offer nothing new other than increased monster difficulty, very lazy design effort imho. Graphics are excellent, but could be better at times (i.e. water falls look cheap).  Land exploration is excellent, lots of hidden paths/secrets. Torrent should also have multiple skins and possibly powers. You're stuck with the same horse from the very beginning, lame.

I would rate Elden Ring a solid 7.5/10 for it's sheer size but loses marks for unrefined game design.

A tiresome overdose of fantasy nonsense. Every inch of this game is too busy with itself. A real mess of game-world, cluttered with polished shit and NPCs spouting the fantasy version of technobabble at you. After trudging through the first overblown castle, the heap of them at the horizon don't look so epic anymore, and the busy path there a slog.
It has the virtues of a game developed by a studio that has done this better before. All the individual assets are of high quality, but because of From Softs approach to (not) telling stories they are not properly tied together into anything greater.

Pros:
*Great bosses
*Cool weapons
*Exploring the world is very fun and rewarding
*If you're not using mimic tear or getting overleveled the game will be very exciting and challenging
*You don't actually need shields or different ways of avoiding damage for bosses as some would assume; rolling will always (or at least 99% of the time) work 
*Soundtrack is also great 
*Torrent is best boi

Cons: 
*They added a slighty longer duration to the estus (?) flask and a small delay in the startup of the rolling which will FUCK Bloodborne/DS3 players in the ass until they get used to it (and even after that too sometimes)
*Previous games were super fair since bosses had great animations and with good reflexes you could dodge attacks, so it always depended on your skills and you never had to memorize any attacks, but then Nameless King came and with him Elden Ring later, seriously, these is a huge amount of delayed attacks that will screw will and make it so that you have to memorize some attacks instead of always depending solely on your skills as a player
*Malenia is insanely easy if you're overleveled/use mimic tear (newbie tools btw :v) but hardest boss in the game without a doubt which usually wouldn't be a problem but she's poorly made and has a lot of artificial difficulty which doesn't depend on your actual skills and instead needs pattern memorizing like waterfowl dance and a few others, they should also have removed her lifestill and gave her a third form instead, like Friede in DS3

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Elden Ring combines gameplay and lessons learned from Fromsoft's portfolio of Souls-like games of the recent past - just thrown into an open-world environment. A generous number of graces (aka bonfires w/ fast travel) and general quality-of-life gameplay improvements give the game a nice flow. The spirit summon system though (with accessibility for casual gamers in mind) can be OP and almost trivialize a majority of boss fights. If you are a completionist and want to collect and see everything in Elden Ring, the game can also feel drawn out from time to time: the map is empty between key locations and optional dungeon bosses are recycled over and over. 

Dark Souls and Sekiro are (imho) still superior games, as their worlds feel more organic and perfectly designed, offering unique bosses that pose a (fair) challenge. Nevertheless, Elden Ring is still one of Fromsoft's most ambitious and epic endeavors and is definitely worth playing if you love Souls-likes!

This game will make you think and forces you to plan your moves rather than presenting a cake walk face roll style easy path.  Its fun, but it will toss you on your butt many times.  Learn to dust off, and learn from your mistakes.  Get too confident?  Then back off on the next try.  Didn't block?  Maybe you can't burst that guy down so you'll have to plan for the long game and be defensive at times.  The game is tough, sometimes seemingly too tough.  Go gain a few, or many, levels and come back later.  I've had WTF fights turn into too easy doing that.  Don't be afraid to die and fail, but if you want low stress, low commitment, this game might not be the best pick.

My very first FromSoft/souls-like game and I absolutely love it. 
Even at 130 hours in, I'm still stumbling into new places and quests. Everything, from the regions, the NPCs, and especially the bosses, seems to be purposefully crafted. I like that it doesn't serve things up on a silver platter. It is one of those games that actually imposes a challenge which is rare these days and I appreciate that. The game also does not tell me to do this and that. I can do whatever I want, whenever I want, and that's what a real open world game should do.  

As I was about to fight the last boss, I caught myself thinking, "I don't want it to end." 
Overall a solid experience, and I'm about to go through another run with a different build this time. With my new best friend, the mimic, of course.

I first fell in love with FromSoftware games through Bloodborne and then retroactively went back to the others on PlayStation. It's clear why the Dark Souls franchise still holds up after all this time and Elden Ring seems to follow in the same timeless appeal considering the polish, love, care, and attention to detail in every aspect that it comes shipped with. This, like sleeper hits such as BG3 are the reason I got in to gaming. There's a love here and Elden Ring's love-letter to it's predecessors stands apparent. 

What are you going to love about it? The story, should you chase after it, is as rich, deep, and complex as one may expect from authors Miyazaki and George R. R. Martin. The rich fantasy and imaginative areas make for the Lands Between to be one of the most unique worlds I've come across in any form of media.

Beyond this, the graphics, sure, but mostly, you're going to enjoy the challenge. FromSoft games are challenging. That's their appeal. But it's a fair challenge that urges you to grow and "git gud". There's an excitement when you fell that boss for the first time and a fun fraction of a moment where you consider apologising to your controller for ever having considering seeing how many walls it could go through from sheer frustration as you channel your anger and chuck it, That said, take a moment, shift your perspective, and try again. 

Git gud. 

This game is tough but fair. Some moments and attack tracking can feel... odd, but by and large, it's a fair game with famously precise hitboxes making for some of the most cinematic fights one can (accidentally) make. 

Overall, yes, buy this game. Products like this are what keeps creative storytelling and innovative gameplay with an unmatched attention to detail to be the norm moving forward.

It doesn't spark any sort of joy in me. Dark Souls is one of my most favorite series in the world. I have more hours in DS3 than I'd ever like to admit across Steam and my Xbox, and this game made me hate FromSoft. The bosses all feel cheap. I don't feel like I'm improving, I feel like I'm spending hours learning one boss, then need to forget everything just to spend hours on the next. I'm a series vet and exactly 1 boss in this game has felt any fun. I can't recommend just buying Dark Souls instead enough. This game broke my heart.

Edit: After trying so hard and giving this game too many chances, nothing has changed. I wanted to love it. So many amazing ideas, but this game doesn't bring even the slightest amount of happiness I felt playing Dark Souls. I tried modding it, I tried reading tips and watching people play, I forced myself to play through and beat every single boss to see what I was missing and simply couldn't, before it turned into a buggy mess I physically couldn't even play. I can't recommend this game at all, and I do not understand the praise.

So before I go into my long paragraph, let me start by saying this is my favorite game with one large problem that needs to be talked about. If you don't care about pvp or playing with friends just buy the game, you will love it. However, if you want to know what the online situation is, read below.

 I bought this game on ps5 and PC and they both are great. During my 1300 hours on two different accounts, I can safely tell you that Elden ring PVP is so busted and the lack of balance and poor online item designs are why. And if you don't believe me, go look at the seamless co-op mod. It removes pvp and changes pve with a different version and has over 3 million downloads. I'm obviously not the first to see the problems with vanilla online interactions. 
https://www.nexusmods.com/eldenring/mods/510 
Now back to the in game proof. Take talismans for example. Dragoncrest greatshield increases physical protection by 20 percent but decreases it to 5 in pvp. While I think It shouldn't be decreased that much I see why 20 percent stacked with other buffs may be busted. But now lets look at Shard of Alexander. A powerful talisman which increases the effects of skills by 15 percent (plus a small damage boost that is noticeable in mid to late game on normal attacks), and it has no nerf whatsoever in pvp. How is this good game design? There are almost no attack talismans that have been nerfed, yet all the defense oriented ones get nerfed to unusability. This is why the community hates weapons like rivers, moonveil, and wave of stupidity(waterever that sword is called that you get from beating elden beast). Now I'm not mad about these weapons. I personally have no problem fighting three mages with all moonveils in a gank squad. But if your going to nerf the things I need to protect myself, at least nerf the attack talismans as well. If Shard of Alexander alone is nerfed I feel like a lot of people would stop spamming special attack and actually learn how to play the game. The online items used to access pvp and pve can also be used as a example. I have invaded people on so many different types of levels. I have invaded at level 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 150, 185, 200, 250, 300, and max level commonly. There is common occurrence that happens at all of these levels (except max level, off course). Over leved phantoms. I don't care what you do. If you are fighting a half decent player, there is no way a level 20 can beat a level 20 with two level 200's guarding him. The fact that I see someone using Hand of Melania when I'm invading at level 20 or 40 is complete bull. Granted, I know how to dodge, but it's still bull. When you invade, the game should look at the player with the highest level instead of the host. Then maybe add 1/4 the level of everyone he is playing with. I'm fine with me being level 60 and my friends level 40 and being invaded by a level 50-80. That is a completely fair fight. Another thing is the the design of taunters tongue. The fact that you can even turn it off during a invasion makes me want to break my keyboard. Most of these people will have the blue cipher ring on as well and just keep summoning people to no end. No wonder gank squads are so common, because it's so easy! Another wonderful thing about taunters tongue, the fact that the host gets full heals if they are alone and I only get half is a dumb design choice. At least half their supply if a blue joins, making it fair. I'm not going to fight someone with 14 heals, with aoe spam, with the cipher ring on, while I have 5 heals. Not to mention if they have spells like erdtree heal as well. Good luck trying to do anything then. A lesser problem is true combos. I am all for true combos, they are a really cool, but the ash of wars need to have longer start up times. Spinning slash is one example. Making it a two instead of three combo would make this not overpowered. Don't even get me talking about stormcaller or storm assault either. No wonder people spam special attack everyday. While nerfing true combos will probably be controversial, It will result in a friendlier pvp experience. Another problem is phantom hits. I don't know why I'm dodging but status effects are still effecting me. I posted this response on wiki, but I doubt Fromsoft will see it there, so here is the steam version. I'm open for any counter arguments that may be spoken.

FromSoftware's latest creation, Elden Ring, is nothing short of a masterpiece that seamlessly weaves together the renowned game design of Hidetaka Miyazaki and the epic fantasy world-building prowess of George R. R. Martin. As a seasoned player of FromSoftware titles, I can confidently say that Elden Ring stands as a testament to the studio's dedication to pushing the boundaries of the action RPG genre.

First and foremost, Elden Ring introduces a vast and breathtaking open-world that dwarfs its predecessors. The Lands Between is a sprawling, interconnected realm filled with diverse landscapes, towering castles, and mysterious dungeons. The sheer scale of exploration is awe-inspiring, and every corner of the map beckons with secrets waiting to be unearthed.

The narrative is a captivating tale of cosmic proportions, intricately woven into the fabric of the game's lore. George R. R. Martin's influence is evident in the rich history, complex characters, and the overarching sense of grandiosity. The lore is not just a backdrop but an integral part of the gaming experience, encouraging players to piece together the narrative puzzle as they venture deeper into the world.

True to FromSoftware's signature style, Elden Ring offers a punishing yet deeply satisfying combat system. The weight of each swing, the precision of dodges, and the strategic use of magic contribute to a combat ballet that demands skill, patience, and adaptability. The introduction of mounted combat adds a new layer to the dynamic encounters, as players can engage foes both on foot and astride their trusty steed, Torrent.

The game's character customization and class system allow for a diverse range of playstyles, ensuring that each player's journey through the Lands Between is a unique experience. The extensive skill tree, combined with the flexibility of weapon and magic combinations, grants a sense of agency over character development.

Elden Ring's bosses are a true highlight, offering some of the most challenging and memorable encounters in the genre. Each boss feels like a living, breathing entity with distinct attack patterns and phases. Conquering these formidable foes is not just a test of skill but a triumph of persistence and strategic thinking.

While the game is a testament to excellence, it's not without its minor flaws. The occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-ins, especially in the more expansive areas, slightly mar the otherwise impeccable presentation. However, these issues are forgivable in the grand scope of Elden Ring's achievements.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a tour de force that exceeds expectations on every front. It pushes the boundaries of what an action RPG can achieve, delivering an unforgettable experience that marries challenging gameplay with a rich, sprawling world. FromSoftware has once again redefined the genre, and Elden Ring stands as a shining beacon in the realm of gaming, inviting players to embark on an epic journey that will resonate long after the credits roll.

My review will talk about the performance, controls, worldbuilding, mechanics, quests and also THIS REVIEW MIGHT CONTAIN MINOR SPOILERS. You've been warned!

I will start first with the performance and controls. Here are my ancient specs:
[list]
    [*]Intel i5 - 7400;
    [*]8 GB RAM HyperX Fury;
    [*]Sapphire RX580 Nitro+ 4GB VRAM version.
[/list]

The game runs between 30 to 60 fps, with an average of 45-50 fps on HIGH settings depending of the region and will drop to 20-25 fps when is loading for some seconds a new area. The game will run smooth in close quarter building with the max 60 fps. 
With my current spec I've met some stutters, but they were minor and it didn't affect my fights or exploration.

When it comes to controls they are very clunky at least at the start of the game, but you will get used to them. I know their games are meant to be played with a controller, but I don't like it very much as "I can't feel the control over my character". You will get the classic experience with the KMB: Q being back for menu and lock-target while playing, R using consumables, E picking up items and the arrows being the switch for weapons, spells and consumables. What is new in this game and what I changed is the SPRINT being put on SPACE, by holding it. I've moved it to SHIFT where I moved also BACKSTEP, DODGE ROLL and DASH that were also put on SPACE. I left the CROUCH on X, and moved the JUMP from F to SPACE. Also be aware that the map is not on M is actually on G, which sadly you can't change it.
Also some tips & tricks:
[list]
    [*]You can change the prompt of controls from Setting > Sound and Display > Device for On-Screen Prompts > Keyboard and Mouse;
    [*]To change from one handed to two-handed and vice versa hold E + LEFT MOUSE BUTTON;
    [*]It's good to put your trusty steed Torrent in your pouch so you can access it by holding E + LEFT, UP, RIGHT, DOWN ARROW (choose your preference).
[/list]
Hope this helps!
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Now I'm gonna talk about the worldbuilding, mechanics and quests. The world of Elden Ring it's very mesmerizing, very mysterious, but also dangerous. When I played, I finally had the feeling of "I'm going to an adventure", and the last time I felt that way was back in Dark Souls 3. The open world it's fantastic and everything it's build with care and attention with tons of different things to either discover or fight. At this moment I have 853 photos that I took through my gameplay and I usually either forget to take photos in game, or take them to a minimum level. I'm amazed about what they built with the same ENGINE and how much depth and details they put into their work, some photos that I took I can even put them as background for my PC, because they look so good and clean. Every single zone from Limgrave to the final zone [spoiler]Farum[/spoiler] it's incredible, filled with so much details, everything has it's own identity, which I personally like it to the very end.
---
The story of the game is "simple", yet complex when you put every single piece of information gathered either through dialogue with NPCs, quests or by exploring. In this game, YOU are a Tarnished, once banished for losing the blessing of the Grace and now recalled back with other Tarnished after the Shattering, in The Lands Between to recover the Great Runes, restore the Elden Ring and become the next Elden Lord.
What I like about the games made by FromSoftware? They never handhold you, or at least they are doing that to a minimum level. It's an open world, you're free to explore, to do whatever you want. But because it's an open world don't expect to fight the end game enemies fast. What you should take in consideration when you play Elden Ring:
[list]
    [*]Sites of grace are your compass, they tell you where the Shard bearers are and where to go next. If you follow them, be assured that you will not get lost, but at the same time don't forget to explore the vast world and meet the other Tarnished (NPCs)
    [*]Elden Ring is not linear as the other past games made by FromSoftware. New players or even veterans, that got used to the old mechanics, don't understand that freedom might be also your biggest enemy. If you explore and reach a zone where you get overwhelmed and destroyed by monster, don't get upsate that it's unfair, just keep in mind you come back later after you got strong and far into the story. [spoiler]I got teleported to Caelid because of a trap chest and I wondered why I wasn't doing that much damage, but I knew that later on I will be fine.[/spoiler]
    [*]As I said previously you have freedom which is your friend and at the same time your enemy. The world is vast and filled with secrets, dungeons, mini-bosses and items. Don't be afraid to discover them, you might discover a spell or weapon that you will like it and presumably will make you stronger.
    [*]Listen to what NPCs have to say. They will tell you where you will meet them in the future, EXPECT that you will meet them. Don't get mad that you lost a quest, or did something bad, learn what you did wrong, plan what to do in your next journey when you finish the game.
    [*]Use every resource you have to your own advantage. Read the messages that other players left behind, some might help you, some might not, and some are wrote just for fun, but they are there. Miyazaki wants the community to help each others, that's why there are messages. Use steam forums, ask for help, ASK YOUR FRIENDS, if you want you can take a glimpse at a guide on the internet on what to do with a specific NPC, quest, as it's not something to be ashamed about, everyone is doing mistakes, and everyone is hitting a wall sometimes. You did a mistake with an NPC in your run, but I will do better in my next one. JUST DO IT!
    [*]Use the map! Pin your NPC, resources, ANYTHING!
    [*]A boss is hard? You spent 1,5 hours trying to beat it? (Looking at you Valiant Gargoyles) You have many options: request help, play with friends, use summon ashes, find a suitable Ash of War for that fight.
    [*]The AI of monsters, mini-bosses, bosses is learning from your moves and mistakes. Unlike the past souls games, in Elden Ring you might get overwhelmed by a long series of fast attacks or even insta kills. Learn from your mistakes, hone your skills, it's possible to beat it!
[/list]
