I have played all the Souls games including Demons Souls, Bloodborne and Sekiro.  I have beaten all of them from Dark Souls 1 to 3 and the Souls cousins above. I just finished playing a heavily modded version of Skyrim (400+ concurrent mods) and I had basically turned Skyrim into Dark Souls.  Playing Elden Ring feels like I am playing a heavily modded version of Dark Souls 3.  It is awesome.

PvE is great, the exploration, soundtrack, boss and world design is amazing.
The stuttering can be quite bad on PC.
Craftable items are a issue as there is a limited amount of stuff you can craft or have and farming for what you can farm for can be a nightmare.
As for PvP...
..the new backstab is great, there has been some decent changes and balances recently but the game still needs a few tweaks PvP wise.
Double lance/heavy thrusting weapons are far too strong.
Poise and hyper armor are too strong. Arena sizes for duels are too large. 
Some spells are borderline useless and some can be dodge by just moving left to right.
Same go for ashes of war, a lot are useless. Flame strike, golden parry, storm caller are still broken.
The free aim on spells are also terrible and have very limited aiming angles.
Still no rewards or rankings for PvP/Arena or covenants, making PvP a bit dry. 
Phantom hits are still a issue but mostly just when you hit/bomb and get procced with madness/frost or when you have a proc of bleed/frost nearly full then someone rolls and it resets the status bar.
It's Dark Souls on Steroids what else is there to say.

Where to start... Well, the game is fantastic. It transports me back to the first time I played Dark Souls, as I eagerly anticipate returning to the Lands Between every morning upon waking up. It's incredibly immersive, and the world is absolutely stunning. The lore is exceptional, as expected, and it's evident that From Software has incorporated elements from every Souls game (including Bloodborne/Sekiro) in the development of Elden Ring. It's definitely worth purchasing, but keep in mind that it may be very challenging for some players at the beginning (especially if you're new to the franchise).

I appreciate the variety of weaponry available, which allows for a multitude of different builds and playthroughs. I admire the effort that From Software put into encouraging players to utilise the FP mechanic by introducing Ashes of War skills. This ultimately enables players to approach the game in numerous ways while experimenting with different builds.

Is the game flawless? Not entirely... there are two aspects of the game that I find worth criticising. Firstly, the repetition of bosses becomes monotonous after a while. I understand, to some extent, why this occurs in an open-world game. Secondly, the hit-boxes of some bosses are quite problematic... the dragons in Azula, for instance, and that Death Bird's Abomination, too. They were defeated... but my greatsword couldn't reach their heads... though I suppose this might not be an issue for certain builds. There are bugs, but they aren't significant enough to dissuade me from enjoying the game.

Regardless, it's a fantastic experience, so give it a try. You won't regret it. :)
lets me commit mass genocide
yes

Pro:
+ Incredibly vast and beautiful open world filled to the brim with content,spectacular vistas and unending dangers, basically the anti-Ubisoft open world

+ Trademark pitch perfect souls combat from the creators of the genre, build variety is top among all the souls series

+ Incredibly good lore with magnificent characters ( Ranni the Witch a personal favorite) with a great story that in pure From Software style needs to be discovered all around you

+ Some of the best bosses fight in the genre, only reached by Lies of P recently

+ Top of the class music and voicework for the entire cast of characters

Con:

- Reuse of minibosses and minor dungeons, catacombs, caverns and their respective minibosses are reused with slight variations quite often, same for some of the open world encounters

- Incredibly weird difficulty spike in the last third of the game that can take even experienced souls player by surprise, also the enemies in the third part are mostly enemies from the rest of the world but with hp doubled and damage tripled, can feel slightly lazy or rushed

- A polarizing last boss where you have a magnificent phase 1 and probably the worst souls boss ever made by From Software for phase 2, its quite jarring

To say that Elden Ring is one of the best games ever made is useless, everyone of the planet knows that already, it battles with Bloodborne and Dark Souls 3 for the throne of best From Software game ever made and in some spots it wins for sure, the Land Between are a pleasure to explore, conquer and die into and basically every player that is not immediately against hard games should buy and play Elden Ring.

Easily a well deserved  9.5/10

As of my last update in January 2022, "Elden Ring" had not been released, so I cannot provide a review based on personal experience. However, I can offer a speculative review based on the information available prior to its release. "Elden Ring" is an upcoming action role-playing game developed by FromSoftware and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment, known for their work on the "Dark Souls" series. Here's a speculative review listing potential positives and negatives:

Positives:

FromSoftware's Legacy: "Elden Ring" is developed by FromSoftware, a studio renowned for its challenging and atmospheric games. With a track record that includes critically acclaimed titles like "Dark Souls," "Bloodborne," and "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice," expectations are high for "Elden Ring" to deliver an immersive and compelling experience.

Open-World Exploration: "Elden Ring" promises to feature an expansive open world for players to explore. FromSoftware's previous games have excelled in creating intricate and atmospheric environments, filled with hidden secrets, challenging enemies, and lore-rich storytelling. The open-world format could allow for even greater freedom and discovery.

Collaboration with George R.R. Martin: "Elden Ring" features collaboration with acclaimed fantasy author George R.R. Martin, known for his work on the "A Song of Ice and Fire" series, which inspired the "Game of Thrones" television show. Martin's involvement suggests a rich and detailed narrative that could elevate the game's storytelling to new heights.

Combat and Gameplay Depth: FromSoftware games are known for their deep and strategic combat systems, which require careful timing, positioning, and mastery of various weapons and abilities. "Elden Ring" is expected to build upon this foundation, offering challenging encounters and rewarding gameplay for players who enjoy a high level of difficulty.

Negatives:

High Difficulty: While the challenging gameplay is a hallmark of FromSoftware titles, it can also be a barrier for some players. The difficulty level of "Elden Ring" may deter those who prefer more casual or accessible gaming experiences, potentially limiting its appeal to a niche audience.

Performance Issues: Open-world games often face technical challenges related to performance, optimization, and bugs. Given the ambitious scope of "Elden Ring" and FromSoftware's track record with technical issues in past titles, there is a possibility that the game could encounter performance issues at launch or require post-launch patches to address.

Steep Learning Curve: FromSoftware games are known for their steep learning curves, requiring players to adapt to complex mechanics and unforgiving combat encounters. While rewarding for those who enjoy a challenge, "Elden Ring" may prove frustrating for players who struggle to overcome its initial difficulty spike.

Sparse Information Pre-Release: As of now, details about "Elden Ring" are limited, and much of the game's content and features remain shrouded in mystery. While this aura of anticipation can be exciting for fans, it also leaves room for disappointment if the final product fails to meet heightened expectations.

In conclusion, "Elden Ring" has the potential to be a groundbreaking addition to FromSoftware's catalog, offering an expansive open world, rich storytelling, and challenging gameplay. However, it also carries the risk of technical issues, accessibility barriers, and unmet expectations. Fans of FromSoftware's previous titles and lovers of challenging action RPGs will likely find much to enjoy in "Elden Ring," but newcomers should approach with caution and be prepared for a demanding and immersive experience.

in most ways, the only FROM SOFTWARE game you'll ever need.

Elden Ring so far outclasses the older games in so many ways, that i find it very hard to return to any of them. In many ways its the hardest of them all but at the same time more forgiving than its predecessors. this is owed to the worlds' open exploration mindedness. banging your head against a boss fight? go somewhere else in the region, or better yet, explore an earlier section more deeply. it was during these moments that i found some of the more engaging aspects of the game, like a slowly expanding crafting system, various fights you never have to do that net you awesome items, chests that teleport you across the map, and interesting areas to farm in. Not to mention the talismans which can alter your playstyle to be more in line with Bloodborne. Magic feels like something that is useful to everyone, even non-magic builds.

the world and story are uh fine. its amazing and beautiful to look at, but you'll always be kept at arms length from its lore and history, thanks to FROMs usual brand of item-description based storytelling and comically cryptic NPCs. Whats there is also simply not as interesting to delve into as DS or Bloodborne. the lack of a journal system makes this game's vast world and numerous quests irritating to keep track of. if its been a while since you last played, you may find it easier to just start over.

Bring Bloodborne to PC.

that concludes my TED talk.

The world is GINORMOUS, to make it even better they added breathtaking scenery with attention to detail. The amount of weapons or spells with unique and eye pleasing effects is hugee, everyone will find atleast one weapon which makes you fall in love with it. Lore isnt directly told to the player for the most time, you have to dicover it by yourself (AND ITS AMAZING). Designs of enemies, bosses, npcs, areas and wearable armor - almost all of them are BEAUTIFUL. Every aspect of this game is almost perfect, its hard to find other games that good but despite that i found 2 things that takes away few points for me:

- replay ability - i found it hard to go through this whole game over and over again. I though about it for a while and came to conslusion that the distances between everything are HUGEE and when you completed your firsth playthrough exploring literally every little corner of this game youll lose almost all of your motivation to play it again. This might be only my problem because Ive heard from many people that its way more replayable than other dark souls games because of this huge world but idk. Mabye someone will find it relatable. 

- The amount of closed areas - Like the classic dark souls ones, they could easly squize two or three more. Theyre iterally the best moments of this game. Despite being the best moments i found them empty and neglected in some small parts. (This thinking may be caused by the love i share to all dark souls games)

I have a lot of mixed feelings about this game. I think it is the best open world game I've ever played, but I also think it's a critically flawed game that has some glaring issues I can't believe made it through production.

The exploration in this game is phenomenal. There is always something to be doing wherever you are, always a cave, always some ruins, always an evergaol or a puzzle or something. There are no vast, empty stretches of nothing in this game like there are in so many other open world games. However, this does lead to the issue of encounter reuse. A lot of those caves are filled with the same enemies, evergaols are mostly just reused bosses, once you do one puzzle tower you sort of get how to do all of them. By the time you finish the game, you'll realize that there are really only a handful of unique encounters, and I think that's a bit of a shame. I wish some of the bigger fights were truly unique so they felt more special. But instead you can find a copy of a big quest-ending boss in a cave somewhere.

The main issue I have with this game comes down to balance. They player is given a lot of tools and a lot of talismans and equipment that seems to imply that those tools would be useful, but the vast majority of them are just trash. Poison status damage is just worse Scarlet Rot. Holy damage is basically unusable at the end of the game. Smaller weapons like claws and daggers and fists stand no chance against larger enemies when you can't even reach their bodies. Death blight is completely useless in PvE, but a lot of spells/gear inflict it.

On the flip side, some stuff just feels way too over-tuned. Jump attacks are almost always the best thing you can be doing as a melee player. Some sorceries scale so hard you might as well just have a gun to shoot enemies with. Dragon cult incantations are way more powerful than most other incantations. It feels like the game has a handful of "correct" builds, and a lot of distractions to throw you off of those builds, and it hopes you figure out which is which by the end game.

All of that being said, this game is still a lot of fun. It feels great when you make a build that works well, and it has so many options that you'll be thinking of alternative builds for future characters the whole time you play.

I can't say enough about this game. Luckily most of it has already been said. I'm not someone who like to try a ton of different builds. I have a clear idea of who I want to be in a fantasy world and pursue that in every game. I have put 308 hours into playing the game and "perfecting" one single build and have enjoyed every minute of it. I say perfecting but I am by no means amazing at this game and that doesn't bother me at all. For those that like to try a variety of builds across many playthroughs this game will support that easily.

At 203 hours, I finished the Elden Ring story, with considerable detours in the middle for stuff and exploration, and I certainly think is a great game, an enjoyable one for the most part of it's runtime; but at the same time, coming to this game after the great experience that was Sekiro, after reading about all it's award winning fame, and after it was paraded left and right as the real way to make video games opposite to the western devs who just don't get it, I was extremely surprised at just how janky the entire game is. And I'm talking about "Bethesda" levels of jank at times, and most of it comes from the same reason: a "Bigger is Better" mentality that permeates the entire design phylosophy of the game, and after the initial shock is starts losing it's luster the more the game drags on. 

The world is vast, with great environments to explore and some clever tricks awaiting the player exploring the catacombs, some of which trully spectacular and some of which literally a white curtain of nothing to see; but at the same time this became an excess, with a map far larger than the enemy variety they were willing to make, including a constant repetition of minibosses (specially the Godskin ones and the lava dragon),and making NPCs almost impossible to find without the external help of a guide or a lot of sheer luck, kind of defeating the purpose of the "no handholding" philosophy people like to highlight.

Bosses are massive, with a lot of well animated attacks and patterns that can change based on players actions or positions (except for like 3, and are truly the highlight of the game; but this also becomes an excess. In a rather ironic twist, the bigger the moster is, the less you actually see of it due to camera limitations (a camera that I already called a possible dealbreaker in Sekiro, a game with mostly human sized enemies, and is left almost intact to try combat things 10 times the size) so most fights against giant enemies, at least if fighting melee, consisted of having the entire screen occupied by the enemy crotch or rear area it couldn't reach with most of their normal attacks while trying to dodge their AoE through sheer instinct. Several field monsters are also too big for the scenario where the fight takes place, ending in situations like having a dragon climb up a hill outside of reach and having to wait for it to respawn to resume combat, having it land on a wall and stand on it vertical, or the rather infamous Night Cavalry who have all their attacks reset by the walls of the very bridges they lurk. All of this made me appreciate a lot more the "smaller", more human like bosses which you could properly see, though they too posed a problem to the camera when they could fly or jump high, as the lock-on's way to keep track of them when they did that in front of you was to rapidly flip up and down while remaining attach to the player's back (second phase Malenia, in particular, caused me nausea due to this constant sudden movements).

Another excess can be found in the variety and options for combat: multiple kinds of weapons are available for you to fit your playstile in any way you want, but at the same time most of the gear feels poorly balanced, with some things that are early jewels that eclipse late game prizes or rare drops. The spells in particular, at least in the incantation section in which I delved, suffered a lot in this regard, as a lot of the stuff I kept finding were basically trash, to slow or weak to replace a simple lightning javelin I got like 20 hours in. The weapons had a similar case: a lot of bloat, with mechanics that are similar in weapons of the same class except for some outliers, but ultimately living or dying due to their scaling or skill. There's a considerable amount of cool or niche stuff to find, but the size of the game calls for them to be rare gems in a sea of mediocre gear you can't even test out for fun due to limitations of stat builds and smiting material.

Ultimately, that's where the game experience eventually leads. The thrill of exploration and fighting really good bosses is certainly there, I had a lot of fun in the game to not recommend it; but at the same time it has it's fair share of frustrations, the game prisoner of it's own bloat, it's own hype, and a camera system that didn't evolve since their last game at all and fails to properly highlight what From Software seems to think is their biggest strenght: fighting huge stuff. I will play some more in NG+ and I'm looking forward to see how the DLC turns out, but also I can't deny my plans to check the Dark Souls trilogy were put on ice after experiencing this, which makes me wonder if my view of Elden Ring would have been more negative had I played the others first.

I am a Soulsborne Veteran and have always enjoyed the titles that came before this one. Each game was different, with it's own set of challenges and flaws. Which is why I thoroughly feel all the things each game did right culminated into the game that is "Elden Ring".

This game is a masterpiece, both in gameplay and storytelling. Where in previous titles you followed a general path to success, Elden RIng allows you multiple avenues and tools to navigate. This game drew from the successful gameplay of Dark Souls III while implementing the scenic styles of all Soulsborne titles. 
This allowed it to be incredibly diverse in design, where enemy and landscape appearances drew heavily from Elden Ring's predecessors.

A Fromsoftware game with an open world and worldbuilding by George R.R Martin (Game of Thrones author). Almost a masterpiece.

Complaints are:

Replays arent too fun.

Feeling of exhaustion when wandering the open world and fighting some enemies.

Reuse of some bosses that make the main story boss encounters less special.

One shots that sometimes feel unfair.

Useless rewards for exploring "mini" areas in the world, rewards that only work for specific builds.

Repeated use of bosses and enemies to fill dungeons and such, but is kind of to be expected for how big of an openworld it is.

Pvp could also get better but will probably be expanded on upon release of dlc and other patches.

And some bosses can seem unfair, for example: Malenia and Elden Beast.

Elden Ring marks my first journey into the realm of FromSoftware's titles, and what a journey it has been. Initially daunted by their reputation for unyielding difficulty, I found myself repeatedly humbled by the game's unforgiving nature. However, with each defeat came a deeper understanding of its intricate combat system, culminating in moments of triumph that are unparalleled in gaming. Overcoming adversaries like Maliketh, Malenia, and the Fire Giant left me breathless and exhilarated, echoing Miyazaki's desire for players to experience the joy of conquering adversity.

Elden Ring is not just a game; it's a testament to the power of perseverance and dedication, and achieving 100% completion on Steam feels like a monumental achievement, a testament to the countless hours spent overcoming its challenges. In the end, Elden Ring stands as a modern masterpiece and a work of digital art, beckoning all who dare to heed its call.

"Arise now, ye Tarnished. Ye dead, who yet live. The call of long-lost grace speaks to us all."

its worse than all the dark souls games but its still basically dark souls 4 and therefore amazing.

the open world causes a lot of things to begin to feel very copy paste. when your not in a legacy dungeon the game becomes "run around and fill out little map points of interest" this is fun the first time around but on a second or third playthrough itll become rather tired out quickly. the combat feels very similar to dark souls 3 but a lot more forgiving. posture is now a thing so frontal ripostes become much more common place without needing to parry. this game truly excels in build variety. there are so many spells, weapons, ashes of war, spitirt ashes, to mess around. respeccing stats is unlocked earlier and is cheap so you can mess around with builds. the only limiting factor is how many final upgrade items you get per playthrough.

the bigger problems i have with this game are the soundtrack, the story, and the inevitable downsides that come from an open world. the soundtrack is fine. a lot of boss themes are very good. the problem is the fact that it feels like they only put effort into the boss music. there are no melancholy tunes in the whole game. Demons souls, dark souls, and dark souls 2, all had amazing title and hub music. its a shame that the only somewhat quiet song that plays in elden ring is the open world ambient music. its mediocre at best and becomes very tired out.

for story bringing on George R.R. Martin feels like one of the worst mistakes they could have done. learning about relationship drama between the main bosses of the game is the main thing that drags the story down in my opinion. i much prefer the stories of dark souls 1, demon's souls, and bloodborne. Im not a fan of game of thrones and would have liked if his style of writing stayed out of the successor to dark souls.

despite all that this game is still amazing and sure to give you many many hours of fun. :)

Would I recommend Elden Ring to other players? Other players of what? 
Zelda? Yes.
Super Mario players? Surprisingly, yes. 
Dark Souls players? Yes.
Visual Novel players? No.
Godeater players? Yes.
Star Craft? No.
Diablo players? Maybe Diablo 1+2 players.
MMO players? Not unless they were stressed out raid leaders.
By players of those games, I mean if that's ALL they like to play and don't want to traverse too deep into another genre... I found the original Demon's Souls straight out of Tales of Symphonia and loved it. So I can't judge what you might be into unless you try it!

Elden Ring does a lot right in the genre. It's the perfect blend of world exploration and anoul grape... When you fight a lot of things you're over levelled for, you won't know... you'll just think you're the bees knees, so you enter a new area and think "hah! What are you? Bird bird!? Come here and I'll teach you the meaning of pain!" only to get mushed into pulp by its ginormous beak. Then you'll get wiser, and come at it from a different approach. More careful. More dodgy, more gud... and win! Maybe. Or you get pummeled again and then realize... maybe you aren't supposed to be here yet? You'll never know. The game gives you a lot of freedom right out the gates, especially with mods like Convergence. 
Apart from the open world that keeps you guessing on what progression path you were supposed to take it has the classic Dark Souls feel.
By that I mean NPC quests that are anything but linear, to the point of being ridiculous(seriously, just follow a guide, there's no shame in it), bosses that you need to rethink over and over again before you can get the hang of them, and zones with dangers that have you looking over your inventory desperately trying to find what resists scarlet rot or fire.
At the end of the day, I find myself coming back for more. Am I a masochist? No, I've modded the game before to be easy for me and just enjoyed it as an easy RPG. On the other hand, I am a masochist to the point that I also like playing the original experience or even a tougher one. I've also modded the game before to be one shots. Players and NPCs all one shot... So I dunno. It's definitely an experience worth having if you're a fan of action RPGs, calculating boss moves and creating builds that will overcome certain challenges and adapting builds for different situations, then yes, you'll probably love Elden Ring, and I can recommend it. If you want a story, and are a fan of having the plot told to you carefully through character archs and story chapters that are linear and make sense... then no. You won't find a lot to keep you invested here.
Thank you for reading and I hope you found this review helpful.

I am very torn between recommending or not recommending this game and I decide against it, because there are enough people who point out in detail, why this game deserves much praise.
Elden Ring is a beautiful game and propably one of the bests ever made.
It is a classic soulslike experience and has incredible detail and much to explore and many things to try.
But that is sadly the thing I am tired of.
It is not Elden Ring in particular, but more the point I realise I am tired of its key features. Mainly the combat.
This started propably with dark souls 2, continued in 3 and Elden Ring is the line where I realize my hatred of said tiredness, that is ruining my experience.
After many raging fits, broken controllers and deleting the games and coming back to it over and over and over again it feels just unhealthy to keep playing. And why should I, if it feels like a waste of time to me? I rather keep the fond memories of the fresh experience of the first game then replacing it with new stressed out ones.
I love the games from From Software, they are one of the best game publishers on the market.
I absolutly recommend the game, but if you realize there is some truth to my points for you, I rather do not recommend buying it.

Elden Ring is one of the best games I have ever played.

First of all, I would like to mention the music on the start screen: Before starting the game, I had to enjoy this masterpiece first. Every time I started the game, I loved listening to it. It is so beautiful. And best of all, the entire soundtrack is a masterpiece. A few pieces of music simply won me over so much, they are very catchy tunes.  

I also really liked the character creation. My character is smiling :)

When I saw Limgrave for the very first time, I was immediately captivated. The entire game world is simply beautiful and I sometimes just stopped to look at the graphic details. The effects and the lights, the sky, everything is a work of art.
This game world is so huge, you discover something new every time and I was always pleasantly surprised.

The gameplay and the role-playing aspects are stunning. It's just incredible fun, you definitely need a lot of patience and you shouldn't get frustrated too quickly. Just enjoy the game and see how you get better and better. Here you definitely need to find out how you survive first (in terms of stat distribution), then you'll enjoy the rest of the game as much as I did.

In this game you have to find out a lot for yourself. Also when it comes to the story elements.
That makes exploring twice as exciting.

I played through the game solo and only found out later on how to help others in co-op, which is incredibly fun. You meet all sorts of different people and everyone is generally very nice. The emote function is also very cool.
I personally haven't experienced much PvP yet, but I'm going to get into that too. 

All in all, I recommend this work of art. Get into it and you will enjoy many, many great hours of play.
Thanks to my friend for believing in me; that I could do it while others said: "You can't do it anyway."
Now I've finished it before them.
This game has a very high emotional value. I'm looking forward to the DLC.

I hold Elden Ring in extremely high regard. It's in a tier of it's own alongside masterpieces like Red Dead Redemption 2, The Last of Us 1 and The Witcher 3.

It is worth noting that Elden Ring is probably Hidetaka Miyazaki's most accessible and friendly game to newcomers in his series of "Souls Games". Where as others in the series put you up against bosses in a more linear fashion, Elden Ring allows you to explore freely and go level up somewhere else to eventually come back and progress past the boss that kicked your ass before.

The quality and care that went into the level design, art style and animations is so good that it puts other games to shame. If Call of Duty is the McDonald's of gaming, then Elden Ring is a 5 star Michelin restaurant where you want to savor every bite.

It's a game that solidifies that videogames are indeed art.

The Hype for the game is completely justified, what an experience. The best part of the game is it's unforgiving at every moment but you're given the opportunity to read all the movesets and try to defeat the bosses. So everytime you die you not only die with frustration but also die knowing something new to deal with the boss and you really get the best kind of dopamine each time you defeat these bosses. You're also given the freedom to fight however the hell you want. Every main boss is uniquely designed with their own set of brutal but awesome move sets. The larger enemies are kind of tedious to fight, they look awesome, the setpieces are visually gorgeous but most of the time they're not as fun as the other enemies who are more challenging and at the same time more fun. Also I really wish the game had a feature where you could replay all these bosses without entering someone else's world. Story wise, I did feel disconnected throughout but I don't think it even matters all that much since it more than makes up for it with the gameplay. Another problem I had with the game is how locked away most of the main bosses are, the game really wants to explore every nook and cranny of its extremely vast open world but it's really hard to look for most of the bosses without an YouTube video guiding you. The exploration aspect is definitely cool but I find myself craving more to fight the bosses the game has to offer. Getting to Malenia was more frustrating than the boss fight itself. It's kinda understandable the developers design the game in a way to get the online community to interact and come up with all the solution to the most bizzare puzzles they've set, but personally I would have preferred it to be easily accessible. If this is the best game of FromSoftware when it comes to accessibility then I really don't know how I'd fair out in their other games. The game doesn't look next gen or anything but it's got one of the best art style you can ever find in a game. The performance was stuttery and it would actually get worse if I lower the settings, the only work around with the performance is playing the game offline. Playing it offline kinda stabilised the performance. Also the final fight had one of the best bosses and at the same time one of the game's worst. I would have really enjoyed the final fight if Radagon had a second phase or something, elden beast was absolutely abhorrent of a boss, the most annoying part of the game for me. With all that said, we will be there no matter what for the DLC as well as NG+.

Finally beat the game, here's the verdict. I've played and beaten every other "Souls" game published by Fromsoft, so I think I have the authority to say that this one is good, but not perfect.

This game really is an open world Dark Souls 2 and it shows. DS3 is a more polished experience, DS2 has a lot more meme potential and soul, BB has better art direction, and it will never be as nostalgic in 12 years as Dark Souls is now.

That being said, it is not a bad game. It's a lot of fun until you beat [spoiler]Morgott for the final time.[/spoiler]. Everything after that point feels like a bloody chore. And it sucks, because the last few bosses are a lot of fun, but by the time you get to them, you're so tired of the game that they aren't enjoyable. 

The bosses in this game are also not *nearly* as hard as the community would make you believe. I beat  [spoiler]Malenia[/spoiler] on the third try, and [spoiler]Godfrey, Radagon and Elden Beast[/spoiler] on the first try. *Orphan of Kos* and *Isshin, The Sword Saint* these are not. 

This lack of difficulty comes down to simply being able to roll through things you really shouldn't be able to. You can simply roll through a lot of AOEs that look like you need to jump over or run away from. Sadly there isn't much of an indication as to whether you need to roll through them or around them, you just have to feel it out and get your timing down right. Once you have it, they really aren't that bad. The downside is, all bosses do a lot of damage that will result in you getting killed very quickly unless you level Vigor all the way to 60 or higher, and even then you're still taking a lot of damage. 

I would change a lot about this game if I could, but thankfully that's where mods come in. Seamless Coop makes playing with your friends much more enjoyable and easy, and you won't have to deal with invaders or hackers. If you like invading... I would stick to Dark Souls 3, as sad as that sounds. Even with all the BS in Dark Souls 3, it's much better optimized for PVP than this game is. 

TLDR: It's worth a buy, but I'd wait for a sale unless you really want it. The game is too long but if you don't mind 50-100 hours per character to get to the end, go for it. May Chaos Take The World.

pretty disappointed with this game.  The combat is just too slow and clunky and not enjoyable for me.  
The way they try to make the game difficult is by making all enemies 10x faster in combat than you, while you very slowly try to dodge insanely fast multi-attacks, and if you don't dodge them perfectly, you're stunned and killed.  I can't stand how slow roll/dodge are.  
This game could have been so much better with fluid combat that takes more skill than trying to perfectly roll dodge constantly.  Ruined the game for me.

It's hard but fair. If you cheese to win, then it still counts as a win. If you get hard stuck, go somewhere else and come back later. The biggest enemy to every new player I know is gravity. Such fun. Would recommend.

I tend to not like souls games.  After 90hrs in Elden Ring, I'm still not sure that I care for this type of game.  That doesn't change my opinion that this is one of the most impressive games I've ever played.  The art direction and passive world building are incredible, and I continue to play this game in spite of the fact that I really dislike a lot of the systems in the game.  Thankfully, this game, for the most part, allows you to avoid a lot of the frustrating systems and interface by enabling you opportunities to out-level the portion of the game that you might be struggling to progress through.

I don't know that I'll have the patience to ever complete this game.  What I do know is that I do believe that this is one of the best games ever made.  It's tedious, clumsy, needlessly punishing, and it can feel repetitive, but the game is fair and beautifully presented.

I can say that this game is good, however I am kind disappointed with Fromsoftware's negligence . First of all, let's just get over the first thing you going to see, the graphics/performance: Overall, the graphics are decent, nothing to brag about, however the performance is a little bit questionable, sometimes the game freezes, other times it just stutters for no reason, it is undeniable that this game struggles with fps for a not so amazing graphics. This game crashes more than it should, for example, in my entire experience playing souls like, none of them crashed on me but ER.
Second,gameplay. The level design,well, it's hard to judge,most of the time the levels are good-ish, but sometimes I can read the developer mind: " how can I make this level the most unbearable experience as possible?........EUREKA! Why not just CTRL-C, CTRL-V the most annoying and attack spamming enemy?". The boss experience is the worse in my opinion, looking wise they are very good, however their animations/move set are not enjoyable. (I don't thing this game has the most amount of bad bosses however a think it has the worse ones). The most stupid difficult bosses they all spam a 10 hit combo sometimes with magick, they have hit kill attacks that punishes you for not dodging that single attack, did I ever mentioned that they explode a lot? Or they just gank you to death. My point is, they're are very good quality however they are so unfair to a point you wish to never fight them ever again, and just skip them whenever you come face to face with them again. It's not a fun fight anymore like the older titles, it's just a burden really.
They took everything from dark souls 3, cranked up the boss speed and damage, decreased the Iframes window from the player and just kept the same speed for using the healing. Dark souls 3 difficulty config was good enough. I don't understand why Fromsoftware's games have to be so hard to a point that I literally just get annoying when you replay the game , dark souls 1 wasn't that difficult back in the day. I hate the "GET GUD" culture,it just makes these games unbearably difficult for no reason, I've already "GOT GUD", and it seems the game just gets worse every run.
Oh yeah before I forget, they have put a incredible feature in the game which allows you to respawn at a checkpoint without having to go back to the bonfire,if only they put them in the right places.
PS: For some weird reason Fromsoftware thinks that fixing some glitches that skips some bad bosses or boring puzzles which makes the game more dynamic and only affects MY EXPERIENCE ALONE is more important than fixing performance issues and  bugs that really cripples the gameplay experience, like clipping through the floor after a game crash and losing all the runes I got or just not being able to finish a questline for no reason.

Looking at my time played whoever's reading this can already tell what direction I am going in. Elden RIng is quite literally my favorite video game of all time. It has substantially altered my brain chemistry and has me wrapped around its finger. It's gameplay, lore, and sense of immersion are so addictive to me that no matter what I literally cannot be pulled away from it. It's probably a sign of mental illness but hey, the DSM5 has classified gaming addiction as a disorder so it's less of a probably and more of a definitely. 
           Speaking of gaming addiction, the gameplay is like crack for the brain. It is so fluid and while simple to learn it is without a doubt hard to master. As a spiritual successor to the Dark Souls trilogy, it is to be assumed that it is hard. While my recent run through DS3 was significantly more challenging than my first time through Elden Ring it definitely was no slouch. It beat my ass first time around, Malenia took a whole week of on and off play to defeat. But that is what is so genuinely wonderful about the Soulsborne franchise. Once I beat Malenia I felt a rush of adrenaline and it felt like I had run a marathon (hyperbole, I have a life and do shower). All the bosses gave me that sense of achievement, its the best part of the game. You feel like you're in a dance, going through the motions with expertise and proficiency. I love the combat of this game and if every other game had this level of gameplay I would probably never get off my PC.
          Honestly however, its not the gameplay that had me wholly hooked, it was the god damn lore. Vaatividya is probably my most watched channel of all time just due to how hooked I am on the lore of this game. Fromsoft and George RR Martin have created a mastercraft story, every boss and enemy feel like they could have a whole essay written on them. Every item feels like it has this major impact and even the smallest details send me on a rabbit hole of speculation. There's this overwhelming sense of tragedy with the  demigod characters you see in game. From Morgott's blind alliegance to the Erdtree in spite of its system oppressing him from birth, to Radahn being a shell of his former self with his men holding a festival in his honor so he may die an honorable death. Every character feels like if the cards were just handed to them a little better things could be different which is why their stories feel so cosmically tragic. With how phenomenal the story is for the base game, I can only imagine what twists and turns the upcoming Shadow of the Erdtree DLC has in store. 
          The deeply entrancing lore mixes like butter with the fluid and masterful gameplay to create a sense of immersion I have never felt for a piece of media. Every time I boot up the game I feel as though I am being transported to another world running on a completely different set of logic. I feel as though I am the tarnished and it is my duty to mend the shattered Elden Ring. It is just such an enveloping world and I don't think I will ever experience something like it.
           In conclusion, please for the love of god buy and play Elden Ring. I am literally a different person after playing it and I cannot recommend it any more.

My opinion has changed somewhat. This game is fun. The gameplay is enjoyable. It's the most accessible and lowest-barrier-to-entry Souls-esque game I've played, but I think that is a downside. You'll probably like this game if you aren't looking to play Dark Souls. I was told to expect this game to be most similar to Dark Souls 2. It is not. It is an entirely different kind of game that I happen to also enjoy, but it does not strike me like a Souls game. It's just entirely different. But I do like it except for the lore that just doesn't hit as good as the Souls series.

I think you'll like this game if you're expecting a more chill relaxing Breath of the Wild-esque experience.
I think you won't like it if you're expecting Dark Souls.

Here is my original review for reference:

-------

"The game is simply not fun. It's lost the identity of earlier FromSoftware Soulslikes. It's easy, the setting is generic and uninspired, and the writing leaves very little to the imagination compared to the Souls series.

The world is bland. There's nowhere that looks particularly interesting to travel to. It's all one note-- beautiful green fields accented by masonry in various states of disrepair. Comparing the huge vista you get as you step into Limgrave to the view you get when you step into Majula (DS2) was gutting. The opening cinematic was run-of-the-mill fantasy worlbuilding. There's a map, a jump button, a mount, sneaking, gathering, crafting. There's nothing with any soul (pun intentional & pertinent) in Elden Ring. Before I even fought a single enemy in Limgrave, I was attacking random wildlife out of sheer disinterest, both in what I'd seen so far, and in what laid before me.

If I hadn't unintentionally left my game running while I got called away from my PC, I would have refunded Elden Ring near immediately. Truly disappointing.

Edit: Steam is unable to refund me for this game-- understandably so, since I was past the 2h refund window-- so I'm gonna play it more and see if my opinion changes. I'll change my review if my opinion improves."

-------

I have played a bit more of Elden Ring. The game IS enjoyable, but it is not Dark Souls 4. The gameplay is fun, but faster-paced than previous FromSoftware Souls games (which I do not prefer). 

I think many mainstream game mechanics (Rideable horse, crafting, standalone jump button, world map, and more) just feel out of place in this kind of game. I am enjoying them-- except the horse, which I am avoiding using for my own enjoyment-- in Elden Ring as long as I stop trying to consider it to be similar to the Dark Souls series. But, imo, I shouldn't have to accommodate a FromSoftware Soulslike not feeling like a FromSoftware Soulslike to enjoy its thematically confused mechanics.

The difficulty is actually there... sometimes. The way the game starts is dreadfully easy. But there are very challenging bosses and even ordinary enemies can be difficult.

The main thing I feel 100% as negatively about as I did in my first iteration of this review is the writing. The world is not gripping in the same way the Souls series is. the Souls series (plus Bloodborne, even) has this nightmarish quality to its storytelling that I am just not seeing in Elden Ring, and that disappoints me. I love the nightmarish mystery of FromSoftware Soulslikes, and I think it is a massive downgrade that Elden Ring is veering so hard toward normal fantasy.

Overall:
- The game starts pitifully. It gets more fun after a few hours and you meet a few NPCs and die to some bosses. I remind you, I tried to return this game because the start was so uninteresting.

- The writing, the lore, and the world, are all much more bland, uninteresting,  fantasy than other FromSoftware games; the George R. R. Martin influence really shows. I consider the world the strongest feature of the Souls series, and here it is the weakest feature of Elden Ring. This is very disappointing for me.

- The game is fun to play in a sense. I am invested in my progressing my character, and in seeing what's up with Melina and Ranni-- I do love them as characters. Wandering around and chilling and exploring while paying attention to a YouTube video or TV show is enjoyable, but any engagement with the lore and writing and worldbuilding of the game is just so uninteresting. In this way and many others, Elden Ring feels to me like the soul of the Souls series is leaving its niche narratively and in terms of the gameplay loop, but holding on to the way it feels to control your character. This has its ups and downs for me. Mostly downs.

If you're a fan of Dark Souls, and consider Dark Souls 2 level and enemy design/placement to be some of the worst game design of all time, I have to implore you to pass on this game. There are four great bosses, two decent ones, and a bunch of Dark Souls 2 bosses.

To further explain: There are "sci-fi turret" style auto-tracking overheads aplenty from many bosses. There are many enemies and bosses who fully invalidate a damage type or playstyle, which in my opinion are both major fouls, considering the scarcity of resources and time to prepare a secondary damage type(a weapon or spells) and playstyle surrounding it. The metagame is a holdover from previous Souls titles, as Fromsoftware opted not to innovate upon their previous and various equipment upgrade schemes.

The least entertaining aspect of boss fights compared to past games, especially Bloodborne, is that position advantages do not last long, or are arbitrarily defeated by a sequence of attacks that explicitly requires you to perform exactly the same strat everyone else uses. This actually makes the gameplay feel stale on the PvE side, and I do not glean enjoyment from joining in on boss fights as most can just be stagger-locked into oblivion with minimal setup/effort.

Since the release of Prepare to Die Edition on Steam, there have been countless mods addressing a variety of valid and arguable flaws in Fromsoftware's implementation of upgrade materials and progression gating in that regard. Of course there is a balance to be struck as overpowering your weapons against the enemies in a level is a bit too cheesy for the fairly hardcore, elitist community. 

Fromsoftware either never checked them out, or felt confident players would enjoy spending hours farming just to enjoy a different weapon and ditch the one they were using for about a hundred hours, considering they put over 500 equippable weapons and high-quality movesets into the game. It is for this reason I consider this game an L.

The endings are very disappointing for the effort required to unlock the majority of them. They swap one line of dialogue at the end. Then you're back to the start, with little reason to do the majority of side content if already completed, leaving long jogs to bosses you wind up steamrolling due to weak NG+ scaling. Another big L and regression from past titles.

I had played a lot of video games in my time, but never anything by FromSoftware before this. I spent about 8 hours in the game, hit a brick wall with Margit, and put it down in frustration. But I couldn't leave it alone. I came back to it after a little while with a more patient and determined attitude, and now have completed the game 14 times from New Game with all kinds of different builds, own it on two different platform, and have now moved on to Bloodborne and Sekiro. I'm 41 years old, and this is one of my top 3 favourite games of all time. An absolute joy.

Skyrim on Steroids

What an absolute masterpieceâ€¦ I am 120 hours in, "finished" the game, and there is still a lot of things left to see and do. 
It's truly amazing, From Software is the giga-chad of developers, almost making a mockery of western studios with the amount and quality of content on offer here.

Difficulty
I always liked from software games but I could never finish one. I know, git gud, etc. This is the first one I finished and I'm super proud of it. I see a lot of people crying in the forums that this game was easy. I don't disagree, it definitely felt easier then their previous titles. It was definitely easier than Lies of P, which I finished by some miracle. But to me this was the perfect difficulty level. It hit a sweet spot that it wasn't so off putting and I was actually motivated to finish it. I don't think it was a worse game because of this. On the contrary. They made a lot of improvements that just removed pointless punishment, like 10 minute boss walks. And you can always explore new areas if you are stuck on a boss.

 I killed pretty much all bosses in under 15 tries. Sometimes I explored some new areas and came back if they didn't take much damage.  
I did explore the game very thoroughly, so I was very high level in the end game (~150). But it's not like I "farmed" XP, I enjoyed every second of exploring the world, and it naturally leveled my character up. I did play a half knight half mage character, so that probably helped, strength builds seem more difficult. If you want to run through the bosses only, you might have a harder time, but why would you want to miss out on all that great side content?

Visuals and design
The art in this game is jaw dropping. There is a monumental vista on every single corner. It just doesn't let up, area after area. You think you are in the end game five times at least, and there are still more gorgeous places to explore, things to do.
The level design is also on point, it was a joy to explore. There are all sorts of secret routes to discover. And you are absolutely 100% free to go anywhere and play the game in any order you want.

Gameplay
The activities in the open world are not overcomplicated, thank god! This is where I feel like they distinguished their game the most from other open world games. They didn't feel the need to bombard you with some BS filler content on every corner. The world that they built is there for you to explore, but it doesn't cater to you. There is risk and reward everywhere, so the exploration always feels exciting, but sometimes you just ride your horse and take in the views. And there is nothing wrong with that. Less is more ubisoft.

The combat is great as usual and you can do it from horseback too in the open. Once you find your playstyle and build you can really get into the zone as you plow through the areas. There is probably a million builds you can try and replay the game forever.

As typical fromsoft, the game is very cryptic and don't hold your hand when it comes to game mechanics. This is fine for most aspects, but it didn't work for me  when it came to the side quests. It's basically impossible to figure out the side quests without looking them up online. The characters say some cryptic stuff, then disappear, then you bump into them in a random cave by  chance 30 yours later to continue their quest. If you are a completionist like me this doesnâ€™t feel great.

Overall, I didn't want this game to ever end. What they achieved with this game is astonishing, especially the amount of content and art they were able to cram into it, and none if it felt like filler, it's unprecedented. They really schooled everyone how open world is done, and I hope devs are making notes. 
It is a time commitment for sure, but if you have the time to invest, there is nothing better out there.

This game is very challenging but also very rewarding once you beat that boss, or finally learn how to parry+riposte those pesky crucible knights.

The game doesn't really explain much of what to do or how things work, so you can either go exploring and figure it out on your own or use some online guides. The game is very large and has plenty of depths and variety for choices of weapons, skills and builds. After almost 80h playtime, I feel like I finally understand most aspects of the game.

I played the first 70h with mouse+keyboard, but finally did the switch to Xbox controller. Not going back. The game is clearly designed for console and even when playing on PC it makes sense to use a controller.

There are plenty of beginner guides out there so I won't give details on what to learn; just try it, die a hundred times, explore new areas, level up, die some more and get on your journey to retrieve all the lost shards of the Elden Ring.

This game does not test your skill, it tests your patience.

Every input is delayed and takes half a second to do, all NCP's have attack patterns that will hold off on doing their 1 hit move until they are just about to die so that you did all that damage, just to die when they are 1 hit away from death. They will also spam you with quick moves to pick at your health slowly, giving you no window to attack.

I was so excited for this game to go on sale, I waited, and hyped it up for 8 months, just for it to be a blatant rage game at a time where I'm doing my best mentally. Hard pass.

Edit - A year after this review, I gave the game another try. My thoughts have changed, although what I was complaining about is still an issue, just not in the way I assumed it was based off my short playtime.

I would like to extend on my complaints on the game and say that the enemies don't spam moves, they just have long combos that YOU MUST RESPECT because you cant stagger them out of the animation, and sometimes youll stagger them out the animation, and theyll skip the stagger animation, or cut it short just to hit you.......

There are countless videos on youtube explaining why the enemies moves in this game are far too punishing and the amount of fake windows there are in these interactions, so I don't need any kind of reassurance from anyone in this community that what I'm saying is true, just look it up for yourself.

80% of the content is at the very start of the game. The remaining 20% is dragged out through the remaining of the game with repeats, reskins, and reused assets.

I personally only find this game playable with mods. Lets not talk about how a game that came out in 2022 is limited to 60fps...... 

Overall, The game redeemed itself from my first time trying it, although all I did was force myself to play through it, to fully understand what exactly is wrong with the game. 

I am aware that there is no such thing as a perfect game, but there IS such thing as stupid game designs, and the fromsoft hardcore fans to understand that not everything in the game needs to be defended with "its a souls game" because they have changed TONS of things in the game after release which shows that none of this is as simple as "git gud" because even they are changing things after the fact...

Btw where is the dlc? this game is 2 years old... It LITERALLY should be out by now but for some reason, the gaming industry has regulated unfinished products and we all have gotten so use to it, we are still sitting here waiting for dlc for a game that released 2 entire years ago.

Elden Ring, Is a really nice introduction to Souls like games if you have not played one yet. 

This game does not hold your hand, but it has a beautiful world to explore and great challenges to overcome. If you are looking to get into the souls series, I highly recommend this game to you all. If you are  souls veteran and want a challenge then come on inside and put the difficulty on high! The game is great! 

Graphics  - Beautifully well done and captures a fantasy world unlike any other!
Music       - The Music in this game is very...ambient? It's nothing that overloads the senses, but when travelling the world, the subtle background music fits each environment well enough, the combat music is nice as well and it matches the tempo of what you're doing. 
Gameplay - The combat can be challenging, but without practice you can overcome it! I played this game mostly on the Xbox and recently got it for PC , have to say PC is the way to go, especially with mods =D. 

Overall I highly recommend this to all of you, get it while its on sale, get it brand new, either way, you will enjoy it. 

GG hope you enjoy it!

I rate the game 10 out of 11

An absolute masterpiece and a giant of a game with a few faults. The camera and targeting can be iffy. Some rediculous spammy bosses toward the end coupled with a few empty feeling zones. A few obscure and hard to find questlines. The incomplete and fragmented dialogue of NPC's can leave you feeling lost or vaguely stranded or not sure what they mean or where to go next. I missed a crucial questline that I wanted to do and was actively looking for. I played 100% blind until I beat the entire game, so this was an especially rewarding but also daunting. The game is dreamlike and it's broken yet hand-crafted nature is part of the experience, but also in the scope and presentation of the landscape and architecture. The exploration, art, and atmosphere created by the team carried the project and create an unforgettable experience if you don't spoil it.

I recommend playing this game blind, or with VERY little info/spoilers.
its really good, and tons of content.
slapped a boss around with 2 greatswords

Boss's that glitch a few terrible hitboxes and enemies with 20+ attack chain are almost as hard as the fight with your camera. true to fromsoft form, once again after x amount of years, still cannot grasp how to make their camera work nor have they even heard of camera distance. when half of your boss/miniboss's are massive, it becomes agonizing torture to even attempt them because half the time you want to lock on, the camera is in the ground. fromsoft lock-on will always be a massive L, as is apparent with all their previous games. theres no way a company with the assets it has still cannot design a camera that doesnt give every enemy you come across a massive handicap. Unfortunately you will have to use this terrible lock-on to use almost any form of range (Spell and Ash of wars) IF, and thats a BIG if, your camera doesnt break lock for some mysterious reason. 

In short, the camera is the true boss of this game

Edit: 4th graders could probably make a better camera/lock on system in scratch. Fromsoft should be absolutely ashamed of themselves for allowing such an atrocious and detrimental thing to even be programmed into a triple A title. its painfully obvious that fromsoft thinks that adding new and innovative game mechanics will somehow hide the fact that they STILL have not fixed many of their issues (even the most basic ones) since darksouls and show no signs of effort or willingness to fix the things that NEED to be fixed. the camera turning, lock-on, and spell tracking during horse combat seem to be made by people who have never even heard of the words "video game". its so inconvenient that, what would otherwise be a near flawless experience, is overshadowed by fromsofts basic programming issues (caused the kindergartners they still continue to employ) that are still persisting from earlier souls boring games. its such a shame to see this amount of low effortness and what seems like shameless corner cutting is still a part of the souls boring series and that the atrocious camera and camera settings havent been rectified by someone on their team whos ACTUALLY PLAYED the game after 2 whole years.

Once again fromsoft paves the way on what NOT to do with your video game and continues to ignore polish that SHOULD NOT be ignored creating an infuriating gauntlet of inconvenience and constant feeling of being baffled by confusing and just straight up terrible game design that the devs seem to deem a non issue. Fromsoft consistently proves that they dont know how to program basic game mechanics and that they dont know how to fix them either.

I'm gonna be completely honest, the first 40-50 hours of the game (basically, everything before reaching the mid/late-game) are absolutely fantastic. The main star being the unmatched exploration that the game offers, with minor nit-picks with weapons and bosses. But then, the overall quality of the game starts to just rot. The enemies become repetitive, the areas are huge but poorly populated, and the bosses start hitting like a fucking truck (even with 50 or more vigor) while sometimes being outright unfair. And to top if all off, the final stretch of the game (at least to me) feels like draining a boss rush paired with little to no exploration. In the end, I still believe the game is "good" and thoroughly recommend it, but it's nowhere near the flawless masterpiece everyone is talking about.

elden ring is elden mid
itâ€™s not a flawed masterpiece or a rough diamond or whatever else the meme 2 hour video essays tell you, itâ€™s just mid
DISCLAIMER: this is my second time playing this game, don't mind the hours, the first time i was doing the hand hook and eyepatch build

>open world
probably the best aspect of this game by far, you just can never get tired of exploring the lands between
one complaint about the open world i often hear is that you often find yourself just traveling way too much from point a to point b, but i donâ€™t see this as a negative, since the gameâ€™s beauty alone is enough to keep your attention 
legacy dungeons are also good but thatâ€™s been said a million times already 
however, even this kind of open world is not without flaws

>copy paste
why does this game have 5 or so dungeon types?
no, i donâ€™t want to explore yet another cave or a mine or some lazily copy pasted catacombs (sometimes with a chariot), but sometimes you have to, to get the smithing stones or that talisman you want
but itâ€™s not just the dungeons that get copy pasted, bosses and enemies do too
can you imagine my disappointment when i got to the mountaintops of giants and was like "holy, this area is so beautiful, i wonder what kind of enemies i'll be fighting in here"
can you imagine my face when i saw the caelid dogs, the caelid birds, the stormveil birds, the demi-humans, the bats, the marionettes, the hands, and the vulgar militiamen
a-at least zamor dudes became a normal enemy instead of a m-mini-boss, so it's at least ONE unique enemy tied to this area, r-right?
miyazaki, my brother in Christ, I HAVE BEEN FIGHTING THESE ANNOYING BIRDS AND BATS AND DOGS THROUGHOUT THE WHOLE GAME, Iâ€™VE KILLED SO MANY OF THE DEFAULT SWORD/SPEAR SOLDIERS, CAN YOU PLEASE ADD MORE ENEMIES INTO THE GAME
NO, YOU CANâ€™T JUST PASTE OLD ENEMIES FROM OLD GAMES, YOU DID THAT TWICE IN ELDEN RING ALREADY WITH ASYLUM DEMON AND CAPRA DEMON
i am especially sick of the copy pasted dragons, erdtree avatars are at least fun to fight
ROT DRAGON, ICE DRAGON, NORMAL DRAGON, MAGIC DRAGON, MAGIC DRAGON 2
ALL OF THEM HAVE THE SAME MOVESET
this is a triple a game, just to remind you
edit: there is way more copy paste from previous titles as it turns out, just today i found out about red wolf of radagon having the same animations as sif and the death blight frogs

>combat
this is where things get bad, such outdated souls-tier combat where it feels like youâ€™re handling a bus instead of a human SHOULD NOT EXIST with such fast bosses that feel like they come straight out of sekiro
either make the player faster and give him more movement options, or make the bosses slower
it is infuriating having to dodge 5-10 boss attacks only to get ONE hit in and then repeat the cycle
torrent is awful to control, and it feels like he's not listening to half my commands
wow, it's just like a real horse!
the decision to make your stamina tied to torrent's is also bizarre and unexplainable
also, input buffering is more often than not the result of your characterâ€™s demise, as it's been countless times that this trash read my ash of war as ash of war + left handed attack after it and i died so many times because of this
before fromdrones shout â€œskill issueâ€, i am literally putting my hands off the keyboard after doing the ash of war and my character still does the normal attack after it
but, despite that, my character drinks only 1 flask half the time despite me mashing the heal button
i often miss the opportunity to reposte thanks to INPUT BUFFERING, so why not let the player know when the boss stagger is coming up?
you're gonna make a posture break mechanic without implementing at least some kind of sign?
i swear to Christ miyazaki has never played his own games
also, why do the enemies' arrows home in on you, yet the player's arrows don't home in on enemies?
do the enemies have special magnet arrows or something?
can some lore expert tell me how this is explained in the story?

>bosses
and these bosses, oh God, these bosses
delayed attacks, input reads (these are especially â€œfunâ€ if youâ€™re doing any run that involves projectiles), blatant destruction of established game mechanics, they got everything you donâ€™t want in an action rpg
and i can't stress enough how awful the input reads are, the best bosses for showcasing such nonsense are margit for his combo extender that he won't do unless you attack and the godskins who shoot black flames at you IMMEDIATELY upon pressing the heal button
someone needs to teach miyazaki that's not how reaction time works
but, being completely honest, i had fun fighting malenia
sure, she is actually one to break established mechanics
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R9Vbsr3Ko7M
but at least that boss has a unique feel and dynamic to it, akin to an old samurai standoff, where the two warriors exchange blows and then fall back to circle around each other
her attacks are more or less intuitive, and she does have a flexible moveset thatâ€™s fun to play around with on your part
EXCEPT FOR WATERFOWL DANCE AND VAMPIRISM, WHOEVER DESIGNED THOSE INTO MALENIA NEEDS TO GET FIRED FROM THEIR JOB ASAP, AND UNLESS YOUâ€™VE NOT DONE SOMETHING AS ELEMENTARY AS BEATING MALENIA WITH A +20 CAESTUS, NO SUMMONS, NO SLEEP POTS, NO BLEED, NO FROST, YOUR OPINION DOES NOT COUNT
also, elden beast is the worst final boss in any video game ever, radagon was such a good conclusion to this mediocre, but still charming game, but nope, my face gets smeared with the broken unfun mess that is elden beast
he's constantly running away, he's not at all dynamic like radagon, and he even looks like crap
come on, who wants to fight a giant space spaghetti as the final boss?
also, ulcerated tree spirit
just ulcerated tree spirit

>story
average fromsoft fan be like:
OH MY SCIENCE IS THAT LE HECKING MIYAZAKI TELLING THE LORE OF THE GAME THROUGH ITEM DESCRIPTIONS FOR THE 1488TH TIME??? HOLY GOSH OOOOOOOOOOO ELDEN RING
seriously though, the lore of this game is admittedly pretty interesting, but the narrative sucks
to give an example, in the beginning we are shown a literal powerpoint presentation about the world
okay, whatâ€™s the night of the black knives?
not gonna explain?
oh, okay
iâ€™m a tarnished?
i donâ€™t even understand what that means
what the hell is an elden ring?
and so on and so forth
stuff like this continues throughout the whole game because the narrative feels like a jumbled mess of in-universe terms and seemingly random events
on that note, quest design in this game is unintuitive as hell
to take varreâ€™s quest for instance, how the hell am i supposed to know that i need invade other players THREE times to advance his quest?
or patches, itâ€™s like heâ€™s teleporting around the map at random, he doesnâ€™t tell you where heâ€™s gonna go

>leveling
softcaps?
really?
at least tell the player when they get to them, so he doesnâ€™t have to google it
i suggest this is due to pvp or some crap like that, but pvp is a portion of the game, not the entirety of it and you donâ€™t balance stuff AROUND it
the smithing stone grind in this game is obnoxious because of what i described about the caves in the open world section
such game design is almost ubisoft-tier, and those are the items that actually get you through the game

>optimization
it is just bad
it is understandable why my fps are bad on medium settings, seeing distant lands is part of the charm of this game
but the crashes are inexcusable
i suspect it is due to the botched anti-cheat, since without steam this game didn't run half as bad

IN CONCLUSION
i really cannot recommend this game if you're into the ACTION part of the ACTION RPGs
it's a strong MAYBE if you're into the RPG part, but it's just simply so tiresome to even control your character
this game is just outdated, through and through, and i think we all know why it won goty
it is because there was nothing else better than elden ring
i mean, come on, you're gonna give it to god of soy?
miyazaki is a hack
an experience every studio should strive for

100/10 Is actually playable.

Edit: I have now put like 200 hours into this game previous review is flawed like this game.
The game is not polished even a little bit and I'm 99% certain they never play tested anything, most of the bosses are just reused and multiplied the the point that it feels like quantity over quality.

The bosses that are big bosses are put in tiny little areas so it's like fighting a dragon in skyrim in the jarls house, it clips into everything and is a pain in the ass and designed to be unfun, flying bosses break the lock on camera because it was not designed for this sorta tracking, half the time with bosses you are running towards them only for them to teleport to the other side of the map and you run over there, hit them once and then your outta stamina.
Every Boss in this game is the same too, they are fast,tough,strong,have a projectile and an AOE they all just kinda blend together and this isn't helped by the lackluster story and the fact that bosses are reused so frequently, its not impressive beating Morgott(?) when you do it 3 more times.

Dragons are poorly designed and reused way to much, you can disagree but your wrong.

Co-op Still needs work but nerfs are the obvious priory not getting the game to play, invasions are a bad feature and have always been a bad feature and there is still no way to turn them off, you don't have to deal with them in single player but you could manage that in older souls games by disabling online so this is like a band-aid on an open wound.

Invasions are also busted with completely broken pvp "builds" and people who can destroy your save files and considering Dark Souls 3 had that RCE exploit then I'd say go online at your own risk.

The latter half of the game is broken enemies you had no problem fighting before now have 4x health and deal 5x damage despite there being no difference in model (the stone imps are a prime example).

No quest log just means I have to use the wiki to keep track of what the fuck to do so that sucks.

Every problem with this game can be fixed easily but it won't be because then it wouldn't be Dark Souls and that's all this is open world Dark Souls complete with all the trash from the souls game splattering shit over what may have otherwise been a good game.

The open world isn't fun to explore, every dungeon is the same and the bosses are ethier too easy because you over levelled or too hard because your under levelled and/or they are busted, getting good in the game requires you to learn how to code so you can balance the enemies properly.

Despite all these complaints its still one of the better games I've played recently and I still plan to play it some more, but goddamn does it feel like a chore.

Colosseum update is a huge pain in the ass and just doesn't work as advertised in typical Dark Souls style

4.5/10 so close to perfection but everything Dark Souls bogs this game down to being just another Souls game, nothing groundbreaking, nothing special, nothing that people will be talking about (outside of the souls community) in a couple of months, just another basic Dark Souls game but you can jump in this one.

Edit 2: i have now put in another 200 hours and my review stands, looking forward to when the DLC drops (never will) and all the bosses are just like Maleina where they have 30 hit combos and regen health, or the blood god who just throws blood on the floor so you can't play anymore, don't forget the dog with the busted hit box who will backflip into invisible walls while literally throwing you through said walls.

The first chunk of this game is pretty good and even great, its the final chunk of the game where they just decided to make enemies hard for the sake of being hard and not for being a challenge, like yea its a challenge to 1v1 someone with x-ray and aimbot in CoD but its not exactly fair is it?

But hey its fromsoft so they get a pass basically, they can do no wrong what so ever so souls fans just keep eating shit and saying thank you.

1/10 the longer you play the more the cracks show, I'd say get it on sale but its a fromsoft game so lol enjoy your wait.

Elden Ring, the collaborative masterpiece between the visionary Hidetaka Miyazaki and renowned author George R.R. Martin, emerges as a pinnacle in video game storytelling, heralding a paradigm shift in narrative depth and player immersion. FromSoftware's distinctive dark fantasy converges with R.R. Martin's expertise in elaborate world-building, birthing a game world that pulsates with life, sprawls expansively, and harbors a wealth of captivating lore. The scrupulous attention to detail in Elden Ring's story constructs a tapestry that enthralls players, beckoning them into an expansive and enigmatic landscape laden with secrets.

What truly distinguishes Elden Ring is its narrative adaptability and the player's agency within the story. The game embraces a non-linear structure, enabling players to mold the narrative through their choices and actions. The interconnections of the world, reminiscent of Dark Souls, fosters a sense of authentic exploration and revelation, infusing every decision with tangible consequences. Martin's narrative finesse, coupled with Miyazaki's design philosophy, produces a storytelling experience that is simultaneously grandiose and intimate, catering to a broad spectrum of player preferences.

Beyond the enthralling narrative, Elden Ring shatters preconceived notions of game development with its breathtaking open-world design. The sheer magnitude of the game world seamlessly integrates diverse environments, intricate dungeons, and colossal boss battles. The meticulous design not only serves the narrative but also immerses players in a dynamic, living realm where every corner conceals a story. This level of artistry not only sets a new benchmark for the Soulsborne genre but also establishes a precedent for the entire gaming industry, showcasing the potential of storytelling and world design to ascend to unparalleled heights in the ever-evolving landscape of interactive entertainment.

As my first FromSoft game, it's a fantastic experience. Like their other games, it requires you to learn and triumph through trial and error with plenty of items, weapons, armor, and spells to help you out and find your favorite way to play. I've played a typical sword-and-board build, a faith-based incantation build, a quick dancer-like build, and a mage/wizard build and they all work and are fun to do.

The main problem I have is actually finding sidequest objectives and the characters themselves rarely give much or detailed direction. So don't at all be afraid to look up things on a wiki or look at a guide if you are unsure of where to go, though, there is fun in finding things randomly and taking it all as it comes.
It's really fun to play just like Dark Souls and any other game that is similar like it.

Loved lots of open world exploration games (Skyrim, Fallout, Witcher 3, Valheim), ARPGs, but had never tried a Souls-like game before.  I've done hundreds of hours in hardcore permadeath games like Diablo/Path of Exile and survival games so I thought difficult would be fine/fun.  

For me, the fact that you have to die to learn and then retry/avoid what you know is coming is NOT a style of game I want to play - it feels too similar to raiding in an MMORPG.  In Elden Ring, I saw one enemy in a room, but there was a hidden enemy just to the left that ambushes you as you enter.  Later in the same tiny dungeon, an enemy was hiding up on the edge of the wall.  

I think if at every death you had a chance to restart 30s ago, 60s ago, or 120s ago, I'd have given this game more playtime, but the long corpse run mechanic on top of respawning enemies and losing your corpse on a subsequent death was just more hassle than I want to deal with.
