Alright, I will start this review with all my respect and love to FromSoftware. I am really huge fan of SoulsBorne series, and I'm for sure not a hater. In this review i will talk purely about technical issues of Elden Ring.
Why in the bloody hell my game always causing stuttering with ANY actions???? Especially with that second Big Guy on the horse that every player faces in the first 10-15 minutes of the game. Every his attack animation causes my fps drop from 60 to 20. And my specs even stronger than recommended : Ryzen 7 1700, GTX 1080, 16 GGB RAM 3200Mhz, game installed on SSD NVME with read and write 520+ MB/s. My CPU and GPU usage not even close to 100%. I tried max and min graphics settings. 
For now, let's talk about gameplay and specially about NET CODE. Froms, how did you ducked it up? It works even worse than dark souls 3 release statement. Every (successful) summoning takes about a minute or two (my internet speed is 100 Mbps). But most of the time, when you already tried to summon a phantom every other try will fail and for some reason game gets stuck in that condition, you can't exit or chill at bonfire, only way I found is alt+F4 or death.
I am really disappointed in that poor technical release quality of that awesome game. This game should be in development at least a month more! For now i dont recommend Elden Ring to buy, but I really want to! Please FromSoftware, fix your game, and let people enjoy beauty of your passion!

Update: Looks like turning off EAC anti-cheat fixes the stutters. Downside is offline mode...

This is probably the best game of all time. i'll drop some of my thoughts about the multiplayer which is what i love the most about FromSoftware games.

Out of all the Soulsborne games FromSoftware made, Elden Ring has the best access to multiplayer due to the addition of Martyr Effigies and the ability to use them globally and the same applies to invasion items. (i wish the Martyr Effigies didn't get reset on NG+ though)

The invasion areas DON'T get reset on NG+ however to some players it effectively does due to the fact that if you die during an invasion, You drop your Runes wherever you died in that world which may be an area you still haven't reach again in NG+ so you can easily end up preferring not to invade at all due to the hassle of picking up Runes, The whole idea of dropping your Runes from death in another world is not a good one honestly.

Also multiplayer could still be improved by opening it to a max of 6 players instead, Which would significantly boost the PvP potential and the enjoyment of it.

This is the worst modern Fromsoft game I've played, and I've played DeS, DaS, DaS2 (and SotFS, played both), DaS3, and BB. Every one of those games held my attention once I got past the initial annoyance with the first one I tried (DaS). I have around 1200 hours across all 5 (6) of them. This game is [b]STRUGGLING[/b] to keep my attention and I'm barely a quarter of the way through as far as I can tell. I am almost ready to just throw in the towel and uninstall out of sheer apathy. Having to force myself to play a game is never a good sign.

[u]The Good[/u]:
- Looks good
- No performance issues in borderless fullscreen for me (surprising considering how widespread they are)
- Added mechanics are nice (jump attack, guard counter, etc.)

[u]The Bad[/u]:
- Nearly everything else

So what do I mean by that? Let's start with the combat. This is DaS3 but with 33% Bloodborne enemies and 33% Sekiro enemies. I know I say that having not played Sekiro, but I have watched several full playthroughs of Sekiro and I don't need more than that to see the similarities. The game is [i]begging[/i] for a quick dash and deflection to allow you to actually play aggressively and proactively instead of having to bait 2/3 enemies into exhausting their combo before moving in. This is especially apparent on bosses, who have way more combo potential than ever and fewer openings. Yeah, you can just bait the combos out and wait 30s for Margit to finish his hit string or whatever and punish but it's [b]not fun[/b]. Not after Bloodborne, not after Nioh, and I'm sure those who played Sekiro would say not after Sekiro. Let me engage with the combat defensively and reverse the enemy's aggression. They can do the same to me, so why can't I do it to them? "Oh but you can parry some-" You and I both know that gets nerfed later on and is somewhat build-reliant. For most people, what you end up doing is rolling and zoning for tens of seconds before doing a quick punish, then repeating for 3-5 minutes to get a boss kill. Boring.

How about exploration? Also boring. There's not much to find when killing enemies gives almost no runes (souls) and 95% of all loot is useless to you. The world has what I call the "Kenshi problem" where it's beautiful and the lore is great but it's basically non-interactive. You might as well be looking at it through a bulletproof glass window because you barely interact with it at all except to kill stuff. In fact it's worse in ER because there's no building or trading. Dungeons are samey, even the few I've played, and I've already seen boss reuse. Due to the upgrade system there's also zero incentive for me to experiment because all it will do is waste resources (runes that are a pain to grind and better used on leveling) and time. This cost also increases with time because, say, if you want to change over when you have a +15 weapon you need to grind a LOT more than if you changed when you had a +6. It's just backwards design in a game where you [i]will[/i] need to change tactics for certain encounters.

What was that about stats? Yeah, so, they matter but you gain them so slowly that it feels like you're slogging uphill constantly, and the game is balanced around you needing to level which makes this worse. In addition to getting hardly any runes from combat, you also need more than in any other souls game to level up, compounding the poor pacing. Also, unlike a game like Nioh 2, your stat allocations early on REALLY matter in this game and you need to pump VGR to avoid getting oneshot. For all the balking about skill from fanboys, a surprising amount of this game is havng the right stat layout. Ain't no skill gonna make a boss fight less awful if you've only got 10VGR short of perfecting it. Same thing with damage output, if you screw your stats even a little say goodbye to "quick" kill times. Even previous souls games weren't this bad about stats, ER is the most heavily build-biased of them by far.

The story also isn't drawing me in much. I get what it is, it's impossible to have not been spoiled on it by now if you cared at all, but even when I heard it initially it didn't impress me. Maybe I just don't like GRRM, but even S1-4 of GoT was watchable for me. This story is like someone reheated the corpse of every souls game since DaS, threw them in a blender, then added gold flakes on top and crossed out the word "souls" and replaced it with "runes". I just don't give a damn about "Vague Miyazaki Stereotype Character #2397" muttering incoherently in a modern knockoff of ye olde English. It was tired by the time DaS2 rolled around, it's practically a parody at this point if you've played the whole series.

[u]In Conclusion[/u]:
I just don't know man. Playing ER makes me want to go back to Nioh 2. This game really, really needs a better combat system (like Nioh 2), a smaller open world (because most of it is empty or pointless), and just better balancing of incentives and character building in general. All the issues with ER existed in previous games but their impact was limited or softened by the world design, enemy design, and better encounters. It really just feels like an awkward middle-step of a game, stuck between what it was (souls) and what it wants to be (something like BotW). I don't know if that's because the devs aren't competent enough to realize the mistakes or if it's because they want to appeal to the fans and got too much flak for Sekiro being different, maybe it's a combination, but it doesn't work. 

I even looked into mods and, while I think something like Reforged might be a lot closer to what I'd consider "good design" for this sort of game, I don't see much that addresses the core issues with enemy movesets. If anything, most make them worse in an attempt to be "hardcore" if they change them at all, missing the point entirely that without a full mechanical rebalance of player abilities the changes just amount to more tedium. It's not generally hard to stand 50ft away from an enemy to avoid their combo, roll their AoEs, then slap them once or twice. Anyone can do it. The issue is that it's not fun.

To make my point, let's consider Nioh 2 again. Every boss in Nioh 2 except maybe the few gimmick bosses like Gyuki and the giant statue guy are pretty much Margit-tier in terms of their combos and moveset. You [i]can[/i] fight them the same way you would in ER, by running away and punishing once or twice for minutes and minutes until they die, but Nioh 2 doesn't want you to do that. The bosses have stamina bars, you have a powerful guard no matter the weapon you use, you have a bazillion moves with different speeds and 3 stances with different kinds of dodges for repositioning and extra yokai abilities that can do anything from utility to punishment AND ki pulses so you can be more aggressive and get longer hits strings out and... etc. All of these are present regardless of build, builds just add even more onto it. The entire game is screaming "GET IN THERE, BE AGGRESSIVE, READ THE FLOW OF COMBAT AND TAKE CONTROL!". BB also had this to some extent with rallying and quick dodging and the general pace.

Meanwhile, ER's mechanics are saying "Wait, wait, wait, wait, not yet, not yet, not yet, okay now hit once! Now wait, wait..." It's different for mages of course, you can just blast away, but that's not really better. The enemy design and combat mechanics are at total odds with each other, and the end result is not fun. Same with the open world vs encounter design vs looting, same with the stats vs resource availability, and so on. At the end of the day, it's just not that good compared to what came before it and other games you can buy right now. Kinda wishing I just picked up AC6 instead.

Love this game! Absolutely worth the price, and it's a wonderful addition to FromSoft's library of games. You can combine the armor pieces seamlessly with each other in most cases (some of the metallic parts don't always match), you can make almost any build you can imagine and have it be viable to beat the game with, and the bosses are unique and varying in difficulty. The NPCs in this game are all so fun, and even when you don't like them you can appreciate that FromSoft put in such characters (Dung eater can go do what his namesake suggests).

The game -can- be frustrating, as any of the Soulsborne games can be, but this shouldn't turn you away from playing it. With the option for summoning help and the addition of ash summons for solo play, most of the bosses are beatable within a few tries. Most of the notoriously difficult bosses are optional and are not required to beat to complete the game (they give especially cool options for weapons after beating them though), and not facing them still gives players an exceptionally large and intricate experience that is worth playing again and again.

Edit: After 800h I'm still loving the game but please RELEASE THE DLC, I'm out of builds to play.
Pro: 
It's a souls game, the open world design is amazing, every point of interest has somethings useful to collects, exploring the world is fun and never feel the same on multiple playthroughs.
There is no path you have to take, you can just choose what ever route you want to progress, if you feels like you're too weak just go to a different area.
Most weapons, skills, spells feels fun to use. In fact you can clear the entire game by just spamming skills/spells and not using normal attacks. 
Just use what ever you feel fun to clear the game, if it's in the game then they're meant to be used, there's nothing cheap about summons or spamming skills.

Cons : 
After beating the game 13 time, I have to say some endgame bosses are just not fun to fight, they are overly aggressive with weirdly long wind up attacks and big AoE attacks, too many reused bosses (looking at you foreskin duo), the difficulty design fall flat after Leyndell.

I don't care how good the Malenia fight is, she's utterly BS and is what's wrong with FS "hard" boss design. She breaks so many fucking rules like no other enemies in the game, she can cancel her animations, she heals even when you guard and take no damage, she can input read like she knows today's lottery numbers, she instantly gain hyper armor from most of her attacks which feels so fucking random, she has way too much HP for someone who can heals and has hyperarmor in almost all her moves which pretty much force you to use status effects, summon, powerstance if you want an easier time, none of the other bosses are like that, you can reasonably beat all the bosses with even just a dagger because no other bosses heal 1k HP per hit while having 33k HP and infinite hyper armor, her AI behaviors are inconsistent, sometimes she'll just be super aggressive during phase one even though she's not suppose to, sometimes she won't attack you even if you stand still, Waterfolwer is suppose to trigger when she lost about 30-33% HP but that's not always the case, sometimes she just won't do it and then randomly do it later so you just have to die, she don't even fucking dodge away before doing that move so the player can actually have time to react because she's suppose to be "hard". She's literally a DPS race, the longer the fight the worse it gets which is not the case for any of the other bosses in the game because none of them breaks so many fucking rules. There's no amount of copiums can justify her terrible design. She would have been a great Sekiro DLC boss, but not a souls game boss because she's literally does not fit with the boss designs of the series.

The sidequest design is HORRIBLE, I missed the raging wolf armor set on two playthroughs, you will miss out items if you don't use wiki to check how and when to do all the sidequests because some quests are gone after you killed the boss of the area.
The Catacombs are fine to clears on multiple playthroughs but the Hero's Graves are simply not fun to clear after the first time.
And the last thing is LOBSTERS, FKN LOBSTERS

First 3/4 of the game was great, and when a boss is too hard, you can just level up your stats or gear and come back. There's a ton to explore, the game looks gorgeous even on a Steam Deck, and just a ton to do in early/mid game.

But the last bit is just a slug fest of boss after boss, and when you already have a maxed out weapon and are at a high-ish level, going from level 145 to 155 isn't really gonna change anything, so you just have to keep trying. Bosses kill you in 2-3 hits, and you need to get a lot of hits in, so a lot of boss battles are just you rolling around and hoping to get a hit in every few mn.

Do I suck at this game? Absolutely. It was my first Soul-like, and I now know I do not enjoy trying the same boss fight 50 times in a row to learn its timing, or at least not when there is 5 of them in a row with basically zero content in between.

By the end I kept going purely because after 50 hours it felt weird to give up on the last boss, but having defeated it, I don't think I want to play this game ever again.

The unicycle is an entirely different system of balance, and even mounting it is wonky. It is mechanically restricted, slower, and if your objective is to ride a wheeled vehicle over a distance it is objectively worse.

But if your objective is to be in the circus, ah it has a charm doesn't it? 

Exactly what that charm is, I can't say. It took me 40 hours hating the experience to feel it, but here we are.

Amazing game through and through, would highly recommend even for people with no familiarity to FromSoft games or souls-like in general.

[h2] Difficulty [/h2]

The game is not difficult in a way that's considered unfair or requires you to grind. It does offer a constant challenge from beginning to end and rewards smart and innovative playstyles. The game additionally provides you with so many useful tools that makes the journey a much better experience and even sometimes just outright trivializes certain mechanics. 

Don't be afraid of using your consumables, you can always craft more thanks to the built in crafting system. Absolutely no reason to save them for "that" moment because you will save yourself so much time and mental. Always use them when it feels you could be using them to make things easier. 

The game also introduces a mechanic called summon ashes that allows you to summon spirits of certain NPC mobs to help you out, mainly against bosses. Use them whenever you can and don't listen to anyone that says it makes you a noob for needing their help. Its a very fleshed out game mechanic with its own upgrade system, it was meant to be used, its not a "cheese" at all. Have fun experimenting with them all.

[h2] Exploration [/h2]

This game must have the best exploration of any game I'm familiar with. The map just keeps getting bigger and bigger. Even when you say "there can't possibly be more", well guess what, there's always more and then some. 

The world is immensely beautiful that you'll find yourself wanting to explore every nook and cranny on your own. What's even more crazy is that quite literally you get rewarded with something by exploring every nook and cranny, whether it is a shiny new weapon, summon ashes, armor or even upgrade materials. 

There have been complaints that certain late game areas have less and less things to do and explore, namely the snow areas, however it does not undermine or undervalue the sheer size and scale of the possible explorations you can do. Those few areas still have a lot of charm to them. 

[h2] Bosses [/h2]

Bosses are extremely well done and each main or secret boss offers a unique experience and feel. Different people will struggle with different bosses depending on their build, playstyle, type of summon, and if they're using consumables which makes the game all the more unique in experiences and offer so much replayability. 

There is criticism to be made about reusing minor optional bosses commonly, but for the most part it makes a lot of sense. It is impossible to create hundreds of unique bosses with each their own mechanics, design and lore without making the game overwhelming. It is also much better for the player to be familiar with a boss due to past encounters making your experiences and knowledge acquired have value. In my experience however, each encounter feels new with repeated minor bosses as there is always something new to learn in addition to them having some extra gimmick attached to them. (Except for Godefroy fuck that reused lazy excuse)

[h3] Some tips for new players [/h3]

Level up your vigor stat (health) early on as it will yield the best results by far. Upgrading your main offensive stat won't matter much in the early game since scaling starts to pick up later. 

Don't go crazy about losing your runes when dying, its not worth the mental and its definitely preferable you try out a different tactic and overcome the challenge rather than worry about your lost runes over and over again till you rage quit. Runes are not a scarce resource and is always in abundance especially if you explore a lot. 

If a certain enemy or area is too difficult at the moment, don't bend yourself backwards trying to complete them. The open world aspect allows you to go explore other places and come back stronger with more levels, better weapons and upgrades. 

Don't go too hybrid leveling up your stats, focus on one offensive stat and a just as needed in the others so that you meet the requirements of your favorite weapons and spells.

Elden Ring is by far the most approachable FromSoft game to date. The traditional Git Gud mentality is shoved to the background in favour of open world exploration, albeit with a clear intended path due to enemy scalings per area.

Visually it is extremely pleasing with amazing vistas in most if not all the major areas of the game (aside from maybe Caelid, that nightmarish hellhole earned its reputation). Enemy design and visual effects are also top notch. It is understandable that enemy and area designs are reused throughout the game, but some are a little overused, especially the Catacomb tileset becomes incredibly repetitive. They have been compared to shrines in Breath of the Wild/Tears of the Kingdom and i'd say that comparison is pretty fair, but far from flattering.

Now, let's talk gameplay. Is it perfect? Absolutely not. The game has plenty of playstyles but some bosses later on in the game will pretty much force you to adjust your approach if you wish to stand a chance. Sadly, this includes the final boss in my opinion. On the other hand, certain weapons and spirit ashes (looking at you, mimic tear+10) can trivialize a LOT of otherwise challenging areas/bosses. This may sound very negative but it is honestly rather nitpicky in the grand scheme of Elden Ring. For i'd say about 90% of the game you are free to take any approach, and that is nothing to scoff at. Another note, some of your attacks can have generous hitboxes, but beware, some bosses have very unforgiving hitboxes to balance it out. My personal experience with PvP is Mohg's favourite word, NIHIL!, so I will refrain from touching on that.

Moving on to audio. FromSoft is pretty (in)famous for the epic scores during their bossfights and Elden Ring is no exception to that. Besides those, the main area themes lend well for immersion and rarely get on your nerves (aside from once again Caelid, but that one is fully intended to keep you anxious). 

Dialogue is surprisingly frequent, with a lot of NPC's to speak to and do quests for if you so wish. I would subtract points for calling me maidenless a multitude of times but its actually pretty funny. Oh and the screams/noises the player character can make for all the different ways you can (and will!) die are almost frighteningly good.

The final point I'd like to bring up is the story. As we are used to from FromSoft, the game takes a Show-Don't Tell approach for the majority of the game. There are plenty of cutscenes but most of them will do very little to explain anything, aside from the introduction cutscene (ohhhh~, rise now, ye Tarnished!). To some, this approach is lackluster as they would rather be spoonfed a story, but to me, FromSoft, with the help of Georgie, have delivered a sublime world with fleshed out characters and lore that goes deeper than the deepest trenches on earth. Be warned, very few characters will get a happy ending, but come on, it's FromSoft and the man behind Game of Thrones, what did you expect?

All in all, Elden Ring is a sublime game with mountains of content that will keep you entertained for over a hundred hours if you let it, and it is eye-pleasing throughout. It has definitely a few flaws, some of which run deeper than others. Thank you for making it this far into this rather lengthy review. Now, let's finally give the game a scoring, shall we? I give Elden Ring an outstanding 8.75 out of 10.

I fucking hate this game...

TLDR: Maybe you will like it, if it is on a discount you can try it. Compared to other recent games this is a decent game.

If they'd remove the mount and 85% of the map, but keep the loot and the enemies the game would be 20% better.

If they'd keep the 15 remembrance bosses and made them appear only once and keep the 12 required boss, let's see keep another 15-20 unique bosses and only add like 1-2 repetitions of them, so only 60-70 bosses would be available instead of 165, that would make the game another 20% better.

If they'd design the bosses with one player in mind and without the mount as it would be removed in the first point and not make the player run after scared bosses for minutes, that would make the game another 10% better.

If they'd remove the crafting materials from loot and made them only obtainable like the flowers and other stuff and made the lower tier crafting materials more common and not only in the first one or two areas it would make the game again 10% better.

Only these four points would make the game so much better, sometimes less is more.

I don't mind open world games, if done correctly, here everything is just a big bloat and I barely remember a couple of bosses, catacombs and mines and whatever else. This game feels also a bit shallow, but much better than Hogwarts Legacy.

Exploring is not rewarding as all the good and important items are right in front of your eyes as soon as you try to explore and get off the path you only find boring crafting materials.

When professional players constantly cheese bosses  to beat them (the duo khm, but there are others) then it is not a good boss design. (I have easily beaten them with the golden greatshield and antspur rapier, not even fully upgraded, 4th try on my first playthrough, did I beat them? Yes. Was it a fun fight? No. Did I feel the accomplishment? I mean I applied rot to fatty, then facehugged the pillars and ran around, wait for him to respawn two times sounds like a big skill then sure, but no.

Story? What story? I mean there is a story, but not a good one. Sadly I heard about G. R. R. Martin participation only later, otherwise I wouldn't have bought the game, it shows in the story though. Miyazaki should have kept his non-writer hand in this. Whatever.

It is clearly a console port: can't use mouse on the map, you have to use E, enter, mouse click doesn't work in many cases, some menus can only be navigated by the arrows not W A S D, clunky controls with the pouch and so on, pretty annoying, could've been better if they'd do a proper port not just a lift and shift approach.

Targeting got a bit better as it is not as aggressive and stiff with the camera, however got much worse as well, because now it is so easy to change targets you cannot really lock on, makes a mess, room full of passive enemies only one that is already aggroed, closest to me and in the center of my view, targeting targets the passive enemy behind the aggressive one, in the corner of my screen, making me vulnerable to the other one. Simply hitting the button resets the camera, which still sucks as it is very fast confusing and usually happens when I want to target the enemy in front of me, but it turns me 90 degrees away from it, making my character vulnerable again. 
Why targeting then you may ask? Because I have a 2,5 meters long huge sword in my hand that I swing horizontally in front of me, the enemy is so close that I cannot move forward and I still miss 6 hits out of ten, previous titles provided an 80-90% accuracy as melee so I only used targeting for casters, in this game you need it almost all the time.

Input lag: always feels like you are playing with 500 ms ping, sometimes when I hit the button once nothing happens, as timing is key it ruins some of my fights immensely, input queue is crazy too, I hit the button, enemy hits me, got me flying I couldn't get up quickly as my previous input is still in buffer so hitting space doesn't work, I get up and recover in 3-4 second, which is a lot and then my action triggers too, just to make it easier to the boss to kill me.

Gamebreaking bugs even after two years: Greatshield pokey pokey you get no runes...
I have found 3 somber smithing stones 7, 2 disappeared from my inventory, same with comet azur spell and god knows what else that I haven't even noticed. (No it is not in my storage, I'm sure I looted the items as I watched multiple guides after the incident as I assumed I remembered wrong, but no) Never happened before in these games. 

I don't even want to replay the game, I don't want to make a new character and try the bosses again to see how much better I got or how much better the new build is. I was like thanks god this boss is over with and I don't have to fight it again and I didn't even struggle with them that much, ok I wasn't using summons, because it would have made the whole thing laughably easy. I played previous titles multiple times, I only stopped because it kinda sucked me in and I couldn't do much else, so I forced myself to stop playing those games, this one? I forced myself to play it through at least once, so I can write a proper review. Oh and I had to use guides to be able to progress, not to mention the terrible scaling and whatnot...

I could go on forever, but I think my review will be too long again and I will not be able to send it.

Is it bad? No, it is just different, so I think for many others this game would be great, for me not so much, but thanks god there are different type of games so everyone can enjoy something and everyone can be happy.

The evolved and graduated form of the Dark Souls formula, Elden Ring. The game expands what in my opinion was greatly lacking in the souls series, and that is open world and exploration. I have always hoped to find a game that would combine the beauty of open world of exploration of a game like Skyrim, but would also incorperate the enjoyable and difficult combat theme of the souls games; moreover, this is the a big step in the right direction for the souls series theme in my opinion.

The character customization is streight up souls style, but enhanced with a bit of greater freedom. The introduction of the skill system allows the player to define to some degree what weapon art they want on their weaponry, though I wish there was a bit more freedom. This is a great boon to me, as playing my spellsword like I did in Dark Souls 2 required me to be able to both parry and reposte with a right-hand weapon; however, getting used to the timing of the parry is a great trial just as it was in the other souls games. I have not found all of the war ashes yet, but the list is getting bigger, and the options are a very welcomed addition. Spell slots are another thing that typically required a great deal of character levels to have any variety, but now they are key items instead of being tied to any of the stats. This will allow me in the end to have ten spells like I did in Dark Souls 2, but without the wasted stat points in a certain stat. The enhancement to co-op has also been well done, in activating summoning pool items allows you to use an item to send your sign to any active pools, making it possible to explore the world and still get summoned to random dungeons. The days of sitting by a certain bonfire with your sign on the ground are gone, and that is really needed change given the open world aspect of this game. Another addition is spirit ashes that allow you to summon various spirits to fight and pull some of the aggression off of the player, making it less tedious to solo some of the bosses. The combat feels very much like Dark Souls 3, but without every enemy's attack being in hyper speed mode; moreover, giving a welcomed feel of a blend between the Dark Souls 2 & 3 enemy attack speed.

The world so far has been beautiful and vast, and they were kind enough to give you a horse to travel and fight with on the open world map. The addition of harvesting resorces and crafting items, along with the various dungeons and sites of interest very much remind me of exploring Skyrim, and that has really added to the joy of the game. I still have not yet explored all that much of the map, and non of the underground area, so there will be many more hours put in this game before I'm done. If you are a souls series addict, then you likely already have the game, but if not this is a great game that to me combines to some degree the greatest aspects of Skyrim with the renowned combat system of Dark Souls. An awsome game, that so far has ran quite well, but I gave them almost a year to patch it up before I started playing. All in all, it is a great game to get lost in with tons of hour of fun and frustration; however, the difficulty is souls inspired, so rise and rise again until lambs become lions.

Three hundred some hours later and am still loving the game, especially since they expanded the spellsword type magics. This has been a fun, but frustrating character build that wasn't an option to this extent in the other souls games. Great game, but have had some crashes while being summoned and odd screen issues during starting and closing the game that I wish they would fix up. Ready for the final boss and the journey of seeing all six endings with three different character builds. A great way to extend the life of the game out and finish the last of the achievements over another year or two.

What do I say about Elden Ring that others have not?  This is one of the best video games I have EVER played in 40 years of life.  It recaptured for me that wonder and joy from the magic of video games from my youth.  This game is an objective, unquestionable absolute masterpiece and the crowning work of Fromsoftware studioes.  

Elden Ring was my first Souls Game, and I have to confess it was a rough start.  I actually came very close to requesting a refund 30 mins into the game.  I am SO glad I gave the game a chance.  The problem with this game is that, instead of a learning curve, the game has a learning CLIFF to brand new players.  But if you are patient, and willing to do some work to scale that cliff, the rewards are great.  

My advice to new players:  1.) DO NOT attempt to fight the Tree Sentinel until much later.  I wasted 2-3 hours when I first booted up the game trying to fight him, and thinking this game was awful and not for me.  He's there to basically troll you, and teach you that you can skip challenges in this game.  

2.) The game does not hold your hand one iota.  It is expected that you will need to furiously look things up online.  It is expected that you will need to watch YouTube videos on how to get through a cave, how to find an item, how to dodge a specific boss's attacks.  

3.)  There are so many ways to tone down the game's difficulty if you are not a Souls veteran, but it's just less obvious than a difficulty slider in the menu.  You can use spirit summons to make boss fights significantly more manageable.  You can play as a mage, magic typically has an easier start (though not necessarily easier by mid-game).  
 
There are so many great things about the game.  The lore that is revealed little by little via environmental storytelling is fantastic.  The creators understood that things are cooler if you leave some things to the imagination.  The art, the boss and enemy variety and designs, the combat, everything is fantastic.  One of my favourite things about the game is that it gives you SO MANY paths, so many ways to become a powerful god-slayer.  There are many ways to awesomness in this game, there is so much variety, and it feels so different.  In my first playthrough, I played as a Dex/arcane samurai.  I started a new game as a mage, and the game feels like a completely different game, so different that I'm not bored at all.  The fact that this game gives so much enjoyment and fun for one base price with no microtransactions and no add-ons is unbelievable.  If you beat a boss you can obtain their armour and weapons to "cosplay" as your favourite boss. This is the type of "skins" that a lesser studio would charge you real-world money for, yet Fromsoft gives it to you for free.  

Elden Ring probably isn't for everyone, but Fromsoft really did make an effort to make this their "most accessible" souls game ever, so I think most people who like video games will probably be able to get a lot out of this.  The game is as easy or difficult as you want it to be, and that's a good thing.  Anyway, I highly recommend this game!  It is a masterpiece.

Been a fromsoft fan for years ever since they released dark souls back in 2011. I remember picking it up at a K-Mart that is now sadly closed. I even went to go get a slushie and some popcorn with my mom so call it a core memory, I guess. Anyway, what followed after that was a journey that legitimately took me almost more than a month to complete. I achieved the link the fire ending and was rewarded with some beautiful music and respawned back in the undead asylum to do it all over again. I played each and every single souls game, including bloodborne, sekiro, and even armored core which isn't a souls game of course, but you get the idea. 

So, when I heard that Miyazaki was cooking something up with GRRM, the creator of one of my (formerly) favorite tv shows and book series, I knew we were all in for something special. Then comes an amalgamation of what made all of their games great. Stealth, powerful weapons, flashy armor, spells with convoluted names, and weapon skills that let you do acrobatics that would make Sekiro jealous.... I remember thinking my mage build in dark souls III was something special until I saw the absolute monstrous builds you could make in this game. 

The main core that makes fromsoft games great is that they give us the tools, but it's up to us to figure out in what ways we can use them. The builds that are capable of existing in this game are indescribable and it allows the player to respec their levels into anything they want, thus making the possibilities nearly limitless. 

The difficulty scaling with this game drastically changed from previous iterations. Essentially, reaching level 40 in previous souls games would make the player rather formidable during early game since everything was so linear and the difficulty would steadily rise. Given the fact that elden ring is open world, the player can easily run into a boss that's far too difficult to fight right off the bat and forces us to go out and explore other places so that we can level up and come back stronger. Being level 40 in Elden Ring is like reaching level 20 in earlier souls games. Granted, the game forces the player to level vigor, because the late game enemies will absolutely one shot everyone. 

Despite all that, there are so many tools to use in elden ring and it grants us every chance to succeed. Though people bitch about the game being too hard, it just simply takes some effort to look around, level up, and also simply git gud to advance. 

Lastly, let's talk story: it would take someone as based and unhinged as GRRM to come up with a world like this. The man gave no fucks when he killed off the Starks in Song of Ice and Fire, and he gave even less fucks when coming up with this depressing, but amazing world. In typical Fromsoft fashion, the player lands in a world that has fallen to ruin and it's up to them to save it, form it into their own vision, or simply destroy it all. So far, I've achieved two endings and will probably end up going for the other ones as well. The sheer amount of self-interpretation is what makes his games so great. Letting the player fill in the blanks is often criticized as lazy storytelling, but I feel like it just takes some patience, which is what a lot of people seem to lack these days. 

Anyway, I recently finished another playthrough. I did as many side quests as I possibly could. Finished Ranni's quest again because of the moonlight sword. Did Fia's quest to get the Fortissax boss fight and I even fought Dragonlord Placidusax for the first time. Who knew that I would find out what it would be like to fight a Boeing 747 that could breath lightning? Coming up next in this game should be a DLC. Whenever that is. Either way, I'll still be waving the fromsoftware banner till I die. 

...Or until they release a game that has a battlepass. 

With that out of the way, 10/10 would play again.

(I'm just changing the review slightly to fix any mistakes I may have made at the time.) Game of the year for a fact. I hope Fromsoftware the issues with patches later in the year. Please take note, if you buy this game don't give in and don't rush your play-though. This game was not meant to be played.  Half of the fucking bullshit content in the game, the only content that makes it "open world" is shit.  Think Bloodborne chalice dungeons, but exponentially worse.  Full of copy pasted half-assed content that is only there to pad out the game and make it seem like it's not just a massive empty world.  Please god make it so that FromSoft never touches "open world" bullshitery again.  This "experiment was a massive failure, even though FromSoft fanboys eat it up relentlessly.  If this is the future of FromSoft souls-likes, I'm fucking done with them as a company.  They have completely lost any notion of difficulty, and replaced it with shitty duo bosses that are literally just copy pasted enemies with hyper-inflated health bars that kill you in 2 hits no matter what your vigor stat is.  The main path is great, sure, but the main path is like 1/3 of the game.  Why make 60% of the game if it's just lazy bullshit time-padding content?  This game is just filled to the brim with unplayable fluff that honestly feels like they didn't even try to make enjoyable or interesting in any way to begin with.  Every single side dungeon just begs the question "why the hell is this in the game?"  I'm so sick of developers making such a huge open world just to fill it with so much half-assed bullshit, when the time wasted on that could have been put to use by making the main quest, aka THE ONLY FUCKING REASON FOR PLAYING THE GAME, better.  It doesn't impress me when one of the selling points is 100+ or whatever dumbshit catacombs and caves and mines and whatever the fuck else, because all of that fucking sucks, and the vast majority of it is indistinguishable from one another.  There are maybe 1 or 2 unique catacombs/caves/mines that try to differentiate themselves from the rest, AND EVEN THOSE AREN'T WORTH PLAYING BECAUSE THE REWARDS ARE SHIT.  If I'm judging this game purely on what parts were enjoyable as to what is offered, the best I can give it honestly is 4/10.  The majority of this game should not exist, and the time put into it was completely wasted.  DO NOT BUY THE HYPE.  The main quest is great, but even it could've been better if the team wasn't so far up their own asses that they thought players would love to fight the same enemies over and over and over and over and over and over and over again as bosses after some half-assed side dungeon nonsense, all for a shitty item that only 1% of builds would ever find any use for, and not even enough souls for half a level up.  It's fucking insulting.

As someone who has never been able to get into a Souls-like game, this has been a wonderful experience. The open world offers much more choice than previous Souls titles, and allows for an "exploration and grind" approach rather than the typical hitting one's head against a brick wall until it falls down. Classes seem more flushed out, and play style can be more varied. 

On top of that, this game offers varied beautiful art design. No more are the dim and dull tones of previous souls games. Here you will find verdant green forests, scarlet barren wastelands, gloomy blue marshes, glowing volcanoes, golden cities, and white snowy tundras. This is an extremely generous game. Where one might think they'd find a long winding corridor of enemies and traps, you'll be pleasantly surprised with more unique and expansive areas to explore and fight in. I highly recommend this game.

[h1]It's a lot of fun, bbbbbuuuuuttttttt the following is quite annoying: [/h1]

Being in an open world game that requires exploration, but will lock you out of certain story-lines and missions if you progress too far or don't do the right thing at the right time or have an enemy (some can be challenging) kill an npc (sometimes when you're not even around). 

Graphics are dated compared to Lords of The Fallen Etc. 

Dated technical features like no wide screen support, etc. 

Having to depend on mods for some quality of life things like better coop is not ideal.  The devs should just pay the modders and incorporate their stuff.  Maybe make it optional in the settings for people that don't want it. 

Having to farm runes is a bit of a chore.  Ideally this would be better implemented in the exploration / playing of the game.  Chasing a ball or having the big metal ball chase you around for several hours so you can get enough vigor and stamina is not ideal.  I like the fact that the the rune farms exist since the game would be a massive pain otherwise.  I think that being able to re-farm bosses and harder enemies would be a better way of doing it.  Perhaps a special tower or something you could do for that.  That way you're still working on your combat skills.  Maybe a modifier-gamble mechanic for extra runes to keep thing interesting. 

Having a rune recall item, spell, or special church/location that was spaced out like larval tears or the rune-substitute-sacrificial-twig would probably better than the sacrificial-twig.  I know there are mods that let you reload your saves, but having something in game would help out quite a bit.  
^^^^I enjoy the mini-bosses and hard enemies that you have to work for, but there are some times in this game where you can get blind-sided by a very hard enemy and you need to stop and go farm runes a bit to "git-guOoud".  Not quite as bad as some of the Dark Souls games, but still annoying for a new player.  Your invested runes from exploring are basically a sunk loss while you try to farm and you pray you don't make a mistake while your farming or you lose both your farmed runes and the ones trapped behind a golden boss wall or in a dangerous area with a semi roaming boss.  Like when a Dragon comes down from the sky to smash you when you are going to clear out a low level mob on an island or when a Black Knife Kindred basically does the same in a blizzard.  

Some of the weapons, magic, and items don't seem to scale well?  Even something called the God-killer Great-sword or something may be lackluster.  However other items are fantastic / borderline op.  I actually hope they buff instead of nerf because if it wasn't for the BloodHound's Fang being absolutely kickass  I would have returned the game. 

I understand the dark mood and setting to create tension.  However there are moments in this game that are beyond dark and depressing.  This would be fine if the story-lines had slightly not as bleak endings.  Currently the game is setup that if you finish the quests you're not *really* going through hell / dark situations in order to make things better... you end up putting a lot of hours into something and the story mostly leaves you at a question of if quite a few things were actually made worse by your involvement.  Not that you have too much of a choice.  Your character is mute (which is fine, I guess that helps with immersion for some folks) and does not have a lot of text options to shift dialog or actions to a more positive outcome (not fine, there should be more involvement) except for a few side-story-lines.    The problem with these side-storylines and the "good" ending is that the game doesn't let you see much actually getting better.  I realize that there may be DLC on the way and that there is only so much time and $$$ that the devs can put on quest outcomes, but since it's really easy to sink 50-100 hours+ in this game it would be good to see a little more positive cause-and-effect.

I hate this game.

I'm a huge fan of Fromsoft and was beyond hyped for Elden Ring. Fortunately, this game lived up to the hype as it successfully evolved not only the Souls formula but the open world of The Legend Of Zelda: Breath Of The Wild. The open world in this game is close to perfection in my opinion as it is not made up of FOMO style content but genuinely worthwhile sights, quests, and thrills that can be indulged in by the player at whatever pace or manner they want. Furthermore, it improves upon BOTW's world by having multiple handcrafted dungeons that greatly vary in scale, design, and necessity (i.e., the majority are optional) but are all uniformly excellent as a result of some truly incredible level and enemy design. In typical Fromsoft fashion, the combat is also fantastic with lots of depth and satisfying mechanics to play around with. The excellent combat is further complimented by great build variety with many cool weapons, magic, incantations, and ashes of war to try out. My only complaint would be that the boss fights are a bit of a mixed bag with a select few matching From's best, many being quite middling, and some being incredibly unpleasant especially during the late game. However, this is a minor complaint because Elden Ring is a triumph of game design and the rare case where a game manages to cement itself as an instant classic.

Loves:
- The progression in the game feels super natural
- It is very challenging
- Epic Bosses!
- Super rewarding when you clear difficult bosses!
- Lots of build variety
- Unique Weapons

Dislikes:
- Ulcerated Tree Spirit
- I get disorientated sometimes
- Limited spell diversity

Things I'd like as someone that primarily plays PvE, and doesn't know how this would affect the game would be a wider spell variety, I'd love for more utility spells (and I don't mean buffs) but like a shield spell that creates a magical shield instead of just a enhancement or spikes from a ground or something neat! 

I absolutely adore super basic non combat spells, like the little light one for caves is a really nice thing.

Overall I highly recommend trying this game and this might just be one of those games I would really love to 100% and try experience all it has to offer.

And lastly, remember two things! There is no "wrong way' to play and don't give up Tarnished! You can do it!

What an incredible game. If you're new to the Souls-like games, this is a perfect game to start with. Fluid movements, polished combats, vast open-world map, variety of play style you can choose, and much more you can get from this. At first, you might feel that it's too difficult, but the more you progress, the more you feel that the difficulty isn't too bad. The only downside is that some bosses' movesets aren't well designed and terribly balanced to the players' abilities. Other than that, this is a masterpiece. Especially if you're a masochist.

I keep coming back to this game and always find something to challenge me, or explore. I didn't play it for almost a year until recent months and can't put it down. The openness of most areas is freeing for new players to the genre who want to customize their initial setup, and the many different ways you're allowed to fight bosses and enemies alike makes it a uniquely fun experience, much like customizing how you fight in Tears of the Kingdom or Dragon's Dogma as I've heard.

Certainly helps to have the wiki open as many things aren't explained to you, in fact, you hardly know what's going on half the time. A refresher in the lore of different areas is always good to read up on to better appreciate it, but isn't necessary. But that's what makes it great as well, you're a character coming up from nothing and not even expected to survive in this world, much less claim the Elden throne. So much of it is a mystery, and yet the more you play, the more is unraveled.

I've attempted to give this game a chance with three separate characters... I start to get extremely bored around the 20 hour mark, every single time. I tried a tank, a dex build, and a mage. The game just feels so vast and empty, like I'm just running around killing everything that moves for no reason. Its an absolute chore to play.

The exploration element was cool at first, but when I realized that most of the time my reward for exploring was an item or weapon that doesn't fit my build, it kind of bummed me out. The combat and graphics are cool, but that's really all this game is; constant fighting in a cool looking world. It gets tedious after a while, given how big the world is. 

I have almost 2000 hours in DS3 and maybe 1000 in DS2 (between vanilla and scholar) and a few hundred in DS1. I love those games, but I just can't get into this one. I really tried. I'm Uninstalling and I regret the purchase.

I do recommend the game for excellent story, scenery and well designed mechanics. The game is similar to Dark Souls 3 I also play but 100 time better. Most annoying things in DS3 for which I rated DS3 low is sorted out.

As the souls game genre, the game is considered difficult. However, there are both online and offline mechanics that help to get through the hardest boss and non-boss fights, although some achievements will require to defeat difficult enemies without such support.

It's a single player open-world game full of mysteries to solve and secrets to discover and places to visit.  It might be overwhelming at first. Players are free to wander around the world and are not forced to follow a specific route. It also takes much more time to complete the game.

Verily I say unto thee, what manner of blasphemy hast thou uttered against me, thou impudent varlet. Know thou that I am a graduate of high renown in the noble company of Raya Lucaria, and have taken part in many covert operations against the forces of Limgrave, with 300 victories to my name. Trained in the art of moon sorcery, I am the premier witch in the armies of the lands between. Thou art but a lowly tarnished to me, unworthy of even a second thought. Be warned, for I shall smite the with a swiftness and precision never before seen upon the face of the lands between, yea even unto the seven generations. Dost thou think thou canst hide behind thou shield and insult me with impunity? Think again thou rogue. As I speak my spies across the land doth track thy every move, and soon thou shalt face the full wrath of mine anger. Thy location shall be traced and the tempest shall come, the likes of which shall make thee tremble. Thy life shall be as nought before me, for I am trained in the arts of magic, moon, and glintstone. With the full might of Caria Manor at my disposal, I shall wipe thee from the face of the lands between leaving no trace of thy existence. Oh that thou hadst known the depth of thy foolishness, perhaps thou wouldst have kept thou tongue in check! But now thou has sealed thy own doom, thou foolish one. I shall conjureth upon thee a moon of fury, and thou shalt be consumed by it. Mark my words: thou art dead thou young pup.

An absolute masterpiece of a game. This game elicited the same feelings I had when I first played GOAT games like Ocarina of Time, Half-Life 2, Final Fantasy 7, Mario 64, etc... A pinnacle in gaming that MUST be experienced.  This was my first souls game and for sure won't be my last. I highly recommend this game!

1) Played for 9 hours, haven't found anything to do. Most of the rewards for exploration are common collectibles you can easily scavenge on the overworld, or very minor sidegrades to the starting weapon.

2) The game does not look good or technically impressive enough to justify the constant lag spikes on my PC which could handle far better looking and more technically impressive games. Wouldn't be an issue if the game wasn't also very hard (meaning a bad lagspike can and will kill you). Oh and it has no pause which means you can't pause through the lag spikes. And death is really punishing so you can be bullshitted out of all your runes at any point.

3) The game is hard but in a bad way, the base game is incredibly easy but the boss fights are huge difficulty spikes the base game did not prepare you for. So you have the choice of throwing yourself at a boss over and over until you win or explore the rest of the world and getting bored to death. In the middle of doing the latter I decided I had better things to do.

4) Every ability is so incredibly lame, like I restarted the game when I realized faith-based casters got a fireball (yes the game does the infuriating "pick a class with no context" thing, AND magic-user roles are the opposite of most of fantasy with faith being the cool one). Then I got the fireball and wow how do you make a FIREBALL lame. Sorcery just gets to fling blue baseballs.

Yadda yadda yadda really good game, we know this, it's been out over a year now. 
(it's sum more DS3 + Jumping + dubblejumping Goathorse) We all on the same page? Good. 

Now then. Please, for the love of god Fromsoft - 

PUT A TOGGLE IN THE OPTIONS MENU THAT LETS ME DISABLE THE COMPASS 
(without turning the HUD off entirely, obviously)
There's nothing intrinsically wrong with having a compass - but I HATE IT. 
It's like trying to drive my car with a huge muddy stain across the the windshield.
 
Take a staff member or two off Fires of Rubicon for a day, and patch this in, plz, FFS. 
(and have them add a vignette disabler too while they're at it, that'd be good)

I truly don't understand the mentality of this design decision. You built a big wonderful game with great visuals and plaster a big ugly Skyrim-esque NSEW on top of everything, and hold my precious HP and STA bars hostage by making them tied to the only option that fully disables the compass. Which, as i mentioned before, involves toggling the ENTIRE HUD.

and before some pathologically incurious bootlicking little dipshit saunters along to tell me "Hey dood! Itz not a big deal!" - YES! dipshit, it is (in fact) a big deal- It's in your face the whole game. Unnecessarily.
By definition, in the context of this videogame, it's a Fire Giant's hairy red ass-sized deal.

As my first time experiencing a "Souls-like" (or a FromSoftware product in general), this review is genuine. I harbor no bias for the company or the genre. That being said, Elden Ring was immediately one of the best games I had ever played to date. Sure, the learning curve is steep, but never have I had so much fun dying over and over. The challenges in this game are an enjoyable kind - minus points for a few (the 'wicked sort,' namely Maliketh for myself.) The bosses in a Souls game are unprecedented as the history goes, but therein also lies in Elden Ring an enamoring sense of discovery and adventure, puzzle, awe and most importantly, triumph! It feels so good to finally get that boss you've been struggling with down, and to the point of the adventure; you always want to turn and look at every corner along the way you go knowing that FromSoftware has fully fleshed out every area in this world and you don't want to miss any of it. Worth every cent of my $60.
game is good

Runs well despite my pc being 3-4 years old, amazing feel to the combat, beautiful graphics, and a very engaging story

Somehow this game can enrage me to hair-loss and still be the most engaging game I own. I have been stomped by a boss for 3 hours, and still kept trying. There is not a single feeling comparable to beating that boss, and looking forwards to the challenge of the next one. The world is diverse and well-crafted, and I honestly didn't notice the recycled content until it was pointed out to me. Even then, they remain thematic to their areas and move-sets regardless of similarity. The Tree Sentinel, Draconic Sentinel, and Loretta are all the same model. Yet, all 3 feel distinct and their moves  require a completely different approach. There is a meta, but every single build can work with enough patience and skill.
Game of the Century.

Heed my words. I am Malenia. Blade of Miquella. And I have never known defeat.

Sixty-five hours in. SIXTY. FIVE. And I've only beaten the first real boss. The vast, vast majority of this game lies ahead and I've already put 65 hours it. Yes, this is my first soulslike. At first I was utterly overwhelmed and actually despaired; surely this just wasn't a game for me, I was helpless, hopeless, and frustrated at every turn. I let it sit for a year and came back to it out of curiosity and dread, and now I'm utterly addicted. I'm powered up enough not to sh!t myself at every turn, and have learned the most important lesson of Elden Ring: Have patience. Have. Patience. 

This game is in my blood now. I've never felt more affinity with and sympathy for a video game character as I feel with my poor, wretched Tarnished. I will see this through, to the end, if it takes me a thousand hours or more. I'm 54, so I may be dead long before my Tarnished finds the Ring. But I'll have fun before I go.

This game made me feel like Nuts from the critically acclaimed manga Berserk

[9/10] Elden Ring was a game that kept me hooked start to end and improves on almost every previous game made by FromSoftware. It is a game truly worthy of its game of the year title.

It is another game that falls under the â€˜SoulsBorneâ€™ genre but sets itself apart from the others with how open the game is and how much freedom it gives you to play how you want and go where you want. Everything in this game is top notch with the worldbuilding, lore and combat. Characters are fleshed out even with minimal player contact and so many details that you might miss. Boss fights are brought to a new high with so many unique fights and the satisfaction received from beating them. The game is outright stunning to look at and always surprises you with how much there is to do and explore and always rewards you for doing so. I loved learning every little trick or bit of lore in this world. There were so many details in every quest, item description, enemy and even aspects of gameplay. Itâ€™s been a while since I played a game that left such a large impression on me, and it would be all I would think of playing when doing anything else.

It isnâ€™t without flaws though. Side quests are difficult to keep track of and the way to progress some isnâ€™t always obvious. Weapons are all so unique but stat requirements are steep where you are unable to wield most weapons at the start of the game. Late game weapons means being built incorrectly to use most new weapons without having to use a large number of resources and time to change your build and find materials to upgrade a new weapon. I found myself opening the wiki a large amount so that I wasnâ€™t wandering aimlessly when trying to complete quests or look for important materials. As fun as some of the boss fights are the game has a habit of repeating them with only a few tweaks which makes exploring feel a bit repetitive as the boss will be something you have already fought, a late game enemy or dragons with just different breath attacks except the two remembrance ones.

It is a game I highly recommend as it was just an amazing experience, and my gripes are minimal to how much fun I had and engrossed I became. Though I understand itâ€™s not for everyone, like those who donâ€™t have the patience to see all what the game has to offer. It was a great time and I my hopes are high for the upcoming dlc.

This game is utterly singular in scope and quality. 

What is left to say about the game that everybody loves? Personally, the game reminded me a lot of old PC RPGs - Might & Magic 7 and 8 in particular, which I fondly remember from my childhood. In those games, the world felt dangerous and alive. You could walk off into any direction you liked, and you might just get killed by a horde of ogres that are completely out of your level. An attempt to clear an early quest could turn into a harrowing journey deep inside a labyrinthian catacomb ridden with the undead. Any victory won feels earned.

Recent AAA games have conditioned players to accept that exploration necessitates calculated bursts of dopamine. Victories are not earned, but rather handed out at set intervals. Elden Ring brought back a quintessential element necessary for a true sense of exploration: dread. A world needs to be able to fight back to feel convincing.

7.5/10
A good game with a great amount of things going for it, but also far more flaws than one would expect.

-First, the movement feels a little sluggish compared to the other games despite the player moving at about the same speed. Not an actual game issue inherently, but especially compared to the speed at which one jumps, it feels weird to me- just a little off-putting. Not too serious.
-Second, the meta is utterly broken. Now I hear what you're saying- "That's not Fromsoft's fault"... it kinda is when if you don't carry a strict few weapons and/or stick to spell, jump attack, or Weapon Art spamming then you won't get very far in the PVP meta. Damage is at an all-time high, which means that anything less than 60 Vigor is within one-shot range, which is definitely taking away from the game. The imbalance strikes this game straight off the roster of PVP games.
-Third, the physics engine just feels... vague? You'll die from a fall pretty much whenever the game feels like it. I'm positive there's math in there, but it just feels inconvenient.
-Fourth, this is only kind of an argument against it, but its bosses utterly destroyed the Fromsoft formula. Darkeater Midir in DS3 set the record for the highest HP of any souls boss at 15,860 health... then Elden Ring brought along a boss with 59,174 HP. 15K is just barely over the average for the later-game bosses, it's not even close to a record. I'm certain you can see why this is unsettling.
-And finally, the game is as good as does false advertising. Of the hundreds of "bosses" in the game, nearly half are just normal enemies with boss bars, but even the remaining ones are mostly repeats- only 8 are unique.

Don't get me wrong; the plot was pretty good, the game was beautiful, and I love most of the PVE, Co-op, and playstyle, but I personally believe for the aforementioned reasons that this game wasn't exactly GOTY material. I'm open for debate on the things mentioned though.

Amazing game, both for the first experience, as the fourth replay. I prefered building new characters up until a suitable PvP level (150 for me) so I could switch characters for different playstyles. What I love most about Elden Ring is how it included everything great about the Dark Souls series and managed to improve upon it. Build variety, how playstyles also feel different to each other.

But it also took a few shortcuts that made the game feel really stale after putting hundreds of hours in the Souls series. Many enemies in Elden Ring have the (exact) same movesets as enemies in the previous games. This includes mini-bosses and regular foes alike. Just before the last zone, you are basically fighting the same type of enemies in long strides of the game. There is feeling of tediousness, more so the ice regions. Many of the early game 'bosses' are just late game enemies. This made NG+ feel a bit of a redundant task compared to the Souls series. But many lategame enemies are also just early game enemies with boosted stats. So not only do we face the same types of enemies multiple times over, a large part of them are recycled enemies from previous games. This made the actual pool of cool and interesting fights, a lot smaller this time around, compared to the Souls games. It can make the endgame feel frustrating the first time around. And a core the third.

But all of my complaints about this game... are after 600+ hours of playtime. This game does nearly everything great to amazing and can easily be improved upon in DLC, more so in a sequel. For half the playtime the game looks like a painting whenever you travel the landscape and find a spot where the view is amazing. First playthrough where you don't hyper optimize your build yet and play with what you find, instead of hyperoptimizing your build on future playthroughs. There are so many items, builds, discoveries, challenges and story elements in this game that make repeated playthroughts an absolute blast, and most of them can optionally be ignored to save time for those that want to certain area's faster. Either by map knowledge, or intentially (by design) find certain items that allow for those skips. Instead of one thing, it is impossible to do a true no-maiden run (yet), which denies certain challenge runs, it literally blocks of the second half of the game, while still giving the option ingame. - I got too far into it only to figure out I wasn't alone...

Second is the implementation of PvP which isn't forced this time around, which is a good thing for newer players, and newcomers to the series. It allows you to progress the game without having invading players kill a hard earned progression run. Yet it also doesn't push a broader audience of players into learning to fight in PvP, nor gives the incentive to learn to PvP early enough. This game sadly promotes PvP players to become MUCH stronger, with specialized builds (for that level range) that makes it very hard for progression players to deal with them one-on-one. But it is much more in the background this time around. You actively have to seek out multiplayer in Elden Ring, to enjoy it.

Compared to Dark Souls 3, which in my opinion has better overal dungeon design, Elden Ring managed to interest me for far longer. Elden Ring managed to do 'true' exploration right, and rewarded story clues in the form of interactions with npc questlines that start to make more sense (as tradition) in future playthroughs, often with the wiki open longer than we'd (I'd) like to admit. The story makes much more sense at first glance, but is deeply layered with loads of mystique you will figure out after watching the lore video's (again). 

Absolute A-grade product, from start to end, with the endgame slightly underwhelming compared to the first half of the game. Which is where the re-use of stone imps, giants, abductor virgins, and various other early game challenges, start to feel stale. Even its most unique and frustrating mechanics can be countered, if you figure out how. A true dungeon crawler, but now in an open world. Can't wait for the DLC, sequal is a guaranteed buy as well.

This is a great game by all standards.  Is it, as branded by many; the best rpg game ever? Nope. It isn't.

One of the problems with this game, is the size of it. Yes, I know; you get more value for your money. But a very large sized world like this, imo, needs a little more variation. In every new area of the game you come to, it is basically the same. Get rid of the enemies, and go finish off the boss. 

I have played through DS1 and 3, and I for one, liked DS 3 a bit more. I don't think a big open world like this, suits a hack'n'slash rpg like Elden Ring is, like it does other rpg adventure games. 

One of the reasons for this:

The NPC's and their stories.  After you first encounter them, you'll run into them again by chance, every now and then. It may be so many hours since last time, that you don't even remember exactly who they are anymore, and what they were up to. 

The game doesn't give you any journal to track anything. If you have played Souls games before, you know this , but for those of you who never have played a Souls game before; you have to Google a lot.

The stories of the NPC's are too fragmented for my taste. And if you don't remember to exhaust their lines, they will not progress in their quests/stories. And because of this, I find I don't care about many, or any of them really.

If you don't play what/how the devs would like you to, or designed the game for, you will miss out help from NPC's in some boss fights, which is really just stupid. You may find out that you forgot to got there,and talk this or that NPC. And no help for you.

Having said all this; it is a great game, if you like hack'n slash rpg. One of the best around. 
It's so big, it's easy to get a bit lost, so Google will be a good source for many things.

If you are not familiar with Souls games, and/or don't want to be invaded by other players; play in off-line mode.

Remember; this is just my opinion.

Title: "Elden Ring: A Disappointing Fantasy Flop"

Rating: â­ï¸â˜†â˜†â˜†â˜†

As an avid gamer, I had high hopes for Elden Ring, especially considering the hype surrounding its release. Unfortunately, my experience with the game left me utterly disappointed and questioning the accolades it has received.

First and foremost, the graphics are far from cutting-edge. In an era where we've seen breathtaking visuals in other open-world games, Elden Ring falls short with its lackluster and dated graphics. The character models are bland, and the environments lack the detail and realism that one would expect from a game of this caliber.

The gameplay is another major letdown. Elden Ring boasts about its challenging combat, but it often feels clunky and unresponsive. The controls are unintuitive, making it frustrating to execute even the most basic attacks. The supposed depth in combat mechanics only adds unnecessary complexity without adding much enjoyment.

The open-world design, while expansive, feels empty and lifeless. The lack of meaningful side quests or dynamic events makes exploration a tedious task rather than an exciting adventure. The world is filled with generic enemies, and the repetitiveness of encounters quickly becomes monotonous.

The narrative, touted as a collaboration between Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R. R. Martin, fails to deliver a compelling story. The lore is convoluted, and the characters lack depth, making it difficult to invest in the overarching narrative. The promised epic tale turns out to be a convoluted mess that fails to engage players on an emotional level.

Furthermore, the inclusion of the open-world elements feels forced, as if the game is trying to check a box rather than offering a genuinely immersive experience. The result is a disjointed world that lacks the coherence found in other successful open-world titles.

In conclusion, Elden Ring falls short of the high expectations set by its developers. The subpar graphics, unpolished gameplay, lackluster open-world design, and underwhelming narrative make it a forgettable addition to the gaming landscape. Save your money and invest in a title that truly delivers on the promises it makes.
