As of this review, while it says I only have 9.1 hours in the game, I mostly play offline on PC, and own it on both Xbox and PlayStation as well and easily have upwards of 500 hours across about 12 profiles, all running different builds, and I'm Still finding new things. Elden Ring has easily become of of my favorite games of all time, and I can proudly say it's the reason I've started playing more Souls-likes in recent years.

There's so much to say I couldn't fit it all here, so TL:DR, just buy it, it's worth it. Look at my hour count, do you think I'd spend this long on a bad game? 

Elden Ring is a wonderful masterpiece, yet plays some rather common themes in fantasy RPG games. You are the chosen one, go kill god. However where it differs is that it doesn't serve you power on a silver platter. You have to earn that power yourself. To start you get a variety of basic weapons to choose from and are thrust into an odd world, post societal breakdown. You must explore the wasted and current structures, still guarded by those cursed to watch them. You must find the power and skill to succeed.

I myself, did not originally find that power. When I first started, I looked up what the most powerful weapon was I could get my hands on (Bloodhound's Fang if you're curious) and I gunned it through the story as fast as I could, only getting stuck on 2 bosses throughout the whole game. This is certainly a way you can do it, but not a good way. Unlike the previous souls installments, with the open world aspect brings a curse, you get overlevel yourself and your gear and steamroll the competition. It makes it easy in an otherwise notoriously difficult franchise. I regret doing that on my first playthrough, and I would like to offer to others ways to prevent that. So the from here on, here are some tips to make your playthrough more enjoyable and consistent to the franchise.

3 weapons to outright avoid on your first playthrough and the reason why:

  1. Bloodhound's Fang - It not only has an insane multi-hit skill, but it is one of the highest scaling weapons in the whole game, and you can grab it withing 5 minutes of starting the game, or better yet, take 10 minutes and you can have an npc kill the enemy for you, and you get the sword for free.

  2. Rivers of Blood - You might have heard of this one, and perhaps that it was nerfed. But trust me, it was only nerfed from game breaking to massively OP. It can clear almost all main bosses withing seconds. And although you can't get it until half way through the game, I would still recommend you stay away, as it's power only becomes stronger the farther you go. It was also inspired by the murimasa, so if you know the background of that, you get the idea.

  3. Reduvia* - Now this is a special entry, while it is an exceeding powerful, super early weapon, it is held back and reigned in by it being a dagger, which some could argue makes it ok. However, just to explain, you can get it also withing 5 minutes, just like BHF (number 1) but also an npc can kill the enemy for you. It's skill is a slightly weaker, but ranged version of rivers of blood's skill. So it is still no shortage of OP throughout the whole game. although a very fit choice if you prefer daggers, but find it difficult to learn the moveset with such a short weapon, while the game tries to slaughter you all the same.

Next, 3 places to be weary of should you find yourself there:

  1. Mohgwyn's Palace - Achievable to access right after Godrick through an npc questline, it might seem logical to assume that its ok to explore such an area as soon as you can, but be warned. Moghwyn's Palace is the 2nd highest scaled area in the whole game. It is a challenge to level 80+ players, let alone under 30, shortly after the first shardbearer. While it does house some truly magnificent loot, certainly reachable if you know the right path, do note most things will kill you in 1 hit, and enemies here are VERY aggressive.

  2. Deeproot Depths - A bit different from the first, but still requires some thought. While deeproot does not pose a huge threat on its own, it can lead to some very nasty places elsewhere. Beware of coffins and portals here, many of the destinations are, shall I say, interesting to travel through. 

  3. Haligtree - Now, of course, many of you may already know about this place, but I'll give a few pointers regardless. If you remember, Moghwyn's Palace was the 2nd highest scaled area in the game, well, Haligtree IS the highest scaled area. I wouldn't recommend coming here on a first or second playthrough till at least level 100, or above if you still struggle with bosses often. That being said, there are countless pieces of fantastic loot here, some behind super difficult bosses, others right out in the open, free for your taking.

Lastly a few individual tips, not regarding the same topics:

  1. Bows and Crossbows - While it may seem at first that bows and crossbows would be an ideal weapon choice for new players, do not be fooled. While they are a great tool for exploration and dungeon diving, they are (aside from 1 crossbow) almost useless for most boss fights. As to why, well there are a few reasons. Firstly, limited ammo. you can only carry 99 of each arrow, and while that does sound fine, it brings us to our next point. Secondly, scaling. Bows simply do not scale well at all. most will gain a maximum of 70-80 extra damage at the top end of its scaling stats. and crossbows, well they don't scale at all. That's right, AT ALL. there is 1 crossbow that shoots 3 arrows at a time, which is ok at applying status effects, but, using 3 times the ammo consumption, is not ideal. And lastly, the overall damage is very low on either weapon. 140-150 damage is rather high for most bows and crossbows. 

  2. Magic - On the contrary, magic is a great option for new players. There is a lot to be said from being able to stand back and pelt enemies with pebbles and magic blades. Limited resources do come into play, as unlike arrows, which you have to buy or craft. FP (the mana stat) regens fully upon sitting at a grace. However, it also it alot easier than melee, with many easy builds pertaining to ravaging bosses in seconds. Certainly fun to play, but about 3 levels of OP under the 3 weapons stated above, with a few spells exceeding them in power. Same goes for incantations, however they have a much greater use in buffing and healing than damage, so I find Faith to be a much more balanced stat.

  3. Some BS - As the name may imply, some things that happen in this game are, well, BS. Let's call this my complaint section. I only have a few. #1, certain bosses difficulty are only an issue because of how much they run away. Several required fights would be cake if it did not either run or teleport to the other side of a huge arena. #2, sometimes death is unavoidable, with or without skill, examples being certain frame attacks of a certain fat boss, while not always a death, is almost always a hit to me and others I've watched. Another would be a certain large boss somersaulting over you, even on Torrent (the horse) you will get pancaked without fail, again not always death, but almost always a hit. #3, dragon breath-like attacks can hit you 2 or 3 times even though you are locked into a falling animation after the first hit. 95% of the time, if you get hit once, it is a guaranteed death, and there's nothing you can do about it. And lastly #4, a truly 1 sided complaint. Some map geometry just isn't that good. See a jump that looks easy? Nope, you slide down a wall and get pushed 4 feet to the left our of nowhere, then missing the platform and dying. or a certain jumping puzzle, where you land on a flat surface, stand up, and proceed to slide off and die before you are able to do anything about it. There are other examples, but you get the idea. 

So, do I recommend the game? Well of course! I love Elden Ring and can't wait for the dlc to arrive. I will likely pass 2000 hours just exploring the dlc, and will almost certainly edit this review after the fact. There are some small flaws, sure, but this is as close to my perfect game as anything has gotten yet. I would certainly recommend it. A quick last tip, if anyone happens to be on the fence, Elden Ring is almost always half off during steams big yearly sales (spring, summer, fall, winter, and christmas sales) and occasionally 20% off)

Its good... but its not Dark Souls

Open World: 
-really only makes sense and is fun if you're on a NG+ run.
-Your first playthrough you will end up going to higher level areas, clearing them, and then going to lower leveled areas later only to destroy everything easily. It's not really fun and I wish they just kept it semi-linear so you would get a natural progression and ramp up to the end.
-Tolkien helped in the design of the map.. which is great, I love LOTR, but my god is it really open and really empty. Basically just rolling plains with scattered ruins and a few major cities/areas

Enemies/Bosses:
-Seems to be a huge lack in variety. Many repeating enemies, many of which are copied assets from previous games with a reskin
-lot of repeating bosses but good variety 
-dont like that some bosses only appear at night and changing to night time is pretty annoying since you have to do it every time you die

Combat:
-classic souls combat
-way more hitbox issues than previous games
-jump mechanic inconsistent success rate
-seems the Ai doesn't understand charged heavy attacks and wont try to dodge/block/or parry them, they just walk right into it
-DELAYED ATTACKS ARE A BORING AND UNINTUITIVE WAY TO MAKE THE GAME MORE DIFFICULT. Every fan of this game will endlessly argue that it adds difficulty for "Souls fans" but everyone hates it. Nobody actually fights like that and sitting in front of a boss whos holding his arm in the air for 10+ seconds or having a boss jump in there air, float for a few seconds, then come back down is more annoying than challenging.
-Spirits

Weapons:
-more weapons that are just pointless and unusable
-policy of "if everythings broken then nothing is broken". Every class of weapon (including magic) has unbelievably broken weapons and I feel kind of forced to use them
-less scythes makes me sad

Weapon Upgrades:
-Classic upgrade system but instead of using stones to obtain effects (heavy/sharpness/quality) its stances which is interesting but odd
-smithing stones arent scattered the way they are in other games, they put most of them in mines which you have to find.. kind of annoying but it works. I had to end up googling where some of the mines were because I had the stones to level up to 20 but was missing the stones for 8-10.

Magic/Pyromancy:
-really cool spells in this game compared to previous but it seems kind of broken sometimes the way you can end boss fights instantly
-pyromancy basically non existent, uses a completely different system than previous games. Overall seems less prominent

Menu/Settings:
-No native Ultrawide support which is unforgivable for a game that came out in 2022. It was in the game on launch and then they took it out. So if you want to change the .ini or download a mod to make it ultrawide you will be locked out of online play for suspected cheating
-You can change the combat and movement controls, but not the menu controls. So you can never change that Q is how you get out of menus instead of Escape like it is in EVERY OTHER GAME. 

Map:
-You can't open the map in combat which is incredibly frustrating while navigating an open world full of enemies. I get that you shouldn't be able to teleport in combat but not being able to open the map is a poor choice
-The custom markers you can place on the map don't have enough variety to be able to remember what they mean when you return to them and they dont show up the way location markers do so you have to place both to locate a custom location. Not very intuitive.
-You can place up to 4 location markers at a single time which is nice

Story:
-Its a souls like so I don't ever expect much story telling but its just okay in my opinion. Felt like I cared more about Souls 1 and 3. 
-The choice not to make a opening cinematic to describe each boss like they did in previous games is kind of sad. Its just a slideshow of images, no videos.. feels like a lack of effort.
-Some of the endings are unnecessarily hard to achieve and some are unnecessarily easy to achieve. The bad ending in DS3 took so much effort and genuinely felt like I was becoming the Dark Lord whereas in this game you become the Dark Lord by simply hugging a 3 fingered hand.

Overall:
Feels like an uninspired, empty, repetitive, lack of effort version of Dark Souls. Feel like I have to force myself to play it and enjoy it. There's a lot of weird choices in game design and it feels like FromSofts entry into an open world game so it seems like there's a lot of cut corners. It doesn't have the quality or polish that the other games have and it really doesn't feel like a passion project like their other titles have been. If this is your first game in the series you will probably like it and don't get me wrong, many people love this game (Souls fans included), I just don't. I love DS1 and DS3 and DS2 really grew on me and I would much rather play those games than this.

It took a long time for me to love this game. Though yes i love this game dearly in this review ill bring up some points that stopped me from loving for so long.
1. Non-rewarding Exploration. this issue comes up alot when learning the game and because the game is SO big and SO long this issue ends up double dipping. Once when your exploring your first time the scenery is lovely and nice, but big visual spectacle is never my thing in video game. If im exploring i do it to fight more bosses and find stuff to add to my build. during the 1st yeah the bosses felt unique enough to slog through the copy paste dungeons and boss fights. Every other playthrough however absolutely not once you know that this dungeon is there and will provide nothing it becomes pointless.
2. Replay-ability. As touched upon in the 1st point this game is big and you will miss dungeons & side-quests all the way up till your 3-4th run throughs of the game if your searching naturally. This results in alot of time spent memorizing where the stuff you like is for future playthroughs.
3. PVP. I played DS3 for 3 years after the Ringed city got released only playing invasions and pvp. Somehow there were almost 0 improvements made and in fact it somehow got worse? ofc the netcode will never be fixed that fine but when you hit hit the invade button the game 7 out of 10 times will put you into the open world. Bugged Weapons, Poor Netcode, Open world invasions, No rewards, and a surprising amount of cheaters make it unsurprisingly not fun. This shits making me go hollow
4. Boss Design. Elden ring departed from the rest of the souls series boss designs in BIG ways. 
Bosses have extensions to their combos which they only use when the player either attacks or heals. In the rest of the souls games you could actively engage the boss and deal damage without getting hit. No one is calling those games easy in fact most souls veterans thinks elden ring is one of the easiest, But elden ring isnt a graceful dance like its predecessors instead its a waiting game. GOD FORBID the boss dodges away after you waiting for its window i mean SERIOUSLY why does every remembrance boss except for rykard have a way to get away from you and STAY away from you. Fire giant, Maliketh, Morgott, Rennalla, Radagon, and Elden Beast. Even Horah Loux one this games best bosses has several moves which will keep you out of melee for 10-20 seconds.
5. Scaling. Instead of throwing your self at the problem and improving as a player it is heavily encouraged to go away and come back when your stronger... thats not a skill issue thats a design choice. 
6. Build Crafting. in pvp is as good as the rest of the souls games but pve? different story if you choose a weaker weapon and dont use elements and status some bosses become a slog fest. If youve played the games you know the ones. Their the bosses the community has put after "the wall" which is a very big damage and health increase in some areas past mid game. Want to spend 8 minutes fighting fire giant? i dont think you do.

In conclusion this game is a masterpiece, Please let the DLC have more legacy areas/dungeons instead of open world.

There's real problems with this game.  Like...big ones.  There's no tutorials and a lot of it is poorly marked, the combat system feels more like "science + luck" than art, and the difficulty is badly imbalanced.  Occasionally they try to throw "plot" at you, but it's so unbelievably ham-fisted and contrived and poorly told that there's no point in trying to decipher it. 

 That said, there's a real special game here if you're willing to commit to some brutal punishment.

"This game is too hard!"
Miyazaki: "Get better at it, then."
"Everything does way too much damage."
Miyazaki: "Get better at dodging, then."
"There's no good reason that all of these bosses have so many attacks with purposely delayed swings."
Miyazaki: "Get better at dodging on reaction over muscle memory, then."
"This enemy/boss is subjectively unfair."
Miyazaki: "Get better at it, then."
"The camera is terrible, it just swings around and never has an affixed position outside of less fights than fingers on my hands."
Miyazaki: "Get better at spinning your camera around in free aim mode before the enemy snipes you in the back, then."
"All of these side quests end with the NPC dying for no good reason."
Miyazaki: "It's for the plot!"
"I never find a weapon that I can use for my build."
Miyazaki: "Get better at finding them, then."
"There's no way that I'm supposed to know that this NPC appears at this place after I move along their side quest.."
Miyazaki: "Get better at finding the NPCs, then."
"Why do I have to fight Radagon before every time I want to fight the Elden Beast? It should be like Gehrman and the Moon Presence."
Miyazaki: "Get better at no-hitting Radagon, then."
"This type of weapon is underpowered, can you buff it?."
Miyazaki: "Pick a better weapon, then."

The entire premise of the game being intentionally hard acts like a shield that the developers can pull out in order to deflect any valid criticism of the game, whether it from me or anyone else. This entire game is so big, but there's literally nothing to do except loot and kill people like a Mongol, and do side quests that give good items for characters that are extremely forgettable due to a lack of personality and emotion, and especially given the fact that likely over half of them die at the very end.
Reusing content is the main way Fromsoft "populates" the place with content, the regular enemy you just fought is probably a boss with a little more health and damage in one of the many repetitive dungeons outside of the purposely unique ones, and vice versa. Hell, they even reused the first demi-god, Godrick, for an evergaol (what in the world is an evergaol, btw?), and all they did was rename him to "Godefroy the Grafted". Again, the map is so big, yet feels so small because you're never going to be exploring every corner of it when it becomes a chore just to wade through piles and piles of enemies just for some item you don't even want, or better yet nothing at all.
The story is basically the same as Dark Souls as well, except replace a few keywords and the Dark Soul with the Elden Ring, make it more obtuse and you're good. Rune Arcs are literally just reskinned Humanity or Embers, except they come in a bunch of flavors (you're only going to be using Godrick's and Morgott's most likely, and Mohg's for invasions, since most of them are really gimmicky or underwhelming in comparison). Even the Graces are just Bonfires, but look even worse because it's just a particle effect suspended in the air. I felt next to nothing fighting any of these bosses except Godfrey and Mohg, because most of these fights are just a bunch of nonsense about this great and mighty warrior or sorcerer or evil person - all of which is very shallow - and then you get to the boss, and you beat them. It's hard to say the same for Radahn though, since I was a bit too overleveled before fighting him, and he did have some cool attacks.. You don't feel like they are a character or anything, all you see is a slab of meat, a strong enemy that you have to kill, you barely ever get attached to any of them because by the time you see them they're dead faster than Millicent. The only bosses that don't instantly disappear forever when you beat them are Renalla, Morgott and Godrick, with Renalla just becoming an emotionless stat changer, and the last 2 just turn into shriveled corpses that say some dramatic nonsense before dying, not even with a flashy animation or anything, just falling over. If you want to make a good fight, a memorable one, there needs to be buildup, you need to get to know who you are fighting strong and well and grow intimate with them from afar before you face them down. It's also obnoxious that we somehow kill everyone except Renalla through the death animation, when it would have been a lot better if we were still able to converse with them after they were defeated, just something at all to grow more close with these characters, something to give them a mind and spirit into their stone carcass frozen colder than Medusa's glare.

This game has the same highs as Dark Souls, and more lows. The most satisfaction you will get from playing is a dopamine rush after beating a tough enemy, or getting an overpowered item. Not much else warrants any interest, much less a feeling of achievement. The most fun, however, you will ever have playing this game, is multiplayer, whether it be reading the hundred-thousand variations of "try finger, but hole", genuinely funny or useful messages, helping others or striking them from the face of the earth, it's the only thing that makes the world feel not totally monotonous and lifeless. My favorite has to be "Try aristocrat" with the laying down emote ontop of the guillotine in the Subterranean Inquisition Chambers..

[h1] First things first [/h1]
This is the 2nd most overrated game I have ever had the displeasure of launching on my computer.

[h3] Credibility [/h3]
this is just a small section to show why you can trust my first impressions as opposed to other people.
I don't care whether you believe any or all of the things listed here.
Firstly, I love challenge whether its simply playing a game on its hardest difficulty or doing challenges where im severely limited.
For example, One of my favorite things to do in Destiny 2 are Solo RAID challenges, obviously not everyone will understand the difficulty of these but just know that there are hundreds of thousands of players on destiny and thousands attempt some of the challenges I have done and only a few hundred complete them. they are unintended by the developers as they didn't even expect these things to be possible.
 I also have a deep passion for single player games especially open worlds.

[h2] First impressions[/h2]

I want to make it very clear that I was going into this game knowing that without a doubt controller was the intended way to play.
So upon opening the game, the first thing I did like I do in every game is go to the settings to attempt to ensure I would most likely not need to return to the menu at any point when playing, obviously its basically impossible in any game to achieve settings where I will feel comfortable on the first go. But before even making it to the settings menu I immediately realized that I was experiencing fps drops and general low fps just on the main menu. I didnt worry about it and proceeded to the settings. A lot of the default options are very questionable and im not even talking about the controls yet. There are several camera options enabled by default that are rightfully considered accessibility options in other games. This isn't that big of a deal for someone like me that changes settings right away but not everyone goes through everything like I do and small things like this eventually will end up adding up so an uncomfortable experience. After finishing most of my settings I went to the controls. Now even if controller is the main input device there is no reason for the MnK control scheme to be this out of touch with modern times. F to jump? But its not only this I quickly realized that the UI was not going to be good once I saw the way some of the things were set up. I was already getting the sense that there was this outdated feel to the game. But Anyway I finished that up and decided to start playing.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

Oh boy... time to make some people mad

I was pretty sure that I was going to have a problem with the combat before buying as by simply looking at gameplay the combat looked like it feels in game, slow, clunky, and boring. There are several weird game design choices right off the bat and I will not only list them but I will explain why I think they negatively impact the experience. Dodging gives no burst of speed completely removing the point of the name dodge it is simply god mode for a few hundred milliseconds on keypress with an animation and that's how the game makes you use it as well. This part may be incorrect due to insufficient playtime however blocking seemed fairly useless as on normal enemies every attack basically staggers them so you just spam left click and then on bosses dodging is all that is necessary. Now to talk about the actual combat. Hitting or killing enemies is not satisfying at all which is pretty crazy considering that's all you will be doing the entire game. To elaborate slightly, the animations aren't special, not enough satisfying feedback when hitting enemies, and a lot of issues with the movement which I will listed above. Things are made intentionally to make the game "harder" such as making literally every enemy in the game basically go slow motion right before you think they are about to attack. As someone who is usually above average this takes only one hit to get used to however it is just one of the many pointless things that are meant to make the game difficult but just end up creating annoying gameplay. I know most people will be unable to comprehend the fact that annoying gameplay and difficulty are two different things but that's not my problem. Some more annoying things include that basically all of your inputs are dropped anytime anything happens. For example, when attacking you cant roll or do anything, after blocking there is this weird cooldown if you let go of block and try to do it again. There are several times during boss fights where you feel frozen. The solution to any actual difficulties with the combat are all solved with one word... Wait. Does waiting sound fun to you? well it wasn't for me when fighting a boss I found myself just staring at them half the time it just bored tf out of me mixed with everything else. Everything in this game just wants you to be slow.

[h2] Performance/Graphics [/h2]

I didn't see much praise over the visuals for this game, which is a good thing since its not too particularly special. It doesn't look bad but it doesn't look amazing. It has an art style and sticks to it which is great. But sadly I have some issues with the performance. One thing you notice immediately is that your fps is locked to 60 which is annoying. Just a dumb limitation most likely required as a result of poor game design. Every time there is any UI elements present there are fps drops which isn't unplayable but is just unacceptable for a game of this praise.
In case anyone wants to know my specs and want to blame it on that here they are.
CPU: Intel i7 12700k
GPU: 7900 XTX
RAM: 32 GB 3600mhz CL16

[h2] Plot/Story [/h2]

I will not go into detail in this category as I am not qualified to do so however there are some things worth mentioning.
The basic premise in interesting enough to warrant giving the game a try however there is nothing more than that. I believe that the two most important parts of a game are its gameplay and story. Only one of them needs to be really good. But sadly there is nothing about the story that was able to hook me from the time I played which can be fine for some games. Another thing that felt dated were the cut scenes, the game would have been better off just not having them as the camera work made me feel like I was playing a game from 15 years ago. Funny enough I wasn't even expecting cut scenes anyway.

[h1] Conclusions [/h1]

The most important thing I want people who havent tried this game to take from this is if you have a feeling you wont like it, do not try it. As I touched on it in the story part above, I believe there is a balance between gameplay and story that needs to be met for example if the gameplay is a 2/10 the story needs to be an 8/10 or they both need to be 5 or something you get the point. But in this game its more of a 3 for gameplay and 5 for story. Sometimes the games appearance can make up for a little bit but as I mentioned above there isnt anything special about the way this game looks. Basically, this game is a clunky and boring mess that feels like it released a long time ago.
This game just isn't for me. I don't understand the appeal of this game. I just found it boring, i am simply not this games audience. Its not terrible just not my cup of tea.

Hands down, the most visually impressive, engaging, challenging, and exciting video game I have ever played.
Overall: 9.9/10

Visuals: 10/10 I love the mid-evil fantasy aesthetic this game offers, and the world around you is beautiful always

Open world: 10/10 To say the world around you is huge would be an understatement and an insult. In my first play through, I was exploring and finding new areas for DAYS. And I still haven't seen it all.

Story: 10/10 Very complex lore wise, incredibly creative fantasy

Mechanics: 9/10 Camera mobility and positioning on your character and other small things could be better, combat on the other hand is very challenging and engaging, I was completely immersed into the combat while playing

Replay-ability: 10/10 The game gives you so many ways to play you could spend countless hours on just one way and then try another and have the experience change completely

The game is fun and all, but to tell you the truth Souls games and open world just don't mix in my opinion.

I stopped playing 50 hours in after I realized that I was googling a lot of things about the game such as correct stats/weapons in order to actually enjoy the game, I created over 11 new characters and Only got past the second boss three times.

When you have a game this difficult giving the player so much liberty can be a bad thing sometimes, as lame as it sounds you need a linear path for these kinds of games so the player isn't left questioning themselves if the loot that they found is acceptable for the current boss.

Just want to add that open world games that give you a lot of freedom are actually some of my most favorite kinds of games, it's just that I do not see it working for Elden Ring because of how punishing the game can be if you don't know what you're doing.

Pros:
- Nice lore
- Nice visuals
- Outstanding flexibility in build variety (weapons & scaling, spells, weapon arts)

Cons:
- Only a few interesting bosses. Uninteresting ones constantly reused.
- Atmosphere lacks loneliness and despair. 
- Fast travel from anywhere disrupts the flow of the game. And I can't stop using it because without it you'll never finish a game.
- My personal biggest flaw - open world. Big, vast, beautiful and frustratingly empty. Cheap trick to add a massiveness to a game. You just ride around these empty planes for hours. Did you think I have 700+ hours on a record because I enjoyed it? No, I was riding torrent for 2.5 hours to pick up this piece of shattered glass, now I need to fast travel and ride 4 hours in an opposite direction to pick up a dung pie. Open world is a disrespect for people's time.

Incredible Game , nothing will beat the night I finally downloaded the game that fateful February , Can't wait for the dlc to drop so I can go hype mode with the ladz .

Got stuck on a boss, so I went somewhere else for a few hours. Came back with a new weapon with cool tricks, and kicked ass.

I don't know if I'll eventually burn out with this game, but I know that I've never finished a Souls game. If you're the type to get frustrated and put a game down because you're getting hard locked by a boss, this might be a good game for you! At no point in this game are you forced to beat a boss to progress. You can just go somewhere else! It's great!

February 2024 Edit:

I have all achievements, have beaten the game multiple times with drastically different builds, and itch to replay it again every few months. Absolutely phenomenal game, cannot wait for the DLC

Probably top 5 greatest games of all time, but there are glaring issues, like copy paste bosses, armour doing jack nothing and dying to many attacks in one hit that feel not "hard but fair" but more like bullshit and cheating which no one likes. Have done probably 10 or more full runs and it feels like if you play without summons you have to use gimmicks and cheese to beat these bosses or be a complete numbers nerd to min max a build. I get the quest style encourages adventure but when that's relying on you being able to see the NPC's waiting at a site of grace maybe make them a bit bigger? Seems so odd how small the player character  and NPC's are. Death birds objectively suck. Elden beast is probably the worst boss in the whole game, (Radagon is very good) because who wants to chase a boss for 5 minutes just to hit the two times. It's not "hard but fair", it's "boring and annoying".

[h1] 9.5/10 [/h1]
I love this game. It is build on the mechanics from previous Fromsoft titles (mainly DS3) and made bigger thanks to reusing some assets (which is a good thing as it is done right). The amount of moves you can pull off is crazy. The jumping feels nice, the world is beautiful and the minimalistic HUD really helps with that.

The combat is as we remember from DS games with addition of jump, counter attack and crouching. 

World is something else, the scenery looks gorgeous and has so much detail that it is easy to forget that the engine the game is running on is not exactly newest (in fact it is the same engine DS3 used).

Weapons are abundant, often very customizable via Ashes of War. The only issue is that it takes a while until you start getting all the pretty weapons and armours as there aren't many at the beginning of the game (read 10ish hours)

While in the previous games I often kept rushing from one boss to another, here I do the exact opposite, I rather explore. Maybe it is because the Bosses in this game are very chatoic, maybe I am not used to them yet, the endgame ones wipe the floor with me every time.

There are 2 things I am not that happy about in Elden ring. The first one being minibosses that are essentially just big regular foes, which is fine with certain enemies and it makes sense, but then there are some fights when they just throw 2 at you at once and call it a day. Fighting more than one strong foe is pure chaos and usually not the good kind. The other thing is the amount of roll cathing attacks in this game. Literally every enemy has some sort of charge attack that looks like it's coming at you, only to stop for fractions of second or longer resulting in completely throwing of your pace. You are not the one that decides the pace of the fight. The enemies are.

All in all I cannot else but recommend this game, My first playthrough took slightly over 90 hours and I thuroughly enjoyed nearly all the things the game threw at me.

By far the best Game I have ever played without doubt. This game succeeds in all areas and is one of the most fun and enjoyable experiences I have ever had. The story, combat, replay ability and exploration are all immaculately crafted to make the perfect video game. I have put a decent amount of time into this game and have beaten it 5 times now and have barely had any moments in which I have not enjoyed my time playing. I could not recommend Elden Ring more to anyone looking for an amazing single player experience and a beautiful story filled game written by George RR. Martin himself.

(Spoilers Ahead)

Now, despite being the most awarded game in history and by far my favorite game of all time, it is not without it's flaws. First off is the multiplayer, now the multiplayer isn't too bad but it could have been done so much better, I think simply having the multiplayer be more traditional would have made the game so much better and more fun with friends. having to download a mod to skip over the bullshit is kind of annoying and having to use consumable items just to play with friends for only a limited time is just obnoxious. Build strength is another issue with the game, now considering how many possible builds there are in Elden ring it would be nearly impossible to make each one completely balanced, but some are just flat out better than others. For example on my first play through I ended up using an Intelligence based great sword and it was overpowered as fuck, i was 5 shoting bosses like Radahn in new game plus. Then I started a new play through focusing mainly on arcane and I couldn't help but notice how much less powerful the weapons were than for intelligence. This is a common issue throughout game being that there are just a lot of cases where 1 weapon or stat is just less good than another one that is available at the same point in the game.

Now all that negativity aside, This game is still amazing and will always be a joy to play no matter what. This game just does so many things right. Bosses are a great example of this, nearly every main boss has an amazing fight as well as good music, lore, and scenery. Whether it be The extremely slow Godrick or the unforgiving Malenia, This game will nearly always provide you with a good experience in terms of boss fights. Speaking of Music and Lore, this game performs incredibly on both of them. In terms of music, it tends to match the environment and or the enemy you are facing. For example, when you reach Leyndel Royal Capital, the music is somber, sad, almost as if the depressing string ensemble is remembering a better past. the lore is similar with it's approach to tone. the game takes place after the golden age and after the great war known as the shattering. everyone has long lost their pride, soul, and will to live and the world is but an empty husk of what it once was.

(End of Spoilers)

Overall this game is a must have to anyone who is looking for an amazing single player experience to sink many hours into. Go buy this game or I will make you fight Melania at level 1 with just your fists until you win.
Absolute masterpiece. Must play and excited for the DLC. I still wish FromSoftware wasn't so cryptic with their lore and side quests though.

This game can be just as short as any other Souls-like. It can also be 5x as long if you want it to be. The amount of content in this game is just nuts. If you always feel like you want more from the other Souls-like games, this one might keep you busy for awhile. 
I am a completionist though and always find myself wanting to get the game over with as I near the end. I believe this is from fatigue of searching every corner of every inch of the map looking for hidden items or bosses, to which there are a ton of. The dungeons you can find all over the map are usually similar in nature though after you have seen the few gimmicks they have to diversify the dungeons. Once you get to the later zones the dungeons are just repetitions of all the earlier ones, the bosses end up just becoming duo boss fights with enemies we have already seen and glad we are past them. Exploring loses incentive as there are just so many items in the game. You wouldn't even use 70% of them in a normal play through of the game.
The main boss fights are generally really fun, and the combat is just as good as any other Dark Souls game. All in all, this game has so much to offer it is truly a blessing and a curse. However you decide to play though, this game has so many hours of great content.

It's amazing to explore the beautiful environments and combat. Lots of builds, weapons and secret areas to discover, plus an intriguing story you need to put together piece by piece. The game can be challenging at times (mainly for people new to souls-like games) but ER actually offers options to help you out with that. Also, it's incredibly rewarding to beat certain areas/bosses once you get the hang of the combat system. And as someone who already played and loves souls games before: more open world, even more dynamic combat and exploration. Combined with the familiar From atmosphere, it's a great game where you can easily spend an incredible amount of hours in.

As always, this is my personal take and assuming this is me writing to my past self, I do not recommend this game. There are some memorable moments but most of the time is just spent reloading and running back to the place of death. It is a big game with plenty of mechanics but the width doesn't really justify how shallow certain things feel. Some deaths and encounters are gimmicky, feeling like the devs are looking to annoy rather than to impress. Some of the toughest fights are pretty much RNG as I can only hope the boss do not spam certain attacks. You can summon help but it feels like it cheapens the encounter. Towards the finale, I only want to see it to the end, and I stopped enjoying it many bosses ago. Maybe I was playing it wrong, or it was simply not a game that I enjoy. But if you can only play it a certain way, or enjoy it a certain way, then to me, it is not a good game.

This the best and most beautiful game I have ever played I haven't nor will play a masterpiece such as this one. I have continuity been surprised by either it's amazing scenery or beautifully designed bosses. I have played this for countless hours on console and to be honest after play through after play through I was still being mesmerized by this masterpiece. Then when I got this game on steam that allowed me to mod it and mods have never enticed me more they have brought back a huge spark to me that has fostered my love for this game even more. I believe that I will never find a game as amazing as this one I truly believe this to be the pinnacle of video games no mater which game gene you enjoy I feel that this game will have you up all night finding new areas or bosses, I feel this way cause it was how I was ever since I got this game and I still am up all night playing PvP, doing a challenge run, or just playing with my friends. Now that I can mod this game it has become exponentially more fun it gave me a similar feeling to when I first started the game and now I will be able to relish in the amazement of this game for even longer. Now that the dlc has been announced to come out soon I will be playing this game even more the only bad things I can say about this game is that the multiplayer isn't as smooth as I was hoping. I feel that they could of made it more like playing with a friend than just summoning someone to come help you, but I do feel that the recusant and invader part was beautifully performed I think that some weapon balancing is in order. I know that making everything perfectly balanced is hard, I think with proper consideration and lots of words from the community the game can be made even better. I will probably play this game till my death and I hope that from software releases something even better than this, but unfortunately I believe this is impossible because as I said this is truly the pinnacle of gaming.

the game is fun, but its not the same as others. "casual filter" bosses aren't casual filters, they're trial and error. previous ones used to require you to beat a boss with skill, not a specific item or load out or spells. owl in sekiro, slave knight gael from dark souls 3, these bosses required you to use the skills you had from learning the game to win with what you invested in. meanwhile elden ring and armored core 6 instead expect you to die, find the required lore item tied to the boss, and trial and error your way through it until you beat them. there is no exciting feeling of victory for the first time beating a boss its only relief and disgust for how long it took or whoever thought it was a good idea for a bossfight. marget's shakel, sleep pots, bleed, ext all fall under this sort of feeling and they work if that's what your build is for, but the game forces you to need them or you're wasting your time.

I am not enjoying the game.
I want to feel great about this game, but I simply can't.

There is so much great about this game. The World is generally very interesting and I want to explore it. Lots of interesting places to explore and to visit. From this point the game is pretty great. But it is eventually the gameplay that I simply don't like, especially the boss fight.

The game is pretty much about dodging the enemy attacks and trying to get a hit without taking too much damage on your own.

Dodging in this game works with so called invincibility frames. Some moves and animations of your character  put your character for a short period in an invicible state where it doesn't matter if you got hit or not. The state, if you are currently invincible or not is hidden. You just have to know it, and often it doesn't make any sense, like the animation to get on the horse is in an invincible state.

The game as a very big amount of weapons, all with their own attack animations. This is pretty cool. But the game also makes it very hard to actually explore different weapons, because after the early game a weapon is only actually useful if you also upgraded it. But you don't have enough materials to upgrade the weapons you find. So you are pretty much stuck with the first weapon that you first decide to upgrade for the rest of the game. Trying out different weapons really doesn't work in this game. But you find a lot of weapons.

Boss fights are horrible. Pretty much all Bosses in this game are huge and their design is pretty interesting. Sadly fighting them is usually all the time to learn their movement pattern. This wouln't be that bad if not almost all bosses had movement patterns that felt completely random. The jump attack, in the middle of the air them become slow motion, defying the laws of gravity and to mess up your timing to prepare for a dodge/pary. Then they slam the ground so you think you could attack, just to immediately hit with three more attacks that are as powerful as the jump attack, but this time without the need for the jump and much much faster, just to catch you off guard. This feels cheap. This feel bad. I hate it, I don't enjoy it. And it makes me avoid the boss fights in this game as much as possible (but it isn't possible). Winning also doesn't feel good. It feels like I got lucky or something, not like I actually learned something.

The game is knows for being challenging. But then every time I die, the game greets you with a loading time. Then you run back to the boss arena. Just to then die immediately for some random shit. There isn't any challenge in getting to the Boss arena. It is just a boring walk. A good game would just reset the boss arena and let me try again until I beat the boss without loading times. But not elden ring. Each death is confronted with loading times and a boring walk balk to the point of failure.

Then I've tried to play with bow in this game. I've tried to use the crenels that are everywhere in the game world. It doesn't work. The arrows constantly get stuck in mid air. I've tried to shoot with a bow from higher grounds, but for some reason you can't shoot down with a bow when aiming manually. Then I tried to shoot a long distance with a bow, just to realize that the game takes out all damage when shooting a far distance. Using a bow pretty much only works, when you wouln't want to use a bow. Not fun at all.

Fall damage in this game is pretty much the most broken fall damage I've ever seen in a game. Sometimes you can jump high, 100s of meters in the air. Land and there is no fall damage at all. Sometimes you have a smooth landing. Walk a few meters, and then die immediately, because the game noticed too late you you hit the ground too hard? Seriously, this stuff is broken, inconsistent, and really takes the fun out of some exploration in this game.

Where the game  really shines though is scale. This game has a lot to offer, and it just doesn't end. The world is interesting and it always allows to go somewhere else when it is too hard. However reused room assets in side dungeons can be a bit disorienting.

In the past I had problems launching the game. I don't know if it was because of the DRM or not. But it felt like a gamble. I could never be sure if the game would lanuch or not. Recently though I did not experience this problem.

Last but not least, when I connect the Dualshock 3 controller via bluetooth, the game runs on 5-10 FPS. If the controller is connected through a wired connection, I have a smooth 60 FPS. I have no idea what the problem is. It took me an eternity to even figure out that bluetooth connection was the reason that sometimes the game just played in extremely low FPS, and sometimes it was very smooth.

Overall, I am very frustrated with this game, even though I certainly had very good moments in this game. Just traveling the world in this game and finding all the loot and doing the side quests is generally a very very good experience in this game.

There is not much more that can be said that hasn't already been said so I suppose I will write this coming from someone whose first @FromSoftware game was Elden Ring.  It is indeed a challenging game.  One that, in the beginning, may make you want to rage quit.  I know I did.  I took a long break from it and then returned.  The game is not perfect.  I am not a big fan of some of the NPC quests.  The reason is they are so esoteric.  You start a quest but then have no idea where to go to continue the quest.  It is almost simply pure luck that you find the NPC to continue its quest.  I do not like leaving my chances up to serendipity.  Additionally, just following the regular questline using the sites of grace as your guide, you will arrive at mini-bosses and bosses that are too overpowered for your character.  You then have to backtrack grinding for runes.  I am not a big fan of that either although it did allow me to hone my combat skills more.  

With that out of the way, let's return to the challenge.  I played this game the only way I know how:  with a keyboard and mouse.  This game, I feel, was more meant for a controller, so to cut down on the challenge, you need to rebind the keys to something more natural for you.  This will help your encounters immensely, at least it did for me.  Next, this is not a FPS.  If you cut your teeth on mostly FPS games, this RPG will murder you.  Luckily, I had played The Witcher before so I had an idea of how to approach battles.  You cannot spam the "hit" button. You have to find out what the weakness is of your foe and play to that weakness.  You also must learn to dodge well.  I didn't deflect or block much because I rarely used a shield, but even then, you need to learn to dodge well.  Even understanding this, when I met my first real boss in the game, a shardbearer, I really hated the devs.  I thought they all must be sadistic types who love screwing the players of the game.  (Yeah, I know, irrational thought.)  This boss seems unbeatable, but after probably 10-15 deaths, I finally hit on its weakness.  After that the boss was actually quite easy.  I am simplifying things, but more or less, this is how to approach every boss.  Individual characters will have their stock moves that you will quickly learn and recognize.  Learn their moves well, and you will have less problems.  

Notice I said, less problems.  I had to realize that dying is part of the game.  So if you die, except for losing runes, it is not that bad of an experience.  It resets the area and you try again.  You usually return to the last site of grace where you were.  The only time dying is really a hassle is when, for me, the game places sites of grace too far apart.  In cases like these, you do grind through the area and then die close to the end of the area and since there was no site of grace, you return to the beginning of said area.  In those times, dying is quite bothersome and takes the wind out of your sails so to speak. 

Pay attention to armor and your build.  When fighting certain mini-bosses and bosses, they attack using a certain type of damage, fire, sorcery, holy, lightning and so on.  Depending on your armor and your stamina, you may be able to put on armor that negates to some percentage the damage given.  In regards to your build, don't do what I did.  I was spreading my runes across all of the attributes at first, but really you need to decide on what sort of character you want: an all strength build or perhaps an all magic build.  There are other builds as well.  I ended up concentrating my build on strength, intelligence and holy attributes.  I personally found that incantations are more powerful and useful than most of the sorcery spells so I sunk a lot of runes into holy which really makes the incantations more powerful.  I also put many runes into vigor and mind, your HP and FP (for spells and skills.)  

Now I am on my second playthrough.  It's not as exciting as before, but every once in a while I find something that I didn't notice on the first playthrough.  The game is absolutely massive.  I am so looking forward to the DLC.  If you are looking for a satisfying challenge, give Elden Ring a shot.  It will be well worth it.  If you get stuck, check out the many tutorials and walkthroughs on YouTube too.

Certainly, please note that game reviews are subjective, and opinions may vary. Here's a fictional negative review of Elden Ring:

Title: "Elden Ring: A Disappointing Journey into Frustration"

Rating: 2/10

Elden Ring, the highly anticipated collaboration between Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R. R. Martin, falls far short of the expectations set by its creators. What could have been a groundbreaking masterpiece turns out to be a frustrating and tedious experience that left me questioning the hype surrounding it.

First and foremost, the difficulty level of Elden Ring borders on the absurd. While challenging gameplay can be rewarding, Elden Ring takes it to an extreme, leaving players with a sense of constant dread and little room for enjoyment. The unforgiving combat system punishes even the slightest mistakes, making progression feel more like a chore than an adventure.

The open-world design, touted as one of the game's strengths, quickly reveals itself as a double-edged sword. The vast landscapes are indeed impressive, but they are marred by repetitive environments and a lack of meaningful content. The open-world structure seems more like an excuse for the developers to fill the game with empty space rather than delivering a truly immersive and engaging experience.

Adding insult to injury, the narrative, supposedly enriched by George R. R. Martin's involvement, fails to captivate. The lore is convoluted and confusing, leaving players detached from the characters and the overarching story. The promise of a deep and intricate world-building falls flat as the game struggles to deliver a compelling narrative to match its grandiose setting.

Furthermore, the technical issues present in Elden Ring are hard to overlook. Frame rate drops, glitches, and long loading times hinder the overall experience, breaking immersion at crucial moments. It's disappointing to see such fundamental problems in a game that was expected to set new standards in the industry.

In conclusion, Elden Ring may find a niche among hardcore fans of the Soulsborne genre, but for the average gamer seeking a balanced and enjoyable experience, it falls short. The excessive difficulty, lackluster world-building, and technical shortcomings make Elden Ring a regrettable addition to the gaming landscape.

Ok, I have 117 hours in this game on New Game+ and I feel like I can finally give my honest opinion. This game is beautiful, but its basically just an open world Mortal Kombat. There is no real RPG elements, you just kill everything you find, or more like run from everything so you don't get one-shotted by some cheap aoe attack that is impossible to dodge. They added a bunch of awful platforming to this game, which is always more of a camera angle struggle than anything to do with skill. You just have to jump and reload 100 times until you finally make it through the section. Some of the bosses are ridiculously cheap. People say "GET GUD" but you really just have to get lucky. There is no real story to this game, every character you meet speaks in riddles and you basically have to look everything up on the internet because there are no waypoints or any kind of journal to remind you what you are doing. Don't even think about taking a break for a few days because you will be completely lost. I don't know, certain parts of this game were fun, but all in all, its just a time suck. I would recommend the game, but its not a masterpiece like people say.

The scale is greater in comparison to previous souls games, but the open world design doesn't do the actual gameplay any favors.
The difficulty curve is like a sine wave, every encounter makes me feel either underleveled or overleveled. Bosses in the open world without proper arenas get stuck on uneven terrain, clip into things, and frequently hit the player through walls.
Reinforcing weapons is miserable due to upgrade materials being sequential, requiring a lower tier material in order to use a higher one. This worked in the more linear souls game, but is undermined by and undermines the open world design. If you miss/skip an area with a lower tier smithing stone, you can be stuck for dozens of hours without the ability to upgrade anything.
Bosses get recycled frequently, sometimes as basic respawning enemies that get spammed in later sections of the game.
Boss runbacks aren't as bad, but in exchange you must now press buttons in menus for a while to rematch night time bosses.
It's also possible, and not particularly hard, to miss critical items such as the Flask of Wondrous Physic, resulting in what is essentially a handicapped run.

The invasion experience is somehow even more miserable, but at least you don't have to grind it for achievements anymore.

Boss design is a step backward from Dark Souls 3

Skibidi Toilet is a machinima web series of YouTube videos and shorts created by Alexey Gerasimov and uploaded on his YouTube channel "DaFuq!?Boom!". Produced using Source Filmmaker, the series follows a fictional war between human-headed toilets and humanoid characters with electronic devices for heads. Since the first short was posted in February 2023, Skibidi Toilet has become viral as an internet meme across various social media platforms, particularly among Generation Alpha. Critics saw the series as Generation Alpha's first foray into internet culture, competing with the older Generation Z. Plot and characteristics
The largely dialogue-free[1] series depicts a conflict between singing human-headed toiletsâ€”the titular "Skibidi Toilets"â€”and humanoids with CCTV cameras, speakers, and televisions in place of their heads. In a New York City-esque setting, the Skibidi Toilets, and their leader G-Man, threaten humanity. Two types of humanoids, cameramen and speakermen, form an alliance against the toilets. Each has one of its kind that is much larger than the rest, termed "titans". A toilet parasite infects the Speaker Titan, leading to casualties. Later in the series, TV-headed humanoids and their titan are introduced, and with their help, the speaker titan is broken free from mind control. The battle spreads to other cities, where the titans destroy what seems to be the G-Man, but is later revealed to be an impostor. The titans convene and seems to defeat the mastermind, the Scientist Toilet, but once again are fooled by a decoy. The true Scientist Toilet is revealed to be in hiding.

Business Insider described the series as "an endless arms race as both the toilets and their foes [produce] stronger fighters".[2] A mashup of the songs "Give It to Me" by Timbaland[3] and "Dom Dom Yes Yes" by Biser King,[4] created by TikTok user @doombreaker03,[5] appears in each episode as the theme of the Skibidi Toilets, and is the origin of the name Skibidi.[3] "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" by Tears for Fears is featured in some videos as the theme of the camera-head resistance.[2]

The show contains references to video games, such as the character G-Man, whose name comes from the Half-Life video game series, and the dances performed by the Cameramen are inspired by emotes from the online game Fortnite.[3]

EDIT: So I've completed the game after adding an additional 67 hours. My recommendation hasn't changed however I felt I should ad some comments.
It is a GOOD game. I enjoyed the challenge and felt accomplished when I overcame a difficult boss, however I cannot recommend it. The people who enjoy this type of game already know about it and will already know if they will enjoy it. I would never recommend it to someone who is not already a fan of this genre. I have never played a Souls game and this was my introduction. However I will not play further Fromsoftware games as I am an adult gamer and simply do not have the time to spend attempting the same challenges over and over. I enjoy games for their story and their game play experience, and this game has both, however as my original comment states it did not respect my time and that's a problem for myself, and many adult gamers who do not have a lot of chances to play games. It's a good game by all standards, it ran decently on my PC, it has a compelling story, and the gameplay is unique, however unless you know what you're getting into don't bother.

I do not believe this game is as replayable as the others in the series due to how massive the game is. The best part of this game is how it naturally nudges you to explore, without revealing too much. There cool twists and bizzare creatures that must be slain!

First 25ish hours are great, and then minor, questionable design decisions compound into something that might overstay its welcome. 

The size and scope of this game means that Fromsoft has had to design around a fuck-ton of playstyles. Because of this, no one system is ever fully realized to its full potential.

(That being said, a runtime of 25 hours is almost a full-damn game in itself. And you can easily expect putting in 3-4 times that amount. So, buckle in.)

What this translates to in terms of gameplay, is that the most effective way of beating most bosses is to roll spam, wait for a specific, easily-punishable attack, get a chunk of damage in, rinse and repeat. There's no interesting back-and-forth like Sekiro. There can't be. 

Later in the game, you get punished for playing risky. You can power up your character so much but the bosses do as well. Getting swiped by one move may mean 90% of your health-bar gone because you get stagger-locked into a combo. You aren't forced to take chances at all. And the chances are, if you're able to get greedy and finesse a posture break or parry, you could've beaten the boss without it anyway. 

In the same vein, differening play-styles do have their strengths and weaknesses, but committing to mastering one play-style is actively hamstringing your ability to succeed. You're given a repertoire of tools in this game, and some of them are just frankly busted. This plays to a power fantasy, but it also means that the game isn't really designed around you necessarily "gitting gud", much to the dismay of souls elitists everywhere.

Really that's the crux of the issue of this game. There's underlying good, fun systems here, but the game never makes you take full advantage of them. The path of least resistance is a little lame sometimes, but intentionally gimping yourself because the balance is so off-kilter is its own problem. It tries to be too much all at once, and fails to recreate something as tight and rewarding as Sekiro. It's a great game to play if you're looking for a really satisfying and beautiful fantasy adventure. Just don't expect Sekiro. Go play Sekiro if you want Sekiro. 

Also, don't do it all in one go (or alone, for that matter)

EDIT: As I sit here patiently awaiting the DLC, I have to say: Yeah the balance kinda breaks into a billion pieces at the end-game. Don't go into it expecting perfectly tuned combat. But. As an RPG. It is great. It's just that I tend to look over singleplayer RPGs as they tend not to hold my interest, and the summoning system baked into the game leaves a lot to be desired if you're looking for a Co-Op experience like me. 

However, playing this game with the seamless Co-Op mod has made me re-evaluate my stance and look at it in a different light. I went over some of what I've said and re-worded it to better fit how I feel about the game now. Most of what I said still holds, but I was wanting something out of this game that it never offered. Instead I understood to enjoy it on its own terms. And for that, it is an unforgettable experience that I highly recommend not missing out on.

Elden Ring, the highly anticipated collaboration between FromSoftware and George R.R. Martin, emerges as a mesmerizing opus that seamlessly blends haunting storytelling with punishing gameplay. In this open-world action RPG, players are thrust into the fractured realms of the Lands Between, a vast and desolate landscape brimming with secrets, danger, and a palpable sense of foreboding.

From the moment you step foot into this enigmatic world, Elden Ring envelops you in its atmospheric embrace. The dilapidated ruins, towering castles, and mist-laden forests evoke a sense of melancholic beauty, while the haunting soundtrack sets the tone for a journey fraught with peril and discovery.

At the heart of Elden Ring lies its gameplay, a refined iteration of FromSoftware's signature formula. Combat is weighty and deliberate, requiring precise timing and strategic thinking to overcome the game's myriad challenges. Whether engaging in intense boss battles or navigating treacherous dungeons, every encounter feels like a test of skill and resolve.

One of Elden Ring's most striking features is its open-world design, which encourages exploration and rewards curiosity. From hidden caves to forgotten citadels, the Lands Between is teeming with secrets waiting to be unearthed. The freedom to chart your own path lends a sense of agency rarely found in such expansive worlds, allowing players to forge their own narratives amidst the chaos.

Of course, no discussion of Elden Ring would be complete without mentioning its enigmatic lore, a tapestry woven with threads of myth, legend, and existential dread. George R.R. Martin's influence is keenly felt here, as the game's narrative unfolds through cryptic dialogue, environmental storytelling, and lore-rich item descriptions. Piecing together the fragmented history of the Lands Between is a daunting task, but one that proves immensely rewarding for those willing to delve deep into its mysteries.

However, Elden Ring is not without its flaws. Technical issues, including occasional framerate drops and texture pop-in, mar an otherwise immersive experience. Additionally, some may find the game's punishing difficulty off-putting, especially newcomers to the genre.

In conclusion, Elden Ring stands as a towering achievement in the realm of interactive storytelling. With its breathtaking world design, refined gameplay mechanics, and captivating lore, it represents a high watermark for the action RPG genre. Despite its challenges, the journey through the Lands Between is one that will linger in the minds of players long after the credits roll.

I'm going to start by saying that I have played and beaten many souls and soulslike games. With Demon's Souls for PS3 being my favorite. (I do a full play through about every 3 months.)  What I'm saying is I have experience in souls games.
I played this game entirely in "Offline Mode" Which means no invasions, but also no co-op to help fight bosses.

-Gameplay:
The Gameplay is your standard "souls" game. Only this time in an open world.
You run around, Explore Catacombs and dungeons, kill enemies (or friends), and collect runes (Elden Ring's version of "Souls") to level up your character or spend at merchants to buy items. Like previous souls games if you die the runes in your possession are dropped and you must go to where you died and touch your "Grace" to retrieve your lost runes. If you die again before collecting them then you lose them.
Combat is all about Light attacks, Heavy Attacks, and Dodge rolling until either you or the enemies you are fighting die.
In this game there is a mechanic called "Stance Break" if you attack enemies until you have dealt enough damage in a small enough window of time you "Break" them leaving them open to critical attacks that deal massive damage.
This being a souls game of course bosses are awesome! Wizards, Warriors, Dragons, And Eldritch Horrors beyond mortal comprehension! Every boss fight is so well put together. It feels so good to learn and memorize a bosses move set and eventually defeat them. All of the bosses are challenging but fair. [spoiler] Except Malenia! [/spoiler]
There is a few other gameplay things I could mention but, they are not important to this review.

-Graphics:
This game is gorgeous. They aren't the best graphics ever (Some things are a little smudgy up close) But the art style of this game can't be Topped! From the fields, the catacombs, the ancient capital city, to the snow filled mountaintops of giants. Everything gets you so immersed in the world. And the bosses look awesome! Giant knights in gleaming armor. a sorceress whose battlefield is on a lake Illuminated by a giant moon in the background. Visuals like these coupled with the awesome OST. You will remember every single fight like it was the greatest thing you have ever experienced!

-Sound:
Sound effects in this game are very similar (If not the same) sound effects as other souls games.
Slashes, Clunks, Fire spells Exploding, and even that satisfying *Shing* sound when you kill something. It all feels exactly like a souls game.
The OST on the other hand might be one of my favorites of all time. It has all the classic souls feel of Loud booming war drums and choirs for intense battles with mighty foes. And then there's the somber tracks with a strings orchestra and a single lone echoing voice that brings a heavy air to some of the more atmospheric battles. (Like the aforementioned sorceress fight.) 
And the music that plays in the world is so fitting to every area you will explore.

-Should YOU play this game?:
I can't recommend this game to every one. It is very difficult and demands a lot of time to play. If you don't have experience with soulslike games or you don't play many difficult games be warned this game will be tough. However if you have the patience (and maybe a little skill) then you will play one of the greatest games of the last 20 years.

-Conclusion:
I love this game! I hope that I am able to help you make an informed decision about purchasing this game.
Now if you'll excuse me... I've got other games to play.

"Elden Ring" has garnered widespread acclaim since its release, praised for its expansive open world, intricate lore, and challenging yet rewarding gameplay. It combines the signature difficult combat and deep storytelling FromSoftware is known for with a vast, explorable world that encourages exploration and discovery. The game's design allows for a high degree of freedom in how players approach challenges, with numerous paths to explore and secrets to uncover.

Comparing it to monumental titles like the "Mass Effect Trilogy" and "The Witcher 3" highlights its impact on players and its place in video game history. "Mass Effect Trilogy" is celebrated for its narrative depth, character development, and player-driven choices that have lasting consequences, while "The Witcher 3" is lauded for its rich story, complex characters, and immersive world. Like these titles, "Elden Ring" offers a deep, engaging experience that can consume countless hours, providing a mix of exploration, storytelling, and combat that appeals to a broad spectrum of gamers.

"Elden Ring" stands out for its ambitious scope, challenging gameplay, and the freedom it offers players. Its success is a testament to the game's quality and the developers' vision, making it a must-have for fans of action RPGs and those looking for a rich, immersive gaming experience. Whether for its challenging boss fights, the beauty and depth of its world, or the intricate lore that players can unravel, "Elden Ring" has certainly earned its place among the greatest games of all time.

The culmination of all of Fromsofts previous works, with a whole new universe to learn about. So pretty. So cool. So damn hard, but you just keep wanting more. Wonderful characters and while I don't know much about the lore I always feel compelled to read random tidbits on stuff in the game.

The world is genuinely breathtaking in some parts,[spoiler] especially when you go to that underground area where it feels like you're walking on a planet inside of a galaxy cloud nebula thing. [/spoiler] The bosses are aplenty and honestly they almost all feel unique and are really fun to fight, with the occasional magma worm exception. The different fighting methods are ACTUALLY balanced in single player, you can progress fine with anything you choose (some are definitely more OP than others). The characters all have some charm to them, though they all seem distant, but that's honestly in line with all Fromsoft games and this universe in particular.

10/10 game and more than deserving of Game of The Year, and will likely be in the running for Game of The Decade come 2030.

"Elden Ring" emerges as a colossal achievement in the realm of action RPGs, masterfully crafted by FromSoftware in collaboration with famed novelist George R.R. Martin. This game not only extends the boundaries of open-world exploration but also refines the challenging combat mechanics the studio is renowned for. Set in the enchanting yet perilous lands of the Lands Between, it offers an unparalleled adventure that rewards curiosity and perseverance.

Gameplay and Mechanics
At its core, "Elden Ring" maintains the signature Soulsborne difficulty, demanding precision, patience, and strategic planning from players. The combat is intricate and rewarding, with a wide array of weapons, spells, and skills that cater to numerous playstyles. Stealth mechanics and the ability to summon spirits for assistance add layers to combat strategies. The introduction of a mount significantly enhances exploration, making the vast world more accessible and enjoyable to traverse.

Story and World Design
The narrative, enriched by George R.R. Martin's lore, unfolds in a cryptic manner typical of FromSoftware's storytelling. The world is dense with lore, hidden paths, and secrets that encourage thorough exploration. Each area, from the haunting catacombs to the majestic castles, is meticulously designed and filled with lore, challenging foes, and intricate puzzles. The open-world design does not merely serve as a backdrop but as an active participant in the player's journey, with dynamic weather and time-of-day systems that affect gameplay and exploration.

Visuals and Audio
Graphically, "Elden Ring" is a feast for the eyes, with breathtaking landscapes, detailed character models, and visually stunning spell effects. The art direction effectively captures the beauty and desolation of the Lands Between, supported by a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that elevates the emotional impact of key moments.

Difficulty
The difficulty in "Elden Ring" is a double-edged sword; it's what makes the triumphs so rewarding but can also lead to moments of frustration. The game does not shy away from challenging its players, pushing them to learn and adapt. This steep difficulty curve is balanced with the freedom to explore other areas and tackle challenges in a non-linear fashion, allowing players to seek out new strategies or power up before facing daunting obstacles.

Conclusion
"Elden Ring" stands as a monumental achievement in the video game industry, offering a deep, engaging, and visually stunning experience that will be remembered for years to come. It successfully balances the unforgiving challenge and rewarding exploration with a rich narrative and immersive world. Whether you're battling nightmarish bosses, uncovering ancient mysteries, or simply admiring the landscapes from atop a cliff, "Elden Ring" offers an adventure like no other. It's a testament to FromSoftware's mastery in game design and a beacon for future action RPGs.
