TL/DR: A flawed masterpiece. A new benchmark for open world exploration and arguably the easiest of the souls titles. Elden Ring is a fantastic journey. Absolutely recommended.
Â 
-
Â 
Elden Ring is an Action RPG in the sense that you level up your stats so your chosen stick hits for ever higher numbers. There is some sort of story, too. Choices even matter.
Â 
You are, once again, thrown into a mysterious, hostile world and set on your path to some resemblance of godhood. You pick your weapons and play style, explore the world and usually die a lot. Assuming a certain familiarity with the genre in general, so far, so soulslike.
Â 
The gameplay loop of killing enemies, acquiring souls (or runes in this case) as currency or XP and figuring out cryptic quest dialogue just to miss the trigger point anyway stays more or less the same. Combat feels like a good combination of previous systems with some meaningful additions. 
You still have your bonfires (or graces), an invasion/summoning system and grotesquely designed monsters to fight. You will forget attack patterns and dodge too early, veterans will feel right at home.
Â 
However this time, it's an open world. With what sometimes seems like even less handholding than before. Whereas there were complex labyrinths of gothic brick, now there is a massive, interconnected country to explore. Filled to the brim with hidden NPCs, dungeons and secrets, towering castles and a lush variety of colours and landscapes. That and a plethora of things out to obliterate you. They really got creative this time, to a point. (More on that later.)
Â 
Exploration in Elden Ring is rewarding. I feel like a lot of the good stuff was superbly hidden off the more obvious path, and sometimes what looks like a short detour might offer up whole new areas of the land. It is entirely possible to pass by major bosses and huge storylines without even knowing about them in the first place.
The game hints you in a vague direction and lets you figure out the rest on your own. It demands you to read it's item descriptions, to actually pay attention to what someone has to say. Otherwise you could miss out on half the game. I like that. It gives away a sense of accomplishment the usual yellow brick path could never manage to deliver. This is my taste, mind, your's may differ.
Â 
After more than two hundred hours in the Lands Between, I didn't see everything. Yet.
As mentioned, decisions matter, and some will have irreversible and lasting effects on the world and its people. There will be no warning. Consequence will take time. Something to look forward to in the next run, with a different outcome than before. Relevant characters can die and do not respawn. Looking at more recent games, imagine that.
Â 
Combat builds around the familiar systems of parry, dodge, block and weapon move-sets on your side against learning enemies' attack patterns and finding (waiting for) an opening. With the added verticality of jumping here. You can stagger your opponents, bring them to their knees to land a special attack. Choose between poison or bleeding them out. Burn or literally kill them with lasers. Pick yours, everything is viable. It's on you.

Admittedly, certain weapons are clearly better than others in PVE, but this brings me to my next point: adjustable difficulty. With a new system of NPC companions (additionally to the usual summoned help), special (and swappable) abilities on weapons and the convenience of just going to a different place after hitting a wall, Elden Ring is way more accessible than previous titles. Challenge remains, though. It is a souls game, after all.

Elden Ring is massive in size, with a first play-through easily lasting for 120h and more, and I feel this variety in difficulty gives me as a player more agency on how to progress. Sometimes it just feels good watching your other self massacre everything with ease. Sometimes you just need it smooth.
Â 
I mentioned flaws, and while I love this game, there are some:
Â 
Mounted combat more often than not just boils down to two adversaries missing each other repeatedly. While I did enjoy the pythonesque moments the first few times, novelty wore off quickly. If the darn thing disappears because spoilers, well.
Â 
There is great variety in common enemies and normal bosses alike, however later on some tend to repeat quite a lot. I do not mind clearing the umpteenth 'gargoyle dungeon' or 'zombie cave', but if my reward is the same boss I killed five times over, I might as well just look up if the drops are even worth the effort.
Â 
Major bosses are very good. That said some feel a bit over-tuned. Not in ways of difficulty (or relentlessness for that matter, as a certain katana wielder may be my favourite in all the souls titles), but in length of their attack patterns. I can acknowledge that my massive lump of steel bolted to an even bigger dragon bone is not the fastest to swing around, but waiting twenty seconds for the boss to decide chaining into another nine hit combo and then fly away is not fun. Besides, if I can wield such brute force, this tiny bow (all my crude hands are able to handle without dexterity) just feels wrong to use as an alternative. So does using something over-tuned (or a shield) myself.
Â 
Both recycling and questionable bossfights led to slight tedium in the end. To be fair, it may or may not have helped to clear every dungeon during my first run. Your mileage may vary.
Â 
On a technical level the game runs quite well, with the occasional stutter. Nothing serious, inconvenient comparable to your last stupid death. You know, when you rode straight off a cliff. (1080p, 2060 6GB, R5, 32GB, high preset)
Â 
After so many games, I still wish there was a better way to consume a lot of different souls (runes). Travelling to a merchant is kind of annoying. Selecting them more so. This is nothing important, but I am still serious. Just let me trade in my fourteen different rune containers at sites of grace. 
Â 
Lastly, I want to note on your weird horse, Torrent. There is no useless minigame behind him. You don't need to feed him limited carrots for more sprint duration. If you're outdoors and want more reach, just summon him and have at it. He even comes with a double jump, right away.
As traversal is both an important means of immersion, as it is one of simple exploration, Torrent executes perfectly. He is fast and versatile enough to cover good distance in a time that still manages to make you feel the weight of the world around. Most importantly, your strange goat does not get stuck on terrain. (Fall damage is another matter entirely, but see for yourself.)
Â 
Elden Ring may have it's flaws, but I still regard it as a masterpiece. Exploring the beautiful Lands Between was a joy. I felt rewarded for experimentation and more often than not stumbled upon something entirely unexpected. The story is great, the world and its characters, albeit quite grim, were fun and memorable to experience. I would recommend playing it.
Â 
Be brave, Tarnished.

[b]well-deserved 2022 game of the year.[/b] i'm writing this review while currently in my 1st playthrough and farming materials that would carry over to new game plus.

dark souls 2 and elden ring were the only soulsborne games i ever played and i could say the latter offers a more vibrant and massive world to explore with good replayability as expected from the newer release.

things to look out for:
â–ªexperiment with various builds, get beefy af, and still get one/two-shotted
â–ªtakes a sheer amount of luck to look for and/or determine what to do with the npcs in this game and correctly knowing what to do with them is already an achievement by itself
â–ªfight world boss, roll, lock-on -> locks on to deer/jellyfish -.-
â–ªno steam game has ever made me want to uninstall until i, using a melee build, fought [spoiler]malenia and maliketh[/spoiler]

despite sounding like inconveniences, the aforementioned are the reasons why i enjoy playing the game as they give a sense of accomplishment beating boss after boss. you can 100 percent the steam achievements in one playthrough by [spoiler]doing almost all possible npc quests (some of which are mutually exclusive), then backing up the save file which you can then just keep on swapping by the time you have to choose your preferred ending after beating the final boss (there are 6 in-game endings but only 3 are required for steam achievements).[/spoiler]

this game has absolutely set a high standard in the franchise and i hope the dlc/s would not disappoint.

Well, slap my character and call me an undead potato, because Elden Ring is like a medieval fever dream on steroids! I haven't been this lost since I tried reading a map without my glasses â€“ and let me tell you, it's a wild ride!

First off, let's talk about the horses. These majestic beasts have the directional skills of a confused GPS. I named mine "Wrong Way" because, you guessed it, that's the only way it seems to know. The amount of times I've ended up in a swamp while trying to reach a majestic castle is almost impressive.

The character customization is so in-depth that I spent a solid hour just deciding the perfect nose for my knight. I mean, who cares about slaying dragons when you can have a perfectly sculpted schnoz?

The enemies in Elden Ring are like misunderstood poets â€“ you can't really understand what they're saying, and they're always trying to stab you with a giant sword. But hey, at least they have commitment! They'll chase you across the map like a relentless door-to-door salesman, and I respect that kind of hustle.

The lore in this game is so deep, I almost drowned in it. There are so many cryptic messages and ancient runes that I started to think my character was majoring in medieval philosophy. I'm just here to bash skeletons, not write a dissertation on the meaning of life!

The multiplayer aspect is like a medieval Tinder â€“ summoning phantoms left and right. "Looking for a sunbro to help me slay a dragon. Must be skilled in jolly cooperation and have a good sense of humor. Serious inquiries only."

And let's not forget the boss battles â€“ they're like a twisted game of dance, where you're desperately trying to remember the steps while a giant monster is trying to turn you into a medieval pancake. Spoiler alert: I'm not the best dancer.

All in all, Elden Ring is like a spicy stew of chaos, exploration, and questionable fashion choices (looking at you, armor sets). If you're into intense gameplay, breathtaking landscapes, and the occasional existential crisis, Elden Ring is the game for you. Just don't forget your map â€“ or your sense of humor.

fromsoft no longer knows how to design a good souls boss.

fromsoft hasnt had good consistent well designed souls bosses without major caveats since DS3 basegame. they fell into the bullsh*t toxic elitist gamerbro fan 'git gud scrub' hype that was NEVER what made souls games good, and their sh*t has suffered greatly since.

(note that by 'souls game' i specifically am NOT including sekiro. IMO from what ive seen sekiro isnt a souls game in its core design, also ive not played it, so am not going to offer an opinion on its difficulty in this area.)

every time i run into a boss in elden ring that looks like it might be well designed, they add SOMETHING to ruin it completely. 80s arcade 'nintendo hard' bad frustrating unreasonable difficulty that sucks to experience.

if players are getting consistently frustrated at your difficulty, you have failed. it should feel like a challenge to overcome, not like beating your head against a brick wall out of spite, hoping the ai just decides not to use the unblockable undodgable 17-hit AoE combo moves this attempt.

i have played every souls game more times than i can count. i have solo'd every boss. i have played numerous non-fromsoft soulslikes. i KNOW this franchise, i KNOW this genre. im VERY good at it. ER is by far the worst experience i have ever had with a fromsoft-made souls game. it just doesnt come together in the end. the bosses feel like they are tuned for a slightly different game with slightly different controls and player character animation speeds. theres a mismatch, a desync. it feels like it needed two more polishing/tweaking passes.

now that ive finally beaten this stupid f*cking game for the first time, im going to do something ive never done with a souls game: uninstall it and never think of it again. no NG+, no new playthrus with new builds, no npc sidequest runs (talk about bad game design, fromsoft sidequests have always been terrible game design and they dont seem interested in ever fixing that nonsense...) and CERTAINLY no dlc. the only thing that kept me going to the end was looking forward to writing this review knowing i'd beaten it, and freeing up 48 GBs.

also the open world is nothing special. it may be hand crafted, and it certainly LOOKS pretty, but its still mostly empty of things of actual interest. a weapon i dont care about here, a useless ash there, some resources, a really f*ckin sh*tty AoE spamming field boss designed by a 9 year old who pulls the heads off of puppies in his spare time. and the optional dungeons are almost chalice dungeon level bad. with some of the worst designed bosses, too. the ones that arent 'potentially good but ruined by one or two mechanics', but the ones that are categorically sh*t from start to finish.

somewhere along the way during dev on the DS3 DLCs, fromsoft lost something. i noted it at the time but hoped it was an aberration. it wasnt. fromsoft changed. they lost the sense for the TYPE of difficulty that made their games great. now its just masochistic 'git gud' absurd meme bait bullsh*ttery all the way down. i felt it in the DS3 DLCs but it was managable. i felt it even stronger in elden ring, and i think im done. if thats the style fromsoft wants to make going forward, then this is where we part ways. some other dev will surely develop the good soulslikes moving forward.

great game

An excellent game with few oversights.

Pros:
-An absolute masterpiece. Stunning visuals. Stunning audio.
-Most forgiving soulslike game due to mostly excellent grace placement.
-Still challenging and rewarding.
-Atmosphere, has peaceful meadows, complex castles, and areas that feel like a horror game.
-Voice acting is incredible. You can hear the emotion in the voices of NPCs.
-Martyr stakes make jolly cooperation incredibly easy an convenient.
-Weapon upgrade system is very intuitive and flexible.
-Brought back power stanced weapons.
-Kept paired weapons like caestus and claws that don't require upgrading 2 of them separately.
-Guard counters make shields far more useful.
-Simplified magic types allow flexibility without removing their unique feel and features.
-Made the lore and story more accessible to people who don't want to read item descriptions.
-Invasions and hunter phantoms work very well.

Cons:
-Some areas seem to cause terrible framerate regardless of graphics quality settings.

Cons from PVP: (separate for a reason)
-Fromsoft still refuses to implement simple fixes to prevent packmule cheaters. This really isn't a problem once you're level 40+. The main issue with this is that as a new player, I really didn't want to see end game weapons and spells before I've encountered them organically. Spoilers suck and getting killed by them ruins the opportunity to be surprised and terrified of them when you encounter that boss or area.
-No apparent post invasion timer, if you are killed by an invader or kill them you can be invaded again almost immediately. This can make PVP feel more like a nuisance rather than extra excitement that just adds challenge when other PVP related problems are also happening simultaneously. Sometimes there's no break from it, killing or being killed by the invading player should feel exciting. Instead it feels like some form of chore or outright pest control.
-No invasion time limit. If you cant kill the host in 30 minutes you're time should be up. Instead, invaders can run off into the distance for over an hour, waiting for the NPC enemies to kill you or just wasting your time. There doesn't seem to be a time limit. This makes going to other areas impossible without jumping of a cliff or disconnecting. The previous souls games had small enough areas that it didn't matter, you could clear the enemies and make it to the boss room or corner the invader if they chose to be passive.
-PVP compass. I absolutely understand why locating the host player in an open world is vital. However, given the previous issue described, it doesn't really make sense to have the host appear on the compass for the invader only. Being unable to locate an invader who has run off into the distance makes eliminating them nearly impossible.

-This one is much less of an issue but it still seems like a poor choice in game design. You can be invaded after starting a boss fight. I understand that open world bosses shouldn't function like a fog gate and cause an invasion to end, that would make invasions pointless since the host could simply trigger a fight and then run until the boss loses aggro. That being said if you've already started a boss fight it seems a little ridiculous to have someone come and gank you when the boss is 3 hits from death. Given the ease of retrieving runes this isn't really a big deal. It is a Fromsoft game, it's supposed to be difficult and punishing.

Overall still a solid 11/10 game. Developers not anticipating how features will be used or abused in multiplayer is nothing new and most of the issues seem to be limited to low level encounters. My experience is that after Stormveil castle and above level 40 most players seem to be happy to just fight you rather than attempting some drawn out time wasting strategy.

The FromSoftware group make merciless games with little to no guidance. When I first started playing, I found this incredibly frustrating and, as this was my first Souls Like game, I put it down for months. But a funny thing happened, you pick it back up, you slowly start to figure out the mechanics, you level up and get more powerful, and the next thing you know, your hundreds of hours in and realize that the grind has been so very much worth it. You appreciate the game more than any other because of the how hard it was when you first started. If this isn't my favorite game ever (a place still in my heart for BOTW), its a close second. This game is incredible
